paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter DEMETRIUS and PHILO$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$PHILO
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS and PHILO enter.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$PHILO

paragraphs.original: PHILO$NEWLINE$Nay, but this dotage of our general’s$NEWLINE$O’erflows the measure. Those his goodly eyes,$NEWLINE$That o’er the files and musters of the war$NEWLINE$Have glowed like plated Mars, now bend, now turn$NEWLINE$The office and devotion of their view$NEWLINE$Upon a tawny front. His captain’s heart,$NEWLINE$Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst$NEWLINE$The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper$NEWLINE$And is become the bellows and the fan$NEWLINE$To cool a gypsy’s lust.
paragraphs.translated: PHILO$NEWLINE$No, our general’s infatuation is out of control. His eyes used to glow with pride when he reviewed his troops. Now his eyes devote themselves exclusively to a certain brown-skinned face. His heart used to burst the buckles on his breastplate in great fights, but now he’s lost all temperance and dedicates his heart to satisfying the lust of an Egyptian whore.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, her ladies, the train, with eunuchs fanning her$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated:
A
trumpet fanfare announces the entrance of ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, her ladies and attendants, and eunuchs with fans.$NEWLINE$trumpet fanfare$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$ANTONY, CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: Look where they come.$NEWLINE$Take but good note, and you shall see in him$NEWLINE$The triple pillar of the world transformed$NEWLINE$Into a strumpet’s fool. Behold and see.
paragraphs.translated: Look at them. Take a good look, and you’ll see that one of the three men who rule the world has turned into a whore’s jester. Look and see.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$If it be love indeed, tell me how much.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$If what you feel is really love, tell me how much.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$There’s beggary in the love that can be reckoned.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$It would be a pretty stingy love if it could be counted and calculated.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I’ll set a bourn how far to be beloved.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I want to measure the extent of your love, to see how far it stretches.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Then you would have to go beyond heaven, beyond earth.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$News, my good lord, from Rome.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I have news from Rome, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Grates me, the sum.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Which irritaties me. Give me a summary.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Nay, hear them, Antony.$NEWLINE$Fulvia perchance is angry. Or who knows$NEWLINE$If the scarce-bearded Caesar have not sent$NEWLINE$His powerful mandate to you, “Do this, or this.$NEWLINE$Take in that kingdom, and enfranchise that.$NEWLINE$Perform ’t, or else we damn thee.”
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No, listen to it, Antony. Perhaps
Fulvia is angry with you. Who knows, maybe the
baby-faced Caesar has orders for you: “Do this, do that; conquer that kingdom, liberate this one. Do it or we’ll condemn you.”$NEWLINE$Fulvia$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$baby-faced Caesar$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                   How, my love?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What, my love?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Perchance? Nay, and most like.$NEWLINE$You must not stay here longer. Your dismission$NEWLINE$Is come from Caesar. Therefore hear it, Antony.$NEWLINE$Where’s Fulvia’s process? Caesar’s, I would say—both?$NEWLINE$Call in the messengers. As I am Egypt’s queen,$NEWLINE$Thou blushest, Antony, and that blood of thine$NEWLINE$Is Caesar’s homager. Else so thy cheek pays shame$NEWLINE$When shrill-tongued Fulvia scolds. The messengers!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Maybe? No, most likely. You can’t stay here any longer. Caesar has sent your dismissal, so pay attention, Antony. Where’s Fulvia’s summons—excuse me, I should have said Caesar’s. Or do Fulvia and Caesar both beckon you back to Rome? Call in the messengers and we’ll find out. As surely as I am the queen of Egypt, Antony, you’re blushing, which means you’re Caesar’s servant. Or that that bitch Fulvia still has the power to humiliate you. Call the messengers!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Let Rome in Tiber melt and the wide arch$NEWLINE$Of the ranged empire fall. Here is my space.$NEWLINE$Kingdoms are clay. Our dungy earth alike$NEWLINE$Feeds beast as man. The nobleness of life$NEWLINE$Is to do thus, when such a mutual pair$NEWLINE$And such a twain can do ’t, in which I bind,$NEWLINE$On pain of punishment, the world to weet$NEWLINE$We stand up peerless.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Let Rome be washed away in the Tiber and let the great empire fall. My place is here. Kingdoms are only dirt. The soil feeds animals as well as people, so how does having a kingdom separate humans from beasts? The noblest thing is to do what we’re doing, particularly when the couple is as well matched as we are. I demand that the world admit we are the perfect couple or else suffer the consequences.$NEWLINE$Let Rome be washed away in the Tiber$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                            Excellent falsehood!$NEWLINE$Why did he marry Fulvia, and not love her?$NEWLINE$I’ll seem the fool I am not. Antony$NEWLINE$Will be himself.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to herself) What an enormous lie! Why did he marry Fulvia if he didn’t love her? I’ll pretend to be a fool and believe him. He’ll never change.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                But stirred by Cleopatra.$NEWLINE$Now, for the love of Love and her soft hours,$NEWLINE$Let’s not confound the time with conference harsh.$NEWLINE$There’s not a minute of our lives should stretch$NEWLINE$Without some pleasure now. What sport tonight?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(overhearing the last sentence) Unless he is moved and inspired by Cleopatra. Now, since we love the feeling of being in love, let’s not spoil the mood with serious discussion. We shouldn’t spend a minute without some kind of amusement. What shall we do tonight?$NEWLINE$(overhearing the last sentence)

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Hear the ambassadors.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Meet with the ambassadors.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                             Fie, wrangling Queen!$NEWLINE$Whom every thing becomes—to chide, to laugh,$NEWLINE$To weep, whose every passion fully strives$NEWLINE$To make itself, in thee, fair and admired!$NEWLINE$No messenger but thine, and all alone$NEWLINE$Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and note$NEWLINE$The qualities of people. Come, my Queen,$NEWLINE$Last night you did desire it.—(to the MESSENGER ) Speak not to us.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$MESSENGER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Shame on you, stubborn Queen! Everything you do is attractive—scolding, laughing, crying—every emotion seems admirable when you express it. I won’t see any messengers but yours. Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and observe the people. Come, my Queen. That’s what you wanted to do last night. (to the MESSENGER ) Don’t talk to us.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$MESSENGER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTONY and CLEOPATRA with the train$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and CLEOPATRA exit with their attendants.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Is Caesar with Antonius prized so slight?
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Does Antony have so little respect for Caesar?

paragraphs.original: PHILO$NEWLINE$Sir, sometimes when he is not Antony$NEWLINE$He comes too short of that great property$NEWLINE$Which still should go with Antony.
paragraphs.translated: PHILO$NEWLINE$Sir, sometimes he’s like a different person, a person who can’t measure up to the former Antony.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$                                                                     I am full sorry$NEWLINE$That he approves the common liar, who$NEWLINE$Thus speaks of him at Rome, but I will hope$NEWLINE$Of better deeds tomorrow. Rest you happy!
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I’m sad to say this confirms the stories being told about him in Rome, which I had taken to be lies. Well, I’ll hope things change for the better soon. Have a good night!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ENOBARBUS, LAMPRIUS, a SOOTHSAYER, Rannius, LUCILLIUS, CHARMIAN, IRAS, MARDIAN the eunuch, and ALEXAS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$LAMPRIUS$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$LUCILLIUS$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$MARDIAN$NEWLINE$ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS, LAMPRIUS, the FORTUNETELLER, Rannius, LUCILLUS, CHARMIAN, IRAS, MARDIAN the eunuch, and ALEXAS enter.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$LAMPRIUS$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$LUCILLUS$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$MARDIAN$NEWLINE$ALEXAS

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost most absolute Alexas, where’s the soothsayer that you praised so to th’ Queen? Oh that I knew this husband, which, you say, must charge his horns with garlands!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost the most consummate Alexas, where’s the fortuneteller you recommended so highly to the Queen? Oh, I only wish I knew the name of that husband you said he predicted will have a cheating wife!

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Soothsayer!
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$(calling) Fortuneteller!$NEWLINE$(calling)

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Your will?
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$What can I do for you?

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(to ALEXAS ) Is this the man? (to SOOTHSAYER ) Is ’t you, sir, that know things?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ALEXAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(to ALEXAS ) Is this the man you recommended? (to the FORTUNETELLER ) Are you the man who knows the future?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ALEXAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$In nature’s infinite book of secrecy$NEWLINE$A little I can read.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$I can understand a few of nature’s infinite secrets.

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$(to CHARMIAN )         Show him your hand.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$(to CHARMIAN ) Give him your hand to read.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(to servants within) Bring in the banquet quickly. Wine enough$NEWLINE$(to servants within)$NEWLINE$Cleopatra’s health to drink.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(to the servants) Bring the dessert in right away, and make sure there’s enough wine to toast Cleopatra’s health.$NEWLINE$(to the servants)

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(giving hand to SOOTHSAYER ) Good sir, give me good fortune.$NEWLINE$(giving hand to$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(giving her hand to the FORTUNETELLER ) Kind sir, give me a good fortune.$NEWLINE$(giving her hand to the$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$I make not, but foresee.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$I don’t make fortunes; I only see them.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Pray, then, foresee me one.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Then see a good one for me.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$You shall be yet far fairer than you are.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$Your beauty will be even greater than it is now.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(to the others) He means in flesh.$NEWLINE$(to the others)
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(to the others) He means I’ll get fat.$NEWLINE$(to the others)

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$No, you shall paint when you are old.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$No, he means you’ll use makeup when you’re old.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Wrinkles forbid!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$May my wrinkles forbid that!

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Vex not his prescience. Be attentive.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Don’t joke about his predictions. Pay attention.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Hush!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Quiet!

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$You shall be more beloving than beloved.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$You will love more than you are loved.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$I had rather heat my liver with drinking.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$I would rather get passion from drink than from love.$NEWLINE$I would rather get passion from drink$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Nay, hear him.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Just listen to him.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Good now, some excellent fortune! Let me be married to three kings in a forenoon and widow them all. Let me have a child at fifty, to whom Herod of Jewry may do homage. Find me to marry me with Octavius Caesar, and companion me with my mistress.
paragraphs.translated:
CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Be kind now and tell me some excellent fortune. Tell me that I’ll marry three kings before noon and be widowed by all of them. Tell me I’ll have a child when I’m fifty who will be honored even by
Herod of Judea. Let me marry Octavius Caesar and become my Queen’s equal.$NEWLINE$Herod of Judea$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$You will outlive the Queen.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, excellent! I love long life better than figs.
paragraphs.translated:
CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, excellent! I love long life better than
figs.$NEWLINE$figs$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$You have seen and proved a fairer former fortune$NEWLINE$Than that which is to approach.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$You have already had better fortune than the future will bring.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Then belike my children shall have no names. Prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have?
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Then my children will probably be illegitimate. Tell me, please: how many boys and girls will I have?

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$If every of your wishes had a womb,$NEWLINE$And fertile every wish, a million.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$If every time you wished for a child you could have had one, you would have a million children.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Out, fool! I forgive thee for a witch.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Get out of here, you fool! Since you’re a fortuneteller I won’t bring charges of witchcraft against you.

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$You seem to think no one outside of your bedroom knows what you wish.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(to SOOTHSAYER ) Nay, come, tell Iras hers.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$(to FORTUNETELLER ) Never mind. Tell Iras’s fortune.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$We’ll know all our fortunes.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$We’ll all want our fortune told.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Mine, and most of our fortunes tonight, shall be—drunk to bed.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$My fortune—like that of many of us tonight—is to go drunk to bed.

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$(giving her hand to the SOOTHSAYER ) There’s a palm presages chastity, if nothing else.$NEWLINE$(giving her hand to the$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$(giving her hand to the FORTUNETELLER ) There’s a palm that will predict a chaste life, if nothing else.$NEWLINE$(giving her hand to the$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$E’en as the o’erflowing Nilus presageth famine.
paragraphs.translated:
CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Like the
overflowing Nile predicts famine.$NEWLINE$overflowing Nile$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Oh stop it, you lusty bed-hopper. You can’t see the future.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I cannot scratch mine ear.—Prithee, tell her but a workaday fortune.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Well, if a moist palm isn’t a clear sign of promiscuity, then I can’t scratch my own ear. (to FORTUNETELLER ) Please, tell her an ordinary fortune.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Your fortunes are alike.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$Your fortunes are the same.

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$But how, but how? Give me particulars.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$But how? How is that possible? Give me details.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$I have said.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$I’ve said what I have to say.

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Am I not an inch of fortune better than she?
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Isn’t my fortune just a little better than hers? By an inch, even?

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I, where would you choose it?
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Well, if you could have just an inch of better fortune than me, where would you like the improvement?

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Not in my husband’s nose.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Not in my husband’s nose.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Our worser thoughts heavens mend. Alexas! (to SOOTHSAYER ) Come, his fortune, his fortune! Oh, let him marry a woman that cannot go, sweet Isis, I beseech thee, and let her die too, and give him a worse, and let worse follow worse, till the worst of all follow him laughing to his grave, fifty-fold a cuckold! Good Isis, hear me this prayer, though thou deny me a matter of more weight, good Isis, I beseech thee!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated:
CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$May heaven save us from indecent thoughts! Alexas! (to the FORTUNETELLER ) Come and tell his fortune. Let him marry a woman he can’t satisfy, dear
Isis, I pray! And then let her die, and give him someone worse. Then let her die, and let her replacement be even worse. And so on until the last one, who is unfaithful with at least fifty other men and laughs at him until he dies. I beg you to grant my prayer, good Isis, even though it means you deny me something more important for myself. Good Isis, I beg you!$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Isis$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$her

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Amen, dear goddess, hear that prayer of the people! For, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded. Therefore, dear Isis, keep decorum, and fortune him accordingly.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Amen, dear goddess. Listen to our prayer. If it’s sad to see a handsome man with a cheating wife, it’s a tragedy to see an ugly thug with a wife who’s faithful. Therefore, dear Isis, do the right thing and give him the fortune he deserves.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Amen.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Amen.

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$(to himself) Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make me a cuckold, they would make themselves whores but they’d do ’t.$NEWLINE$(to himself)
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$(to himself) See! If they could make me a cuckold, they’d whore themselves in order to see it done.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Hush! Here comes Antony.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Quiet! Here comes Antony.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Not he. The Queen.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$It’s not him; it’s the Queen.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Enter$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA enters.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Saw you my lord?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Have you seen my lord?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$No, lady.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$No, lady.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Was he not here?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Wasn’t he here?

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$No, madam.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$No, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$He was disposed to mirth, but on the sudden$NEWLINE$A Roman thought hath struck him.—Enobarbus!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$He was in a good mood, and then suddenly he started thinking of Rome. Enobarbus?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Madam?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Madam?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Seek him and bring him hither.—$NEWLINE$Where’s Alexas?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Find him and bring him here. Where’s Alexas?

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Here at your service. My lord approaches.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Here, at your service. Here comes my lord.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY with the FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and the FIRST MESSENGER enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$We will not look upon him. Go with us.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I won’t see him. Everyone come with me.$NEWLINE$I won’t see him.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ANTONY and the FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: Everyone follows CLEOPATRA out, leaving ANTONY and the FIRST MESSENGER.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Your wife, Fulvia, mustered her army first.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Against my brother Lucius?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Against my brother Lucius?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Ay.$NEWLINE$But soon that war had end, and the time’s state$NEWLINE$Made friends of them, joining their force ’gainst Caesar,$NEWLINE$Whose better issue in the war from Italy$NEWLINE$Upon the first encounter drave them.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Yes. But that war ended as soon as circumstances made it advisable for them to join together against Caesar. But in their very first battle, Caesar won and drove them out of Italy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Well, what worst?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Well, give me the worst news.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The nature of bad news infects the teller.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The bearer of bad news is often blamed for it.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$When it concerns the fool or coward. On.$NEWLINE$Things that are past are done, with me. ’Tis thus:$NEWLINE$Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death,$NEWLINE$I hear him as he flattered.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Only if the hearer is a fool or a coward. Go on. As far as I’m concerned, what’s past is done. It’s like this: as long as a person tells me the truth, even though it means my death, I will listen as though he praised me.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                 Labienus—$NEWLINE$This is stiff news—hath with his Parthian force$NEWLINE$Extended Asia: from Euphrates$NEWLINE$His conquering banner shook, from Syria$NEWLINE$To Lydia and to Ionia,$NEWLINE$Whilst—
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The news is disturbing.
Labienus, with the army he led in Parthia, has conquered all of Asia, all the way to the Euphrates River, including Syria, Lydia, and Ionia, while—$NEWLINE$Labienus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$“Antony,” thou wouldst say.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$“While Antony . . .” is what you want to say.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                        O my lord!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Oh, my lord!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Speak to me home. Mince not the general tongue.$NEWLINE$Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome.$NEWLINE$Rail thou in Fulvia’s phrase, and taunt my faults$NEWLINE$With such full license as both truth and malice$NEWLINE$Have power to utter. Oh, then we bring forth weeds$NEWLINE$When our quick minds lie still, and our ills told us$NEWLINE$Is as our earing.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Speak plainly. Don’t tone down what the people are saying. Call Cleopatra what the Romans call her. Use Fulvia’s abusive language. Freely scold me for my faults with as much severity as an enemy with truth on his side. It’s easy to err when left to our own devices, but criticism helps us to see our faults and correct them.

paragraphs.original: Enter SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A SECOND MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: Fare thee well awhile.
paragraphs.translated: Good-bye for a while.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$At your noble pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I’ll be at your service.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$From Sicyon, how, the news? Speak there.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY$NEWLINE$What’s the news from
Sicyon. Tell me.$NEWLINE$Sicyon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The man from Sicyon—
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The man from Sicyon—

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                Is there such an one?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Is he here?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He stays upon your will.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He’s waiting outside.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                               Let him appear.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Have him come in.

paragraphs.original: Exit SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$SECOND$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: These strong Egyptian fetters I must break,$NEWLINE$Or lose myself in dotage.
paragraphs.translated: (to himself) I must break Cleopatra’s powerful hold over me or else I’ll lose myself in foolish infatuation.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter THIRD MESSENGER, with a letter$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A THIRD MESSENGER enters with a letter.$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: What are you?
paragraphs.translated: What’s your message?

paragraphs.original: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Fulvia thy wife is dead.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Your wife, Fulvia, is dead.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                              Where died she?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where did she die?

paragraphs.original: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$In Sicyon.$NEWLINE$Her length of sickness, with what else more serious$NEWLINE$Importeth thee to know, this bears.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$In Sicyon. In this letter you’ll find details of her illness and other, more serious matters that concern you.

paragraphs.original: He gives ANTONY a letter$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: He hands the letter to ANTONY.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                     Forbear me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Leave me.

paragraphs.original: Exit THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Exit$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The THIRD MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: (to himself) There’s a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$What our contempts doth often hurl from us$NEWLINE$We wish it ours again. The present pleasure,$NEWLINE$By revolution lowering, does become$NEWLINE$The opposite of itself. She’s good, being gone.$NEWLINE$The hand could pluck her back that shoved her on.$NEWLINE$I must from this enchanting Queen break off.$NEWLINE$Ten thousand harms, more than the ills I know$NEWLINE$My idleness doth hatch.—How now, Enobarbus!
paragraphs.translated: (to himself) A great spirit has gone from the world! This is what I wanted. Once it’s gone, the very thing we reject becomes what we desire. What’s enjoyable one day becomes the opposite as time rolls around. Now that she’s gone, I want her. Now I would call her back, though I pushed her away. I have to break from this beguiling Queen. The time I’ve wasted here has caused ten thousand more problems than the ones I know about. (calling) Are you there, Enobarbus?$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$. (calling)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS enters.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$What’s your pleasure, sir?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$What would you like, sir?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I must with haste from hence.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I have to leave right away.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Why, then, we kill all our women. We see how mortal an unkindness is to them. If they suffer our departure, death’s the word.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$That will kill our lovers. We know how much they suffer if we are unkind to them. If we leave, it will feel like nothing less than death to them.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I must be gone.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I must be gone.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Under a compelling occasion, let women die. It were pity to cast them away for nothing, though between them and a great cause they should be esteemed nothing. Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of this, dies instantly. I have seen her die twenty times upon far poorer moment. I do think there is mettle in death, which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a celerity in dying.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$If it’s that important, then let the women die. It would be a pity to throw them away for nothing, but if it’s a matter of choosing between them and a great cause, then they’re worthless. If Cleopatra hears even a breath of this, she’ll die immediately. I’ve seen her claim to be dying twenty times before, and for far less reason. I think there must be something invigorating about death, since she dies with such enthusiasm.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$She is cunning past man’s thought.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$She’s more cunning than anyone can imagine.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Alack, sir, no, her passions are made of nothing but the finest part of pure love. We cannot call her winds and waters sighs and tears. They are greater storms and tempests than almanacs can report. This cannot be cunning in her. If it be, she makes a shower of rain as well as Jove.
paragraphs.translated:
ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Alas, sir, no, her feelings come from pure love, not cleverness. Her sighs and tears are like great winds and floods. She has more storms and tempests in her than a weather almanac. Her temper is not a trick or a skill—if it is, she can make it rain as well as
Jove.$NEWLINE$Jove$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Would I had never seen her!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I wish I’d never seen her!

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$O sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful piece of work which not to have been blessed withal would have discredited your travel.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Then you’d have missed an amazing piece of work, sir, and your trip would have been poorer for the loss.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Fulvia is dead.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Fulvia is dead.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Sir?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Pardon me?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Fulvia is dead.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Fulvia is dead.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Fulvia?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Fulvia?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Dead.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Dead.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice. When it pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a man from him, it shows to man the tailors of the earth, comforting therein, that when old robes are worn out, there are members to make new. If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented. This grief is crowned with consolation. Your old smock brings forth a new petticoat, and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Then you should offer the gods a sacrifice to show your thanks. When a man’s wife dies, he can be comforted by the knowledge that there are replacements to be found. If Fulvia were the last woman on earth, there would be a reason to grieve. But in this way, grief and comfort appear together. The only kind of tears you should shed in this case are the kind you might get from holding an onion to your nose.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The business she hath broached in the state$NEWLINE$Cannot endure my absence.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I must go and continue the business Fulvia started.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$And the business you have broached here cannot be without you, especially that of Cleopatra’s, which wholly depends on your abode.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$The business you began here needs you as well—especially the business with Cleopatra, which only you can attend to.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No more light answers. Let our officers$NEWLINE$Have notice what we purpose. I shall break$NEWLINE$The cause of our expedience to the Queen$NEWLINE$And get her leave to part. For not alone$NEWLINE$The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches,$NEWLINE$Do strongly speak to us, but the letters too$NEWLINE$Of many our contriving friends in Rome$NEWLINE$Petition us at home. Sextus Pompeius$NEWLINE$Hath given the dare to Caesar and commands$NEWLINE$The empire of the sea. Our slippery people,$NEWLINE$Whose love is never linked to the deserver$NEWLINE$Till his deserts are past, begin to throw$NEWLINE$Pompey the Great and all his dignities$NEWLINE$Upon his son, who—high in name and power,$NEWLINE$Higher than both in blood and life—stands up$NEWLINE$For the main soldier, whose quality, going on,$NEWLINE$The sides o’ th’ world may danger. Much is breeding$NEWLINE$Which, like the courser’s hair, hath yet but life,$NEWLINE$And not a serpent’s poison. Say our pleasure,$NEWLINE$To such whose place is under us, requires$NEWLINE$Our quick remove from hence.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Enough of this frivolous talk. Give our officers notice of our intentions. I’ll tell the Queen the reason for our quick departure and get her permission to leave. Fulvia’s death and the pressing concerns related to it are not the only reasons I am eager to go; friends in Rome have also sent many letters advising my return. Sextus Pompeius has challenged Caesar. His fleet controls the sea. Our fickle citizens—who never reward service until that service is over—are now giving all the rights and honors won by Pompey the Great to his son, Sextus. Sextus has great honor and power, and his spirit and energy are even greater, all of which makes him the most formidable soldier in the empire. The empire may be in danger if he’s not restrained before he reaches his full potential. There are many troubles brewing now that have yet to become full-fledged threats.$NEWLINE$Like horse’s hairs dropped in a bucket of water, they come alive like snakes but as yet they bear no poison. Relay our intentions to the officers who will be in charge of the move.$NEWLINE$Like horse’s hairs dropped in a bucket of water, they come alive like snakes but as yet they bear no poison.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I shall do ’t.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I will.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They both exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, ALEXAS, and IRAS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$ALEXAS$NEWLINE$IRAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, ALEXAS, and IRAS enter.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$ALEXAS$NEWLINE$IRAS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Where is he?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Where is he?

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                          I did not see him since.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$I haven’t seen him recently.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to ALEXAS ) See where he is, who’s with him, what he does.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ALEXAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I did not send you. If you find him sad,$NEWLINE$Say I am dancing. If in mirth, report$NEWLINE$That I am sudden sick. Quick, and return.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to ALEXAS ) Find out where he is, who’s with him, and what he’s doing. Don’t tell him I sent you. If he’s sad, tell him I’m dancing. If he’s happy, say that I’ve suddenly taken sick. Hurry, and come back.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ALEXAS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit ALEXAS$NEWLINE$ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS exits.$NEWLINE$ALEXAS

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Madam, methinks, if you did love him dearly,$NEWLINE$You do not hold the method to enforce$NEWLINE$The like from him.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Madam, I think if you love him so much, you aren’t using the best way to get him to reciprocate.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                       What should I do I do not?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What should I do that I’m not doing?

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$In each thing give him way. Cross him in nothing.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Always give him his way. Never contradict him.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Thou teachest like a fool the way to lose him.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$You advise me like a fool. That’s the way to lose him.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Tempt him not so too far. I wish, forbear.$NEWLINE$In time we hate that which we often fear.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Don’t push him too far. I wish you’d be patient. We come to hate that which controls us.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: But here comes Antony.
paragraphs.translated: But here comes Antony.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                               I am sick and sullen.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I am sick and sullen.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose—
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’m sorry to have to say this—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Help me away, dear Charmian! I shall fall.$NEWLINE$It cannot be thus long. The sides of nature$NEWLINE$Will not sustain it.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Help me away from here, dear Charmian! I shall faint. I won’t be able to go on this way much longer. Human nature isn’t built to withstand this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                     Now, my dearest Queen—
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now, my dearest Queen—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Pray you, stand farther from me.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Please, stand farther away from me.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I know by that same eye there’s some good news.$NEWLINE$What, says the married woman you may go?$NEWLINE$Would she had never given you leave to come!$NEWLINE$Let her not say ’tis I that keep you here.$NEWLINE$I have no power upon you. Hers you are.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I can see in your eyes there’s been some good news. What, does your wife say you can come home? I wish she’d never let you come. Don’t let her say I kept you. I have no power over you. You belong to her.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The gods best know—
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The gods know—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                             Oh never was there queen$NEWLINE$So mightily betrayed! Yet at the first$NEWLINE$I saw the treasons planted.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, never has a queen been so betrayed as I have been. I knew from the first it would be this way.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                    Cleopatra—
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Cleopatra—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Why should I think you can be mine, and true—$NEWLINE$Though you in swearing shake the thronèd gods—$NEWLINE$Who have been false to Fulvia? Riotous madness,$NEWLINE$To be entangled with those mouth-made vows$NEWLINE$Which break themselves in swearing!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$How could I have ever thought that you would be faithful and true, even though your vows of love shook the heavens themselves—you, who were unfaithful to Fulvia? It was wild insanity to believe promises made by the mouth and not the heart. Such false vows are broken as soon as they are spoken.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                      Most sweet Queen—
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Most sweet Queen—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Nay, pray you, seek no color for your going,$NEWLINE$But bid farewell and go. When you sued staying,$NEWLINE$Then was the time for words. No going then!$NEWLINE$Eternity was in our lips and eyes,$NEWLINE$Bliss in our brows’ bent, none our parts so poor$NEWLINE$But was a race of heaven. They are so still,$NEWLINE$Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world,$NEWLINE$Art turned the greatest liar.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No, please don’t try to excuse your departure. Just say good-bye and go. When you begged to stay, that was the time for words. You didn’t want to go then! You saw eternity in my lips and eyes, and happiness in the arch of my eyebrows. Then, all my parts seemed angelic to you. My features are still that beautiful—or else you, the greatest soldier in the world, have become the greatest liar by overpraising them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                     How now, lady?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What do you mean, lady?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I would I had thy inches. Thou shouldst know$NEWLINE$There were a heart in Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I wish I were as big and strong as you. Then you’d see the courage that lives in the Queen of Egypt.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                        Hear me, Queen:$NEWLINE$The strong necessity of time commands$NEWLINE$Our services awhile, but my full heart$NEWLINE$Remains in use with you. Our Italy$NEWLINE$Shines o’er with civil swords. Sextus Pompeius$NEWLINE$Makes his approaches to the port of Rome.$NEWLINE$Equality of two domestic powers$NEWLINE$Breed scrupulous faction. The hated, grown to strength,$NEWLINE$Are newly grown to love. The condemned Pompey,$NEWLINE$Rich in his father’s honor, creeps apace$NEWLINE$Into the hearts of such as have not thrived$NEWLINE$Upon the present state, whose numbers threaten;$NEWLINE$And quietness, grown sick of rest, would purge$NEWLINE$By any desperate change. My more particular,$NEWLINE$And that which most with you should safe my going,$NEWLINE$Is Fulvia’s death.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Listen to me, Queen. There is an emergency I must take care of, but my whole heart will remain here with you. My Italy is full of civil war. Sextus Pompeius is sailing toward the port of Rome. When two domestic opponents are equally matched—as we are against Pompey—factions will form on the smallest of pretexts. When a formerly hated man grows powerful, he suddenly finds himself with many supporters. Pompey, who was once condemned, now wields his father’s power, and all the citizens who have grievances against the government are joining him. Pompey’s numbers are steadily growing, and the government is ready to do something desperate. But my personal motivation—and that which should move you most to sanction my departure—is that Fulvia is dead.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Though age from folly could not give me freedom,$NEWLINE$It does from childishness. Can Fulvia die?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I may not have outlived the foolishness of my youth, but I’m not that childishly naïve. Is it possible Fulvia is dead?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$She’s dead, my Queen.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$She’s dead, my Queen.

paragraphs.original: He offers letters
paragraphs.translated: He shows her the message.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Look here, and at thy sovereign leisure read$NEWLINE$The garboils she awaked, at the last, best,$NEWLINE$See when and where she died.
paragraphs.translated: Look at this. Take your royal time and read about the quarrels she encouraged. And saving the best for last, read when and where she died.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                          O most false love!$NEWLINE$Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill$NEWLINE$With sorrowful water? Now I see, I see,$NEWLINE$In Fulvia’s death how mine received shall be.
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, unfaithful lover!
You should be filling vials with your tears. Seeing how you take Fulvia’s death, I can see how you would react to mine.$NEWLINE$You should be filling vials with your tears.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Quarrel no more, but be prepared to know$NEWLINE$The purposes I bear, which are or cease$NEWLINE$As you shall give th’ advice. By the fire$NEWLINE$That quickens Nilus’ slime, I go from hence$NEWLINE$Thy soldier, servant, making peace or war$NEWLINE$As thou affects.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Stop arguing and listen to my plans. Whether I go ahead with them or not is completely up to you. I swear by the sun that when I leave here, it will be as your faithful servant. I will make either peace or war, whichever you prefer.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Cut my lace, Charmian, come!$NEWLINE$But let it be. I am quickly ill, and well,$NEWLINE$So Antony loves.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Cut my corset laces, Charmian, so I can breathe. Hurry! No, leave it alone. I waver easily between sickness and health. Just as Antony loves.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$My precious Queen, forbear,$NEWLINE$And give true evidence to his love which stands$NEWLINE$An honorable trial.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Control yourself, my precious Queen, and concede that my love is true. It has endured many genuine trials.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$So Fulvia told me.$NEWLINE$I prithee, turn aside and weep for her.$NEWLINE$Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears$NEWLINE$Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one scene$NEWLINE$Of excellent dissembling, and let it look$NEWLINE$Like perfect honor.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s what Fulvia told me. I beg you, turn away and cry for her. Then say good-bye to me and tell me those tears were for my benefit. Good. Now perform a scene for me, using your excellent skills of playacting, and pretend that you’re being honorable and righteous.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                      You’ll heat my blood. No more.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You’ll make me angry. No more of this.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$You can do better yet, but this is meetly.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I know you can do better than that, but it’ll do for now.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now, by my sword—
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I swear by my sword—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                             And target. Still he mends.$NEWLINE$(to CHARMIAN ) But this is not the best. Look, prithee, Charmian,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$How this Herculean Roman does become$NEWLINE$The carriage of his chafe.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Swear by your shield, too! (to CHARMIAN ) He’s getting better, but still it’s not his best. See, Charmian, how well this mighty Roman portrays anger?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ll leave you, lady.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ll leave you, lady.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Courteous lord, one word.$NEWLINE$Sir, you and I must part, but that’s not it.$NEWLINE$Sir, you and I have loved, but there’s not it,$NEWLINE$That you know well. Something it is I would—$NEWLINE$Oh, my oblivion is a very Antony,$NEWLINE$And I am all forgotten.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Polite sir, let me say one thing. Sir, you and I must part company—no, that’s not it. Sir, you and I were lovers—no, that’s not it, either. You already know all that. There’s something I’d like to—oh, I’ve forgotten what I wanted to say. Just as Antony has forgotten me.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                             But that your royalty$NEWLINE$Holds idleness your subject, I should take you$NEWLINE$For idleness itself.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$If you weren’t the queen of immaturity, I’d think you were immaturity itself.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                    ’Tis sweating labor$NEWLINE$To bear such idleness so near the heart$NEWLINE$As Cleopatra this. But, sir, forgive me,$NEWLINE$Since my becomings kill me when they do not$NEWLINE$Eye well to you. Your honor calls you hence.$NEWLINE$Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly,$NEWLINE$And all the gods go with you! Upon your sword$NEWLINE$Sit laurel victory, and smooth success$NEWLINE$Be strewed before your feet.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$It’s difficult to have such immaturity so close to my heart, but bear with me. Even the traits that become me most kill me when you don’t approve of them. Your honor is the reason you are leaving. So I beg you not to listen to my foolishness. May the gods be with you. May your sword be victorious and everything you do succeed.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                       Let us go. Come.$NEWLINE$Our separation so abides and flies$NEWLINE$That thou, residing here, goes yet with me,$NEWLINE$And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.$NEWLINE$Away!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Let’s go. Come with me. Our imminent separation so occupies our thoughts that even though you stay here, you come with me, and even though I leave here, I stay with you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, reading a letter, LEPIDUS, and their train$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIUS CAESAR enters, reading a letter, with LEPIDUS and their courtiers and attendants.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS CAESAR$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You may see, Lepidus, and henceforth know,$NEWLINE$It is not Caesar’s natural vice to hate$NEWLINE$Our great competitor. From Alexandria$NEWLINE$This is the news: he fishes, drinks, and wastes$NEWLINE$The lamps of night in revel; is not more manlike$NEWLINE$Than Cleopatra, nor the queen of Ptolemy$NEWLINE$More womanly than he; hardly gave audience, or$NEWLINE$Vouchsafed to think he had partners. You shall find there$NEWLINE$A man who is th’ abstract of all faults$NEWLINE$That all men follow.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR$NEWLINE$Now you’ll see, Lepidus, that I don’t disdain our noble ally because of a personal whim. Here’s the news from Alexandra: Antony fishes, drinks, and celebrates all night. He’s become as frivolous and self-indulgent as
Ptolemy’s queen, Cleopatra. He rarely attends to his duties or acknowledges he has partners to be considered. Here’s a man who is the epitome of all the vices known to man.$NEWLINE$Ptolemy$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                        I must not think there are$NEWLINE$Evils enough to darken all his goodness.$NEWLINE$His faults in him seem as the spots of heaven,$NEWLINE$More fiery by night’s blackness, hereditary$NEWLINE$Rather than purchased, what he cannot change$NEWLINE$Than what he chooses.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$I can’t believe there could be enough vice in the world to outshine all the good in him. His faults stand out because they must be compared to all his virtues, like stars that shine brightly against the dark night sky. They’re more likely to be the result of inherited weakness than independent choice.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You are too indulgent. Let’s grant, it is not$NEWLINE$Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy,$NEWLINE$To give a kingdom for a mirth, to sit$NEWLINE$And keep the turn of tippling with a slave,$NEWLINE$To reel the streets at noon, and stand the buffet$NEWLINE$With knaves that smell of sweat. Say this becomes him—$NEWLINE$As his composure must be rare indeed$NEWLINE$Whom these things cannot blemish—yet must Antony$NEWLINE$No way excuse his foils when we do bear$NEWLINE$So great weight in his lightness. If he filled$NEWLINE$His vacancy with his voluptuousness,$NEWLINE$Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones$NEWLINE$Call on him for ’t. But to confound such time$NEWLINE$That drums him from his sport and speaks as loud$NEWLINE$As his own state and ours, ’tis to be chid$NEWLINE$As we rate boys who, being mature in knowledge,$NEWLINE$Pawn their experience to their present pleasure$NEWLINE$And so rebel to judgment.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You’re too forgiving. Let’s say, for argument’s sake, that it’s not improper to fool around with Ptolemy’s wife, or to trade a kingdom for a joke. That it’s fine to engage in drinking matches with inferiors, or stumble drunkenly through the streets in the middle of the day, or get into fist fights with sweaty servants. Even if we said that this behavior suits him—though only a man with a perfect character could avoid being disgraced by such antics—there’s no excuse for the extra work we’ve had to take on while he’s been off amusing himself. If he’s been spending his leisure time in lustful pursuits, then he’ll be punished with venereal diseases, and that’s his business. But he’s wasting time and resources vital to our cause and endangering both his position and ours. He should be chastised, like any boy who knows what’s right but chooses to satisfy his desires regardless.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The FIRST MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$FIRST MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                                   Here’s more news.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Here’s more news.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Thy biddings have been done, and every hour,$NEWLINE$Most noble Caesar, shalt thou have report$NEWLINE$How ’tis abroad. Pompey is strong at sea,$NEWLINE$And it appears he is beloved of those$NEWLINE$That only have feared Caesar. To the ports$NEWLINE$The discontents repair, and men’s reports$NEWLINE$Give him much wronged.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MESSENGER$NEWLINE$We’ve followed your commands, lord Caesar. You shall have hourly updates regarding the situation at sea. Pompey has a strong navy. All the people who only stayed with you out of fear are gathering at the port to join him, in the opinion he’s been treated unfairly.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                  I should have known no less.$NEWLINE$It hath been taught us from the primal state$NEWLINE$That he which is was wished until he were,$NEWLINE$And the ebbed man, ne’er loved till ne’er worth love,$NEWLINE$Comes deared by being lacked. This common body,$NEWLINE$Like to a vagabond flag upon the stream,$NEWLINE$Goes to and back, lackeying the varying tide$NEWLINE$To rot itself with motion.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I should have known it. It’s been this way ever since the first government was organized. People will transfer their support to a strong figure until he becomes their actual leader. Then they will value their former leader, even though the loss of their support has made him powerless. The common crowd changes like the tide, to and fro, serving whoever is on the rise. Their power is worn away by their fickleness.

paragraphs.original: Enter SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Enter$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Caesar, I bring thee word$NEWLINE$Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates,$NEWLINE$Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound$NEWLINE$With keels of every kind. Many hot inroads$NEWLINE$They make in Italy—the borders maritime$NEWLINE$Lack blood to think on ’t—and flush youth revolt.$NEWLINE$No vessel can peep forth, but ’tis as soon$NEWLINE$Taken as seen, for Pompey’s name strikes more$NEWLINE$Than could his war resisted.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Caesar, I have news about Menecrates and Menas, notorious pirates who prowl the sea in a variety of ships. They’ve made many raids upon Italy—and the naval patrols go pale at even the thought of resisting them. The young, energetic men are joining Pompey. These pirates can capture a ship as soon as it leaves the harbor, since the simple mention of the name “Pompey” carries as much power as a fleet of troops in battle.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$SECOND MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                        Antony,$NEWLINE$Leave thy lascivious wassails. When thou once$NEWLINE$Wast beaten from Modena, where thou slew’st$NEWLINE$Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel$NEWLINE$Did famine follow, whom thou fought’st against,$NEWLINE$Though daintily brought up, with patience more$NEWLINE$Than savages could suffer. Thou didst drink$NEWLINE$The stale of horses and the gilded puddle$NEWLINE$Which beasts would cough at. Thy palate then did deign$NEWLINE$The roughest berry on the rudest hedge.$NEWLINE$Yea, like the stag, when snow the pasture sheets,$NEWLINE$The barks of trees thou browsèd. On the Alps$NEWLINE$It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh,$NEWLINE$Which some did die to look on. And all this—$NEWLINE$It wounds thine honor that I speak it now—$NEWLINE$Was borne so like a soldier, that thy cheek$NEWLINE$So much as lanked not.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Antony, it’s time to stop your wild hedonism. When you were defeated at the battle of Modena—where you killed the consuls, Hirtius and Pansa—and then driven away, you had to face hunger and thirst. And even though you were brought up as a gentleman, you patiently tolerated more hardships than savages could withstand. You drank horses’ urine and water from scum-covered puddles that even animals would refuse. Though you were used to the finest foods, you didn’t turn up your nose at the bitterest berries on the thorniest bushes. You even ate bark from trees, as deer do in winter. Going over the Alps, you ate strange meat that some men would rather die than consume. And you went through all this—the comparison between then and now shames you—in such a soldier-like way that you didn’t seem to suffer at all.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$’Tis pity of him.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$It’s too bad.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Let his shames quickly$NEWLINE$Drive him to Rome. ’Tis time we twain$NEWLINE$Did show ourselves i’ th’ field, and to that end$NEWLINE$Assemble we immediate council. Pompey$NEWLINE$Thrives in our idleness.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Let’s hope his sense of shame will send him back to Rome quickly. It’s time that we brought our armies into the field. Let’s call a council of war immediately. Pompey is making the most of our absence.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                               Tomorrow, Caesar,$NEWLINE$I shall be furnished to inform you rightly$NEWLINE$Both what by sea and land I can be able$NEWLINE$To front this present time.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, Caesar, I’ll be able to tell you what land and sea forces I can raise for this war.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                    Till which encounter$NEWLINE$It is my business too. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I’ll be getting my own figures together in the meantime. Good-bye.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Farewell, my lord. What you shall know meantime$NEWLINE$Of stirs abroad, I shall beseech you, sir,$NEWLINE$To let me be partaker.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Good-bye, my lord. If you receive any more news, please share it with me.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Doubt not, sir. I knew it for my bond.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Don’t worry, that goes without saying.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN enter.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$MARDIAN

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Charmian!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Charmian!

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Madam?
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Madam?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Ha, ha! Give me to drink mandragora.
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Ah, give me some
mandragora to drink.$NEWLINE$mandragora$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Why, madam?
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Why, madam?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That I might sleep out this great gap of time$NEWLINE$My Antony is away.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$So I can sleep away the time while my Antony is gone.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$You think of him too much.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$You think about him too much.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, ’tis treason!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s treason!

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                Madam, I trust, not so.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$I hope not, Madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Thou, eunuch Mardian!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Eunuch! Mardian!

paragraphs.original: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$                                                What’s your highness’ pleasure?
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$What can I do for your highness?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Not now to hear thee sing. I take no pleasure$NEWLINE$In aught an eunuch has. ’Tis well for thee$NEWLINE$That, being unseminared, thy freer thoughts$NEWLINE$May not fly forth of Egypt. Hast thou affections?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I don’t want to hear you sing. I’m not interested in anything a eunuch can do. It’s a good thing for you that, being castrated, you can better concentrate on my needs. Do you have desires?

paragraphs.original: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, gracious madam.
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$Yes, dear madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Indeed?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Indeed?

paragraphs.original: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$Not in deed, madam, for I can do nothing$NEWLINE$But what indeed is honest to be done.$NEWLINE$Yet have I fierce affections, and think$NEWLINE$What Venus did with Mars.
paragraphs.translated:
MARDIAN$NEWLINE$Well, not in deed, madam, since I can’t do anything unchaste. But I do have intense passions—and I do think about
what Venus did with Mars.$NEWLINE$what Venus did with Mars$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                        O Charmian,$NEWLINE$Where think’st thou he is now? Stands he or sits he?$NEWLINE$Or does he walk? Or is he on his horse?$NEWLINE$O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony!$NEWLINE$Do bravely, horse, for wott’st thou whom thou mov’st?$NEWLINE$The demi-Atlas of this earth, the arm$NEWLINE$And burgonet of men. He’s speaking now,$NEWLINE$Or murmuring “Where’s my serpent of old Nile?”$NEWLINE$For so he calls me. Now I feed myself$NEWLINE$With most delicious poison. Think on me,$NEWLINE$That am with Phoebus’ amorous pinches black$NEWLINE$And wrinkled deep in time. Broad-fronted Caesar,$NEWLINE$When thou wast here above the ground, I was$NEWLINE$A morsel for a monarch. And great Pompey$NEWLINE$Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow.$NEWLINE$There would he anchor his aspect, and die$NEWLINE$With looking on his life.
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, Charmian, where do you think he is now? Is he standing or sitting? Or is he walking? Or is he on his horse? Oh, how fortunate that horse is to have Antony on him. Do well, horse. Do you know whom it is you carry? A man who carries responsibility for a third of the world on his shoulders. He’s speaking now, or perhaps he’s whispering, “Where’s my serpent of the Nile?” For that’s his pet name for me. I’m killing myself with this provocative speculation . . . Are you thinking about me? Even though I’ve been darkened by the sun and wrinkled with age? Caesar, with your broad forehead, when you were alive,
I was the perfect young consort for a king. And powerful Pompey used to stare at me as if he were frozen in time.$NEWLINE$I was the perfect young consort for a king. And powerful Pompey used to stare at me as if he were frozen in time.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ALEXAS$NEWLINE$ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS enters.$NEWLINE$ALEXAS

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Sovereign of Egypt, hail!
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Queen of Egypt, greetings!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$How much unlike art thou Mark Antony!$NEWLINE$Yet, coming from him, that great med’cine hath$NEWLINE$With his tinct gilded thee.$NEWLINE$How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$You are nothing like Mark Antony! But since you come from him, you’re saturated with his healing spirit. How does it go with my magnificent Mark Antony?

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Last thing he did, dear Queen,$NEWLINE$He kissed—the last of many doubled kisses—$NEWLINE$This orient pearl.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$The last thing he did before sending me off, dear Queen, was to kiss—the last of many such kisses—this Indian pearl for you.

paragraphs.original: He gives a pearl.
paragraphs.translated: He gives CLEOPATRA a pearl.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: His speech sticks in my heart.$NEWLINE$
paragraphs.translated: His speech is stored in my heart.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Mine ear must pluck it thence.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$My ear must pull it out.

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$                                                           “Good friend,” quoth he,$NEWLINE$“Say the firm Roman to great Egypt sends$NEWLINE$This treasure of an oyster, at whose foot,$NEWLINE$To mend the petty present, I will piece$NEWLINE$Her opulent throne with kingdoms. All the East,$NEWLINE$Say thou, shall call her mistress.” So he nodded,$NEWLINE$And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed,$NEWLINE$Who neighed so high that what I would have spoke$NEWLINE$Was beastly dumbed by him.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$“Good friend,” he said, “say that the faithful Roman sends an oyster’s treasure to the great Queen of Egypt, and that he plans to enhance this meager gift by adding new kingdoms to her empire. Tell her that the entire East shall call her Queen.” Then he nodded and solemnly mounted an armored warhorse, which neighed so loudly it effectively silenced anything I might have said in reply.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What was he, sad or merry?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Was he sad or happy?

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Like to the time o’ th’ year between the extremes$NEWLINE$Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$He was like that time of year halfway between the extremes of hot and cold: he was neither sad nor happy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$O well-divided disposition! Note him,$NEWLINE$Note him, good Charmian, ’tis the man, but note him.$NEWLINE$He was not sad, for he would shine on those$NEWLINE$That make their looks by his. He was not merry,$NEWLINE$Which seemed to tell them his remembrance lay$NEWLINE$In Egypt with his joy, but between both.$NEWLINE$O heavenly mingle! Be’st thou sad or merry,$NEWLINE$The violence of either thee becomes,$NEWLINE$So does it no man else.—Mett’st thou my posts?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, what an even disposition he has! Observe, observe good Charmian! That’s exactly how he is! Just notice. He wasn’t sad, because he knows that his disposition affects others. He wasn’t merry, because to be merry would indicate that he had forgotten his love in Egypt. He was somewhere in the middle, between them . . . Oh, heavenly mixture! Whether you are sad or merry, the intensity of either suits you like no one else . . . Did you meet my messengers on your way here?

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Ay, madam, twenty several messengers.$NEWLINE$Why do you send so thick?
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Yes, madam, twenty different messengers. Why did you send so many?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                     Who’s born that day$NEWLINE$When I forget to send to Antony$NEWLINE$Shall die a beggar. Ink and paper, Charmian.$NEWLINE$Welcome, my good Alexas. Did I, Charmian,$NEWLINE$Ever love Caesar so?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Whoever is born on a day I forget to send a message to Antony will die a beggar. Bring ink and paper, Charmian. Welcome, my good Alexas. Charmian, did I ever love Caesar as much as this?

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                         Oh, that brave Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, that splendid Caesar!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Be choked with such another emphasis!$NEWLINE$Say, “the brave Antony.”
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$May you choke on any other sentiments like that! Say, “That splendid Antony.”

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                The valiant Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$The courageous Caesar!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth$NEWLINE$If thou with Caesar paragon again$NEWLINE$My man of men.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$By Isis, I’ll give you bloody teeth if you ever compare Caesar with Antony, my best man among men.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                  By your most gracious pardon,$NEWLINE$I sing but after you.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Pardon me, but I’m just repeating what you yourself have said.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                        My salad days,$NEWLINE$When I was green in judgment, cold in blood,$NEWLINE$To say as I said then. (to everyone) But, come, away.$NEWLINE$(to everyone)$NEWLINE$(to CHARMIAN ) Get me ink and paper.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$He shall have every day a several greeting,$NEWLINE$Or I’ll unpeople Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That was when I was young and inexperienced and didn’t know what passion was. (to everyone) But come. (to CHARMIAN ) Go get me ink and paper. He shall have different messages every day if I have to depopulate Egypt to send them.$NEWLINE$(to everyone)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter POMPEY, MENECRATES, and MENAS, in warlike manner$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$MENECRATES$NEWLINE$MENAS
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY, MENECRATES, and MENAS enter, dressed for battle.$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$MENECRATES$NEWLINE$MENAS

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$If the great gods be just, they shall assist$NEWLINE$The deeds of justest men.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$If the great gods are just, they will help the most honest men.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$                                                  Know, worthy Pompey,$NEWLINE$That what they do delay, they not deny.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$You should know, noble Pompey, that although the gods may delay action, that doesn’t mean they will necessarily refuse their help.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays$NEWLINE$The thing we sue for.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$But while we pray and wait for that help, the cause we petition for may be lost.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$                                          We, ignorant of ourselves,$NEWLINE$Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers$NEWLINE$Deny us for our good, so find we profit$NEWLINE$By losing of our prayers.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Sometimes we don’t know what’s best for us and ask for things that may harm us. In that case, the wise gods deny our prayers for our own good.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                I shall do well.$NEWLINE$The people love me, and the sea is mine.$NEWLINE$My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope$NEWLINE$Says it will come to th’ full. Mark Antony$NEWLINE$In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make$NEWLINE$No wars without doors. Caesar gets money where$NEWLINE$He loses hearts. Lepidus flatters both,$NEWLINE$Of both is flattered, but he neither loves,$NEWLINE$Nor either cares for him.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I’ll do well. The people are on my side, and I’m in charge of the sea. My forces are growing, and everything I know tells me it’s all coming together. Mark Antony is at dinner in Egypt and won’t be going outside to make war. Caesar loses supporters wherever he raises money. Lepidus flatters both of them, as they flatter him, but he doesn’t love them, and they don’t love him.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$                                                Caesar and Lepidus$NEWLINE$Are in the field. A mighty strength they carry.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Caesar and Lepidus are organizing their military operation. They have a massive army.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Where have you this? ’Tis false.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Where did you hear this? It’s not true.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$                                                              From Silvius, sir.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$From Silvius, sir.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$He dreams. I know they are in Rome together$NEWLINE$Looking for Antony. But all the charms of love,$NEWLINE$Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wanned lip!$NEWLINE$Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both.$NEWLINE$Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts,$NEWLINE$Keep his brain fuming. Epicurean cooks,$NEWLINE$Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite,$NEWLINE$That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honor$NEWLINE$Even till a Lethe’d dulness—
paragraphs.translated:
