POMPEY$NEWLINE$He’s dreaming. I know they’re in Rome together, hoping for Antony to return. Lecherous Cleopatra, may all the charms of love soften those withered lips! Join your witchcraft with your beauty, and let Antony’s lust combine with both. Keep this libertine occupied with endless debauchery. Keep his brain drunk and his appetite unsatisfied, so that sleeping and eating make him drowsy and forgetful of his duties, like the
Lethe does.$NEWLINE$Lethe$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter VARRIUS$NEWLINE$VARRIUS
paragraphs.translated: VARRIUS enters.$NEWLINE$VARRIUS

paragraphs.original: How now, Varrius?
paragraphs.translated: What’s the news, Varrius?

paragraphs.original: VARRIUS$NEWLINE$This is most certain that I shall deliver:$NEWLINE$Mark Antony is every hour in Rome$NEWLINE$Expected. Since he went from Egypt ’tis$NEWLINE$A space for farther travel.
paragraphs.translated: VARRIUS$NEWLINE$This news is absolutely true: Mark Antony is expected to arrive in Rome at any hour now. In the time since he left Egypt, he could have traveled an even longer distance.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I could have given less matter$NEWLINE$A better ear.—Menas, I did not think$NEWLINE$This amorous surfeiter would have donned his helm$NEWLINE$For such a petty war. His soldiership$NEWLINE$Is twice the other twain. But let us rear$NEWLINE$The higher our opinion, that our stirring$NEWLINE$Can from the lap of Egypt’s widow pluck$NEWLINE$The ne’er lust-wearied Antony.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I would have listened to less important news with greater enthusiasm. Menas, I had no idea this amorous glutton would have put on his helmet for such an insignificant war. His military ability is double that of the other two. We must form a better opinion of ourselves if our uprising can pull the insatiable Antony’s attention away from that Egyptian widow.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$                                                              I cannot hope$NEWLINE$Caesar and Antony shall well greet together.$NEWLINE$His wife that’s dead did trespasses to Caesar.$NEWLINE$His brother warred upon him, although, I think,$NEWLINE$Not moved by Antony.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$I don’t expect Caesar and Antony will have a very friendly reunion. Antony’s dead wife raised an army against him, as did his brother, though I don’t think Antony instigated it.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                              I know not, Menas,$NEWLINE$How lesser enmities may give way to greater.$NEWLINE$Were ’t not that we stand up against them all,$NEWLINE$’Twere pregnant they should square between themselves,$NEWLINE$For they have entertainèd cause enough$NEWLINE$To draw their swords. But how the fear of us$NEWLINE$May cement their divisions and bind up$NEWLINE$The petty difference, we yet not know.$NEWLINE$Be ’t as our gods will have ’t. It only stands$NEWLINE$Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.$NEWLINE$Come, Menas.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Menas, I don’t understand how minor quarrels can be superseded by greater ones. If it weren’t for the fact that we oppose all three of them together, they’d be fighting each other. They certainly have enough provocation. But it’s possible the fear of us may mend their petty differences, though how that will work out, we cannot say. It will be as the gods see fit. In any case, our survival depends on putting together the strongest force possible. Let’s go, Menas.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ENOBARBUS and LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS and LEPIDUS enter.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Good Enobarbus, ’tis a worthy deed,$NEWLINE$And shall become you well, to entreat your captain$NEWLINE$To soft and gentle speech.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Good Enobarbus, you would be doing a very good thing if you advised your captain to speak calmly and quietly.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                   I shall entreat him$NEWLINE$To answer like himself. If Caesar move him,$NEWLINE$Let Antony look over Caesar’s head$NEWLINE$And speak as loud as Mars. By Jupiter,$NEWLINE$Were I the wearer of Antonio’s beard,$NEWLINE$I would not shave ’t today.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I will advise him to speak as he usually does. If Caesar makes him mad, let Antony stand tall and speak as loudly as Mars, the god of war. By Jupiter, if I were Antony, I wouldn’t shave my beard today. I’d leave it long and dare Caesar to insult me by pulling on it, just so I could fight him.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$’Tis not a time for private stomaching.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$This is not the time for dwelling on personal grievances.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Every time serves for the matter that is then born in ’t.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$It’s always appropriate to deal with matters as they arise.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$But small to greater matters must give way.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$But major issues must come before minor ones.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Not if the small come first.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Not if the minor ones come up first.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Your speech is passion. But pray you stir$NEWLINE$No embers up. Here comes the noble Antony.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$You speak out of passion, but I beg you not to stir things up. Here comes the noble Antony.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and VENTIDIUS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$And yonder, Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$And there comes Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, MECAENAS, and AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$OCTAVIUS CAESAR$NEWLINE$MECAENAS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA enter from another door.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to VENTIDIUS ) If we compose well here, to Parthia.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Hark, Ventidius.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to VENTIDIUS ) If we can come to an agreement here, we’ll move on to Parthia. Listen, Ventidius.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: They talk aside
paragraphs.translated: They talk privately together.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(to MECAENAS ) I do not know, Maecenas. Ask Agrippa.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MECAENAS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(to MAECENAS ) I don’t know, Maecenas. Ask Agrippa.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$(to CAESAR and ANTONY ) Noble friends,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$That which combined us was most great, and let not$NEWLINE$A leaner action rend us. What’s amiss,$NEWLINE$May it be gently heard. When we debate$NEWLINE$Our trivial difference loud, we do commit$NEWLINE$Murder in healing wounds. Then, noble partners,$NEWLINE$The rather for I earnestly beseech,$NEWLINE$Touch you the sourest points with sweetest terms,$NEWLINE$Nor curstness grow to th’ matter.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$(to CAESAR and ANTONY ) Good friends, the cause that joined us was noble. Don’t let some petty quarrel tear us apart. Let’s discuss this calmly. When we argue our differences with raised voices, we do more harm than good. So I plead with you to use reasonable words as you discuss these unreasonable deeds, and don’t lose your tempers.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                 ’Tis spoken well.$NEWLINE$Were we before our armies, and to fight,$NEWLINE$I should do thus.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You’re right. If we were in front of our armies, about to fight, I would do this.

paragraphs.original: Flourish
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet fanfare.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Welcome to Rome.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Welcome to Rome.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Thank you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Thank you.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Sit.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Have a seat.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Sit, sir.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$After you.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Nay, then.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$No, after you.

paragraphs.original: They sit
paragraphs.translated: They sit.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I learn, you take things ill which are not so,$NEWLINE$Or being, concern you not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I hear you’ve interpreted some of my actions as being improper, when they weren’t improper at all—or if they were, their impropriety didn’t concern you.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                     I must be laughed at$NEWLINE$If or for nothing or a little, I$NEWLINE$Should say myself offended, and with you$NEWLINE$Chiefly i’ th’ world; more laughed at, that I should$NEWLINE$Once name you derogately, when to sound your name$NEWLINE$It not concerned me.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I should be ridiculed if I were offended so easily—and laughed at even more for speaking of you disrespectfully, when I had no reason to speak of you at all.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$My being in Egypt, Caesar, what was ’t to you?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Caesar, what did my stay in Egypt have to do with you?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$No more than my residing here at Rome$NEWLINE$Might be to you in Egypt. Yet if you there$NEWLINE$Did practice on my state, your being in Egypt$NEWLINE$Might be my question.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$No more than my staying here in Rome might mean to you in Egypt. But if you conspired against my position while you were there, I might be interested in the reason for your stay in Egypt.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                             How intend you, “practiced”?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$How do you mean, “conspired”?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You may be pleased to catch at mine intent$NEWLINE$By what did here befall me. Your wife and brother$NEWLINE$Made wars upon me, and their contestation$NEWLINE$Was theme for you. You were the word of war.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You can judge for yourself what I mean. Your wife and brother led troops against me, claiming to be fighting in your name. They said they were acting for you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You do mistake your business. My brother never$NEWLINE$Did urge me in his act. I did inquire it,$NEWLINE$And have my learning from some true reports$NEWLINE$That drew their swords with you. Did he not rather$NEWLINE$Discredit my authority with yours,$NEWLINE$And make the wars alike against my stomach,$NEWLINE$Having alike your cause? Of this my letters$NEWLINE$Before did satisfy you. If you’ll patch a quarrel,$NEWLINE$As matter whole you have to make it with,$NEWLINE$It must not be with this.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You’re mistaken. My brother didn’t use my name to justify his rebellion. I talked to some reliable participants in that battle. On the contrary, his fight was with both of us. He rejected my authority as much as yours. Since you and I share a common cause, wouldn’t his actions against you be hostile to me as well? I’ve already sent the proof in my letters. If you want to pick a fight, you’ll have to find a more substantial excuse.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                               You praise yourself$NEWLINE$By laying defects of judgment to me, but$NEWLINE$You patched up your excuses.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You defend yourself by blaming my judgment, but you’re just making up feeble excuses.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                          Not so, not so.$NEWLINE$I know you could not lack, I am certain on ’t,$NEWLINE$Very necessity of this thought, that I,$NEWLINE$Your partner in the cause ’gainst which he fought,$NEWLINE$Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars$NEWLINE$Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife,$NEWLINE$I would you had her spirit in such another.$NEWLINE$The third o’ th’ world is yours, which with a snaffle$NEWLINE$You may pace easy, but not such a wife.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Not true, not true. You know I would never approve a war against my own cause. As for my wife, if only you had such a wife. It’s easier to rule a third of the world than a wife like that.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Would we had all such wives, that the men might go to wars with the women!
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$We should all have wives like that. Then the women could go to war with the men.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$So much uncurbable, her garboils, Caesar,$NEWLINE$Made out of her impatience—which not wanted$NEWLINE$Shrewdness of policy too—I grieving grant$NEWLINE$Did you too much disquiet. For that you must$NEWLINE$But say I could not help it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I had no control over her uprisings, Caesar, which arose from her impatience—and were shrewdly undertaken, as well. I’m sorry she caused you so much trouble. But you can’t blame me for her offenses.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                    I wrote to you$NEWLINE$When rioting in Alexandria. You$NEWLINE$Did pocket up my letters and with taunts$NEWLINE$Did gibe my missive out of audience.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I sent you a letter while you were carousing in Alexandria. You put my letters in your pocket without reading them and then mocked my messenger out of the room.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                        Sir,$NEWLINE$He fell upon me ere admitted, then.$NEWLINE$Three kings I had newly feasted, and did want$NEWLINE$Of what I was i’ th’ morning. But next day$NEWLINE$I told him of myself, which was as much$NEWLINE$As to have asked him pardon. Let this fellow$NEWLINE$Be nothing of our strife. If we contend,$NEWLINE$Out of our question wipe him.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Sir, he burst into the room without invitation, just after I had come from an important banquet with three kings. I was not myself, as a result of the wine. The next day I explained all this to him, which was as good as begging his pardon. Let’s not fight over this fellow. If we must argue, let us remove him from our arguments.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                            You have broken$NEWLINE$The article of your oath, which you shall never$NEWLINE$Have tongue to charge me with.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You’ve broken the terms of our sworn agreement. You will never be able to say the same about me.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Soft, Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Easy, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, Lepidus, let him speak.$NEWLINE$The honor is sacred which he talks on now,$NEWLINE$Supposing that I lacked it.—But, on, Caesar.$NEWLINE$The article of my oath?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, Lepidus, let him say what’s on his mind. Now he slanders my honor, which is sacred to me. Go on, Caesar. What part of the agreement did I break?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$To lend me arms and aid when I required them,$NEWLINE$The which you both denied.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You agreed to send me troops and weapons when I needed them. You refused me both.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                       Neglected, rather,$NEWLINE$And then when poisoned hours had bound me up$NEWLINE$From mine own knowledge. As nearly as I may$NEWLINE$I’ll play the penitent to you, but mine honesty$NEWLINE$Shall not make poor my greatness nor my power$NEWLINE$Work without it. Truth is that Fulvia,$NEWLINE$To have me out of Egypt, made wars here,$NEWLINE$For which myself, the ignorant motive, do$NEWLINE$So far ask pardon as befits mine honor$NEWLINE$To stoop in such a case.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I overlooked your request, but I did not deny it. Your request came at a time when the poisonous effects of reveling caused me to be unaware of my own actions. I will apologize as much as is appropriate, but my apology will not diminish my great stature—or if I am denied that honor, I will withhold my military might. The truth is that to get me out of Egypt, Fulvia provoked riots here. And though I am only indirectly the cause of all this trouble, I ask your pardon to the extent that my honor permits me to lower myself in such a situation.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                               ’Tis noble spoken.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Spoken like a gentleman.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$If it might please you to enforce no further$NEWLINE$The griefs between ye, to forget them quite$NEWLINE$Were to remember that the present need$NEWLINE$Speaks to atone you.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$If it’s okay with you, you should not press your grievances any further, but realize that the current situation should be enough to reconcile you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                          Worthily spoken, Maecenas.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Well put, Maecenas.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Or, if you borrow one another’s love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again. You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Or you can pretend to settle your differences until this matter with Pompey is finished. You can argue as much as you like when there’s nothing else to do.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Thou art a soldier only. Speak no more.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You are only a soldier. Be quiet.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$That truth should be silent I had almost forgot.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Oh, I’d forgotten that no one’s supposed to speak the truth.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You wrong this presence. Therefore speak no more.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$It’s not appropriate for a soldier to be part of a discussion among noblemen. Don’t speak any further.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Go to, then. Your considerate stone.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$As you please. I’ll pretend to be a conscious stone, and think without speaking.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I do not much dislike the matter, but$NEWLINE$The manner of his speech, for ’t cannot be$NEWLINE$We shall remain in friendship, our conditions$NEWLINE$So diff’ring in their acts. Yet if I knew$NEWLINE$What hoop should hold us stanch, from edge to edge$NEWLINE$O’ th’ world I would pursue it.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I agree with what he says, though I don’t care for the way he says it. It’s not possible for us to be friends anymore. We’re too different, in both our dispositions and actions. But if there were something that could join us together again, I would go to the ends of the world to find it.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Give me leave, Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$May I speak, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Speak, Agrippa.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What is it, Agrippa?

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Thou hast a sister by the mother’s side,$NEWLINE$Admired Octavia. Great Mark Antony$NEWLINE$Is now a widower.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$You have a beautiful half-sister, Octavia. Great Mark Antony is a widower now.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                    Say not so, Agrippa.$NEWLINE$If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof$NEWLINE$Were well deserved of rashness.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You’d better not make that suggestion, Agrippa. If Cleopatra heard you, you would be well punished for your audacity.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I am not married, Caesar. Let me hear$NEWLINE$Agrippa further speak.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$It’s true I’m not married, Caesar. Let me hear what Agrippa has to say.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$To hold you in perpetual amity,$NEWLINE$To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts$NEWLINE$With an unslipping knot, take Antony$NEWLINE$Octavia to his wife, whose beauty claims$NEWLINE$No worse a husband than the best of men,$NEWLINE$Whose virtue and whose general graces speak$NEWLINE$That which none else can utter. By this marriage,$NEWLINE$All little jealousies, which now seem great,$NEWLINE$And all great fears, which now import their dangers,$NEWLINE$Would then be nothing. Truths would be tales,$NEWLINE$Where now half-tales be truths. Her love to both$NEWLINE$Would each to other and all loves to both$NEWLINE$Draw after her. Pardon what I have spoke,$NEWLINE$For ’tis a studied, not a present thought,$NEWLINE$By duty ruminated.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$If Antony were to take Octavia as his wife, you two would be bound in eternal friendship. As brothers, your hearts would be tied together in an unbreakable knot. She is beautiful enough for the best of men. Her virtue and grace are unparalleled. With this marriage, all the petty jealousies that now seem huge, and all the great fears that are dangerous in themselves, would disappear. People would become used to speaking the truth rather than gossip. Since she would love both of you, you two would be joined in that love. Excuse my bluntness. This is not a spur-of-the-moment suggestion. I have been considering this for some time, in my duties to both of you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                        Will Caesar speak?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What do you say, Caesar?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Not till he hears how Antony is touched$NEWLINE$With what is spoke already.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I’d rather hear your reaction to this first.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What power is in Agrippa$NEWLINE$If I would say, “Agrippa, be it so,”$NEWLINE$To make this good?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$If I said to Agrippa, “I agree. Make it happen,” does Agrippa have the power to make it so?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                      The power of Caesar, and$NEWLINE$His power unto Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$He has both my power and my influence over Octavia.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                 May I never$NEWLINE$To this good purpose, that so fairly shows,$NEWLINE$Dream of impediment! Let me have thy hand$NEWLINE$Further this act of grace, and from this hour$NEWLINE$The heart of brothers govern in our loves$NEWLINE$And sway our great designs!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I wouldn’t dream of opposing such an obviously promising idea. Let’s shake on it. If you go through with this plan, from now on we’ll be brothers, and our love for one another will guide our actions.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                         There’s my hand.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Here’s my hand.

paragraphs.original: They clasp hands
paragraphs.translated: They shake hands.

paragraphs.original: A sister I bequeath you whom no brother$NEWLINE$Did ever love so dearly. Let her live$NEWLINE$To join our kingdoms and our hearts, and never$NEWLINE$Fly off our loves again!
paragraphs.translated: I give you a sister whom I love more than a brother ever loved any sister. She will be the bond that joins our kingdoms and our hearts. We’ll never fight again.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                             Happily, amen!
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$I’m happy to say “amen” to that!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I did not think to draw my sword ’gainst Pompey,$NEWLINE$For he hath laid strange courtesies and great$NEWLINE$Of late upon me. I must thank him only,$NEWLINE$Lest my remembrance suffer ill report;$NEWLINE$At heel of that, defy him.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I didn’t think I would ever fight Pompey. He’s shown me unusual deference lately, and I must repay his favors or risk a reputation for ingratitude. That done, I can turn against him.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                                 Time calls upon ’s.$NEWLINE$Of us must Pompey presently be sought,$NEWLINE$Or else he seeks out us.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$There isn’t much time. Either we go after Pompey or he’ll come after us.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where lies he?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where is he now?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$About the Mount Misena.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR$NEWLINE$Near
Mt. Misena.$NEWLINE$Mt. Misena$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What is his strength by land?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$How large is his land army?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Great and increasing.$NEWLINE$But by sea he is an absolute master.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Large and increasing. But his navy rules the sea.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$So is the fame.$NEWLINE$Would we had spoke together! Haste we for it.$NEWLINE$Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we$NEWLINE$The business we have talked of.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$That’s what I hear. I wish we’d had this conversation sooner. Let’s get down to business—and yet, before we get ready for war, let’s take care of that business we just discussed.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                              With most gladness,$NEWLINE$And do invite you to my sister’s view,$NEWLINE$Whither straight I’ll lead you.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$With pleasure. I’ll introduce you to my sister. Follow me.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Let us, Lepidus, not lack your company.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Come with us, Lepidus.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Noble Antony, not sickness should detain me.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Noble Antony, even illness couldn’t keep me away.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play a fanfare. Everyone exits except ENOBARBUS, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$(to ENOBARBUS ) Welcome from Egypt, sir.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$(to ENOBARBUS ) Welcome back from Egypt, sir.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Half the heart of Caesar, worthy Maecenas! My honorable friend, Agrippa.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$You’ve become Caesar’s right hand man, Maecenas! It’s good to see you too, Agrippa.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Good Enobarbus!
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Good Enobarbus!

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$We have cause to be glad that matters are so well digested.$NEWLINE$You stayed well by ’t in Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$We can be happy that things have been resolved so agreeably. And I see you survived your time in Egypt.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, we did sleep day out of countenance and made the night light with drinking.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, it was tough. We confused the daytime by sleeping through it, and made the night merry with our drinking.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast—and but twelve persons there! Is this true?
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$We heard that once you were served eight wild boars roasted whole for breakfast—for only twelve people! Is that true?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$This was but as a fly by an eagle. We had much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$That was nothing. There were many even more memorable feasts.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$She’s a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$She’s a remarkable lady, if the rumors are to be believed.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$When she first met Mark Antony, she pursed up his heart upon the river of Cydnus.
paragraphs.translated:
ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$From the first time Antony saw her, sailing on her barge on the
Cydnus River, he was hers.$NEWLINE$Cydnus River$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$There she appeared indeed, or my reporter devised well for her.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$She made quite an appearance there, or else my informant invented a very flattering description of her.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I will tell you.$NEWLINE$The barge she sat in, like a burnished throne,$NEWLINE$Burned on the water. The poop was beaten gold,$NEWLINE$Purple the sails, and so perfumèd that$NEWLINE$The winds were lovesick with them. The oars were silver,$NEWLINE$Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made$NEWLINE$The water which they beat to follow faster,$NEWLINE$As amorous of their strokes. For her own person,$NEWLINE$It beggared all description: she did lie$NEWLINE$In her pavilion—cloth-of-gold, of tissue—$NEWLINE$O’erpicturing that Venus where we see$NEWLINE$The fancy outwork nature. On each side her$NEWLINE$Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids,$NEWLINE$With divers-colored fans, whose wind did seem$NEWLINE$To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool,$NEWLINE$And what they undid did.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you. Her barge looked like a golden throne upon the waves, burning bright with the sun’s reflections. The rear deck was covered with hammered gold. The sails were dyed purple, and they were perfumed so heavily that they made the air seem dizzy with love. The oars were made of silver, and the oarsmen rowed in time to flute music. As the oars beat the water, the waves seemed to speed up as if excited by lust. Cleopatra’s appearance was indescribable. As she reclined under a canopy woven from gold thread, she was more beautiful than any artist’s idealized portrait of the goddess Venus. Pretty, Cupid-like boys stood on either side of her, smiling and cooling her with multicolored fans, which seemed to fan the flames in her cheeks even as they cooled them, undoing what they did.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                                   Oh, rare for Antony!
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$How excellent for Antony!

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides,$NEWLINE$So many mermaids, tended her i’ th’ eyes,$NEWLINE$And made their bends adornings. At the helm$NEWLINE$A seeming mermaid steers. The silken tackle$NEWLINE$Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands$NEWLINE$That yarely frame the office. From the barge$NEWLINE$A strange invisible perfume hits the sense$NEWLINE$Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast$NEWLINE$Her people out upon her, and Antony,$NEWLINE$Enthroned i’ th’ marketplace, did sit alone,$NEWLINE$Whistling to th’ air, which, but for vacancy,$NEWLINE$Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra too$NEWLINE$And made a gap in nature.
paragraphs.translated:
ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Her ladies-in-waiting—like
Nereides, or mermaids—tended to Cleopatra as she watched them, and their graceful movements added to the beauty of the scene. It seemed as if a mermaid were steering. The silken sails and ropes swelled in the wind, expertly handled by the ladies’ soft hands. People on the wharves could smell exotic perfume wafting from the barge as it passed them. All the people came out to see her, and Antony, waiting for her in the marketplace, was left alone. Even the air itself would have gone to look at Cleopatra, if that wouldn’t have caused an unnatural vacuum in the atmosphere.$NEWLINE$Nereides$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                                    Rare Egyptian!
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Extraordinary Egyptian!

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Upon her landing, Antony sent to her,$NEWLINE$Invited her to supper. She replied$NEWLINE$It should be better he became her guest,$NEWLINE$Which she entreated. Our courteous Antony,$NEWLINE$Whom ne’er the word of “No” woman heard speak,$NEWLINE$Being barbered ten times o’er, goes to the feast,$NEWLINE$And for his ordinary pays his heart$NEWLINE$For what his eyes eat only.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$When she landed at the port, Antony sent an invitation for her to come to supper. She replied by saying that it would be better for him to be her guest instead. Our courteous Antony, who has never said “no” to any woman, after spending plenty of time being groomed by the barber, goes to the feast. For that simple meal, he paid with his heart—even though it was only his eyes that were satisfied.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                                   Royal wench!$NEWLINE$She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed.$NEWLINE$He plowed her, and she cropped.
paragraphs.translated:
AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Royal seductress! She lured Julius Caesar into her bed, he made love to her, and she bore
his child.$NEWLINE$his child$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                                I saw her once$NEWLINE$Hop forty paces through the public street,$NEWLINE$And having lost her breath, she spoke, and panted,$NEWLINE$That she did make defect perfection,$NEWLINE$And, breathless, pour breathe forth.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I saw her once hop forty feet down the street. When she stopped she was so out of breath that she was panting. Her beauty made even that weakness seem perfect, and even in her breathlessness she seemed to pour out breath.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Now Antony must leave her utterly.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Now Antony has to leave her completely.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Never. He will not.$NEWLINE$Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale$NEWLINE$Her infinite variety. Other women cloy$NEWLINE$The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry$NEWLINE$Where most she satisfies, for vilest things$NEWLINE$Become themselves in her, that the holy priests$NEWLINE$Bless her when she is riggish.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$He’ll never leave her. Age won’t wither her, and her charms are so varied that she never grows boring. With other women, the more familiar you grow with them the less appealing they become. Cleopatra, on the other hand, makes you desire her the more you see her. Even her worst faults are charming, and holy priests bless her even when she acts the slut.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$If beauty, wisdom, modesty, can settle$NEWLINE$The heart of Antony, Octavia is$NEWLINE$A blessèd lottery to him.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$If beauty, wisdom, and modesty can settle Antony’s restless heart, Octavia will be the best thing that has ever happened to him.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                                 Let us go.$NEWLINE$Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest$NEWLINE$Whilst you abide here.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Let’s go. Good Enobarbus, consider yourself my guest as long as you’re here.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                             Humbly, sir, I thank you.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I humbly thank you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY, CAESAR; OCTAVIA between them$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and CAESAR enter with OCTAVIA between them.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to OCTAVIA ) The world and my great office will sometimes$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Divide me from your bosom.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to OCTAVIA ) There will be times when my duties and responsibilities take me away from you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$                                                         All which time$NEWLINE$Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers$NEWLINE$To them for you.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$And I will spend our time apart on my knees, praying for you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$     (to CAESAR )     Good night, sir.—My Octavia,$NEWLINE$     (to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)     $NEWLINE$Read not my blemishes in the world’s report.$NEWLINE$I have not kept my square, but that to come$NEWLINE$Shall all be done by th’ rule. Good night, dear lady.$NEWLINE$(to CAESAR ) Good night, sir.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to CAESAR ) Good night, sir. My Octavia, don’t believe everything you hear about me. I haven’t always lived a conventional life, but the future will be by the book. Good night, dear lady. (to CAESAR ) Good night, sir.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Good night.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Good night.

paragraphs.original: He exits with OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR and OCTAVIA exit.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA

paragraphs.original: Enter SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: The FORTUNETELLER enters.$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now, sirrah, you do wish yourself in Egypt?
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now,
sirrah, I hear you wish you were back in Egypt.$NEWLINE$sirrah$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Would I had never come from thence, nor you thither.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$I wish I had never left Egypt and that you had never come to Egypt.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$If you can, your reason?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Tell me why, if you can.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$I see it in my motion, have it not in my tongue. But yet hie you to Egypt again.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$It’s a feeling, but nothing I can put into words. But you had better get back to Egypt again.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Say to me whose fortunes shall rise higher,$NEWLINE$Caesar’s or mine?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Tell me who shall have the better luck, Caesar or me?

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$Caesar’s.$NEWLINE$Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side.$NEWLINE$Thy dæmon—that thy spirit which keeps thee—is$NEWLINE$Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable$NEWLINE$Where Caesar’s is not. But near him thy angel$NEWLINE$Becomes afeard, as being o’erpowered. Therefore$NEWLINE$Make space enough between you.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$Caesar. So you’d better not stay with him, Antony. Your guardian angel is noble, courageous, significant, and unmatched when Caesar’s not around. But when you are with him, your angel is weakened and easily frightened. That’s why there must be space between you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                  Speak this no more.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Don’t speak of this again.

paragraphs.original: SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$To none but thee, no more but when to thee.$NEWLINE$If thou dost play with him at any game,$NEWLINE$Thou art sure to lose, and of that natural luck$NEWLINE$He beats thee ’gainst the odds. Thy luster thickens$NEWLINE$When he shines by. I say again, thy spirit$NEWLINE$Is all afraid to govern thee near him,$NEWLINE$But, he away, ’tis noble.
paragraphs.translated: FORTUNETELLER$NEWLINE$To none but you, only to you. You will surely lose any game you play with Caesar. With his natural luck, he will beat you even against the odds. Your light dulls when he is near. I repeat: your angel is afraid to inspire you when you’re around him, but when he goes away it becomes brilliant again.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                               Get thee gone.$NEWLINE$Say to Ventidius I would speak with him.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Leave now. Tell Ventidius I want to speak with him.

paragraphs.original: Exit SOOTHSAYER$NEWLINE$SOOTHSAYER
paragraphs.translated: The FORTUNETELLER exits.$NEWLINE$FORTUNETELLER

paragraphs.original: (to himself) He shall to Parthia. Be it art or hap,$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$He hath spoken true. The very dice obey him,$NEWLINE$And in our sports my better cunning faints$NEWLINE$Under his chance. If we draw lots, he speeds.$NEWLINE$His cocks do win the battle still of mine$NEWLINE$When it is all to naught, and his quails ever$NEWLINE$Beat mine, inhooped, at odds. I will to Egypt.$NEWLINE$And though I make this marriage for my peace,$NEWLINE$I’ th’ East my pleasure lies.
paragraphs.translated: (to himself) I’ll send him to Parthia. Whether he’s truly gifted or just lucky, what the Fortuneteller said is true. Even the dice obey Caesar. When we compete in sports, my skill is defeated by his luck. If we pick numbers in a lottery, he wins. His roosters always beat mine at the cockfights. His quails beat mine, even against the odds, when mine have the advantage. I’ll return to Egypt. Though I’ve made this marriage to keep peace with Caesar, my pleasure remains in the East, with Cleopatra.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS
paragraphs.translated: VENTIDIUS enters.$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS

paragraphs.original: O come, Ventidius.$NEWLINE$You must to Parthia. Your commission’s ready.$NEWLINE$Follow me and receive ’t.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Ventidius. You must go to Parthia. Your authorization is ready. Come with me and I’ll get it for you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LEPIDUS, MECAENAS, and AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$MECAENAS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA enter.$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Trouble yourselves no further. Pray you, hasten$NEWLINE$Your generals after.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Don’t spend any more time here. Go tell your generals to hurry their preparations.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                       Sir, Mark Antony$NEWLINE$Will e’en but kiss Octavia, and we’ll follow.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Sir, we’ll follow as soon as Mark Antony kisses Octavia good-bye.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Till I shall see you in your soldiers’ dress,$NEWLINE$Which will become you both, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Good-bye then, until the time I see you dressed in your battle gear, which will suit you both very well.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$                                                                             We shall,$NEWLINE$As I conceive the journey, be at the Mount$NEWLINE$Before you, Lepidus.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$According to my reckoning, we’ll get to Mt. Misena before you, Lepidus.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                          Your way is shorter.$NEWLINE$My purposes do draw me much about.$NEWLINE$You’ll win two days upon me.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$You’re taking a shorter route. My plans take me a roundabout way. You’ll get there two days before me.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS, AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                                         Sir, good success.
paragraphs.translated: BOTH$NEWLINE$Good luck, sir.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS enter.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$ALEXAS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Give me some music. Music, moody food$NEWLINE$Of us that trade in love.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Play me some music. Music feeds the melancholy moods of us lovers.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$                                               The music, ho!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Musicians, come in!

paragraphs.original: Enter MARDIAN the eunuch$NEWLINE$MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: MADRIAN enters.$NEWLINE$MADRIAN

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Let it alone. Let’s to billiards. Come, Charmian.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Never mind. Let’s play billiards. Play with me, Charmian.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$My arm is sore. Best play with Mardian.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$My arm is sore. You’ll have a better game with Mardian.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$As well a woman with an eunuch played$NEWLINE$As with a woman.—Come, you’ll play with me, sir?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Playing with a eunuch is the same as playing with a woman. Will you play with me, sir?

paragraphs.original: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$As well as I can, madam.
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$I’ll do my best, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$And when good will is showed, though ’t come too short,$NEWLINE$The actor may plead pardon. I’ll none now.$NEWLINE$Give me mine angle. We’ll to th’ river. There,$NEWLINE$My music playing far off, I will betray$NEWLINE$Tawny-finned fishes. My bended hook shall pierce$NEWLINE$Their slimy jaws, and as I draw them up$NEWLINE$I’ll think them every one an Antony$NEWLINE$And say, “Aha! You’re caught.”
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$When a person tries in good faith, even if he fails he cannot be blamed. I don’t want to play now. Give me my fishing rod. We’ll go to the river. With my music playing in the background, I’ll lure fish. My hook will go through their slimy jaws and as I pull them up I’ll imagine each one is Antony. I’ll say, “Aha! I caught you!”

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                              ’Twas merry when$NEWLINE$You wagered on your angling, when your diver$NEWLINE$Did hang a salt fish on his hook, which he$NEWLINE$With fervency drew up.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$It was funny when you and Antony bet on who could catch the first fish. You had a diver put a salted fish on his hook. He was so excited as he hurried to pull it in!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                  That time—Oh, times!—$NEWLINE$I laughed him out of patience, and that night$NEWLINE$I laughed him into patience. And next morn,$NEWLINE$Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed,$NEWLINE$Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst$NEWLINE$I wore his sword Philippan.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That time? Oh, there were so many fun times. I would play some trick on him and laugh until he lost his patience. Then, that night, I would laugh with him while we made love until he was patient again. Then by nine in the morning I would have him so drunk I could dress him in my clothes while I wore the sword he used at the famous battle of Philippi.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: Oh, from Italy!$NEWLINE$Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears,$NEWLINE$That long time have been barren.
paragraphs.translated: Oh! News from Italy! Cram your good news into my ears. It’s been so long since I’ve heard from him.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                                Madam, madam—
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, madam—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Antonio’s dead! If thou say so, villain,$NEWLINE$Thou kill’st thy mistress. But well and free,$NEWLINE$If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here$NEWLINE$My bluest veins to kiss—a hand that kings$NEWLINE$Have lipped, and trembled kissing.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Antony’s dead! If you say that, you bastard, you’ll kill your Queen. If you say he’s healthy and free, I’ll give you money and you may kiss my hand. Kings have trembled to kiss this hand.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$First, madam, he is well.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Let me say first, madam, that he is well.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Why, there’s more gold. But, sirrah, mark, we use$NEWLINE$To say the dead are well. Bring it to that,$NEWLINE$The gold I give thee will I melt and pour$NEWLINE$Down thy ill-uttering throat.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Well then, here’s more money for you. But you know, sirrah, we customarily say that the dead are well. If that’s what you mean, I’ll melt this gold and pour it down your throat that speaks these hateful words.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Good madam, hear me.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Good madam, let me speak.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Well, go to, I will.$NEWLINE$But there’s no goodness in thy face—if Antony$NEWLINE$Be free and healthful, so tart a favor$NEWLINE$To trumpet such good tidings! If not well,$NEWLINE$Thou shouldst come like a Fury crowned with snakes,$NEWLINE$Not like a formal man.
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$All right, I will. But you don’t look as if you bring good news. If Antony is free and healthy, you shouldn’t wear such a sour face while bringing such good news.$NEWLINE$If he’s not well, you should arrive like a
Fury with snakes for hair, not in the shape of a normal man.$NEWLINE$Fury$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                             Will ’t please you hear me?
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Do you want to hear my news?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak’st.$NEWLINE$Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well,$NEWLINE$Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him,$NEWLINE$I’ll set thee in a shower of gold and hail$NEWLINE$Rich pearls upon thee.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I have half a mind to hit you before you speak again. But if Antony is alive, healthy, friendly with Caesar, and not Caesar’s prisoner, I’ll shower you with gold and pearls.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                            Madam, he’s well.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, he’s well.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                                                 Well said.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s well spoken.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$And friends with Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$And he’s friendly with Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                 Th’ art an honest man.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$You are an honest man.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Caesar and he are better friends than ever.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Make thee a fortune from me.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I’m going to make you a rich man.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                          But yet, madam—
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$But yet, madam—

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I do not like “But yet.” It does allay$NEWLINE$The good precedence. Fie upon “But yet.”$NEWLINE$“But yet” is as a jailer to bring forth$NEWLINE$Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend,$NEWLINE$Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear,$NEWLINE$The good and bad together. He’s friends with Caesar,$NEWLINE$In state of health, thou say’st, and, thou say’st, free.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I don’t like the sound of “but yet.” It reverses all the good that came before it. Damn those words, “but yet!” “But yet” is like a jailer about to bring out some horrible criminal. Please, my friend, give me all the news, both good and bad, at the same time. You say he’s friendly with Caesar, healthy, and free.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Free, madam, no. I made no such report.$NEWLINE$He’s bound unto Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I didn’t say free, madam. No, I didn’t say that. He’s bound to Octavia.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                 For what good turn?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$For what favor?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$For the best turn i’ th’ bed.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$For the favor of sleeping in her bed.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                    I am pale, Charmian.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I’m sick, Charmian.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, he’s married to Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He’s married to Octavia, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$May you die of the worst disease!

paragraphs.original: Strikes him down
paragraphs.translated: She knocks him down.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Good madam, patience.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Good madam, be patient.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What say you?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What did you say to me?

paragraphs.original: Strikes him
paragraphs.translated: She hits him again.

paragraphs.original: Hence, horrible villain, or I’ll spurn thine eyes$NEWLINE$Like balls before me! I’ll unhair thy head!
paragraphs.translated: Get out, you horrible bastard, or I’ll gouge out your eyes. I’ll scalp you.

paragraphs.original: She hales him up and down
paragraphs.translated: She drags him across the stage.

paragraphs.original: Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine,$NEWLINE$Smarting in ling’ring pickle!
paragraphs.translated: I’ll have you whipped with wire and soaked in brine like a pickle, making your pain linger.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                        Gracious madam,$NEWLINE$I that do bring the news made not the match.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Gracious madam, I only brought the news. I didn’t make the match.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Say ’tis not so, a province I will give thee$NEWLINE$And make thy fortunes proud. The blow thou hadst$NEWLINE$Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage,$NEWLINE$And I will boot thee with what gift beside$NEWLINE$Thy modesty can beg.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$If you say it isn’t true, I’ll give you a province and make you rich. The blows I gave you already will make up for your upsetting me. And on top of that I’ll give you whatever you ask for.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                            He’s married, madam.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He’s married, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Rogue, thou hast lived too long.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Rogue, you’ve lived too long!

paragraphs.original: Draws a knife
paragraphs.translated: She draws a knife.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                              Nay then, I’ll run.$NEWLINE$What mean you, madam? I have made no fault.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$No way, then, I’ll run. What’s the matter with you, madam? I haven’t done anything to you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Good madam, keep yourself within yourself.$NEWLINE$The man is innocent.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Good madam, restrain yourself. The man hasn’t done anything wrong.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Some innocents ’scape not the thunderbolt.$NEWLINE$Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures$NEWLINE$Turn all to serpents. Call the slave again.$NEWLINE$Though I am mad, I will not bite him. Call!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Even innocents cannot always escape disaster. May Egypt drown in the Nile and all good creatures turn into poisonous snakes. Call that servant back. Even though I’m mad, I won’t bite him. Call him!

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$He is afeard to come.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$He’s afraid to come in.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                          I will not hurt him.$NEWLINE$These hands do lack nobility that they strike$NEWLINE$A meaner than myself, since I myself$NEWLINE$Have given myself the cause.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I won’t hurt him. My hands are tainted if they hit an inferior, especially since I myself am the cause of my own distress.

paragraphs.original: Enter the MESSENGER again$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER returns.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: Come hither, sir.$NEWLINE$Though it be honest, it is never good$NEWLINE$To bring bad news. Give to a gracious message$NEWLINE$An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell$NEWLINE$Themselves when they be felt.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, sir. It may be honest, but it’s never wise to bring bad news. You can give good news in many ways, but let bad news interpret itself as you tell it.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I have done my duty.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I’ve only done my duty.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is he married?$NEWLINE$I cannot hate thee worser than I do$NEWLINE$If thou again say “yes.”
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is he married? I can’t hate you any more than I already do if you repeat that he is.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                             He’s married, madam.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He’s married, madam.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$The gods confound thee! Dost thou hold there still?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$May the gods destroy you! Do you maintain the same story?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Should I lie, madam?
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Do you want me to lie, madam?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                         Oh, I would thou didst,$NEWLINE$So half my Egypt were submerged and made$NEWLINE$A cistern for scaled snakes! Go, get thee hence.$NEWLINE$Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me$NEWLINE$Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, I wish you had lied, even if it meant half my kingdom would be submerged and filled with snakes. Go, get out! Even if you were as handsome as
Narcissus, your face would be ugly to me. Is he really married?$NEWLINE$Narcissus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I crave your highness’ pardon.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I beg your highness’ pardon.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                           He is married?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is he really married?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Take no offense that I would not offend you.$NEWLINE$To punish me for what you make me do$NEWLINE$Seems much unequal. He’s married to Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Please don’t be offended that I don’t want to offend you any more. It’s not fair to punish me for something you make me do. He’s married to Octavia.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, that his fault should make a knave of thee,$NEWLINE$That art not what th’ art sure of! Get thee hence.$NEWLINE$The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome$NEWLINE$Are all too dear for me. Lie they upon thy hand$NEWLINE$And be undone by ’em!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$It’s too bad that Antony’s fault should make you look like a jerk. You didn’t have anything to do with it. Go away. The merchandise you bring from Rome is too expensive for me. Let it stay in your inventory until it bankrupts you.

paragraphs.original: Exit MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                               Good your highness, patience.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Be patient, your highness.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$In praising Antony, I have dispraised Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$When I have praised Antony, I’ve disparaged Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Many times, madam.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Many times, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I am paid for ’t now. Lead me from hence.$NEWLINE$I faint. O Iras, Charmian! ’Tis no matter.—$NEWLINE$Go to the fellow, good Alexas. Bid him$NEWLINE$Report the feature of Octavia: her years,$NEWLINE$Her inclination. Let him not leave out$NEWLINE$The color of her hair. Bring me word quickly.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I’m being repaid for that now. Help me out of here. I feel faint. Oh, Iras, Charmian! It doesn’t matter. Good Alexas, go ask that fellow to describe Octavia. How old is she? What kind of disposition does she have? Don’t let him leave out the color of her hair. Bring me his answers quickly.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit ALEXAS$NEWLINE$ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS exits.$NEWLINE$ALEXAS

paragraphs.original: Let him forever go!—Let him not, Charmian.$NEWLINE$Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,$NEWLINE$The other way’s a Mars. (to MARDIAN ) Bid you Alexas$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MARDIAN$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me, Charmian,$NEWLINE$But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.
paragraphs.translated:
Let Antony be purged from my life forever—but no, don’t let him, Charmian. Even though half of him is like a
Gorgon, the other half is like Mars. (to MARDIAN ) Ask Alexas to also ask him how tall she is. Feel sorry for me, Charmian, but don’t talk to me. Help me get to my bedroom.$NEWLINE$Gorgon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MARDIAN$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter POMPEY and MENAS at one door, with drum and trumpet; at another CAESAR, LEPIDUS, ANTONY, ENOBARBUS, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA, with soldiers marching$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet fanfare sounds. POMPEY and MENAS enter through one stage door to the music of a drum and a trumpet. CAESAR, LEPIDUS, ANTONY, ENOBARBUS, MAECENAS, and AGRIPPA enter through another door, followed by soldiers.$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Your hostages I have, so have you mine,$NEWLINE$And we shall talk before we fight.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I have your hostages and you have mine. Let’s talk before we fight.$NEWLINE$I have your hostages and you have mine. Let’s talk before we fight.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                                Most meet$NEWLINE$That first we come to words, and therefore have we$NEWLINE$Our written purposes before us sent,$NEWLINE$Which, if thou hast considered, let us know$NEWLINE$If ’twill tie up thy discontented sword$NEWLINE$And carry back to Sicily much tall youth$NEWLINE$That else must perish here.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$It’s proper that we speak first, which is why we sent our proposals ahead of us for your consideration. If you’ve had time to think over these points, let us know whether they will relieve your frustration. If yes, then a lot of brave young men can return to Sicily who would otherwise die here.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                      To you all three,$NEWLINE$The senators alone of this great world,$NEWLINE$Chief factors for the gods: I do not know$NEWLINE$Wherefore my father should revengers want,$NEWLINE$Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar,$NEWLINE$Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted,$NEWLINE$There saw you laboring for him. What was ’t$NEWLINE$That moved pale Cassius to conspire? And what$NEWLINE$Made the all-honored, honest Roman Brutus,$NEWLINE$With the armed rest, courtiers of beauteous freedom,$NEWLINE$To drench the Capitol, but that they would$NEWLINE$Have one man but a man? And that is it$NEWLINE$Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden$NEWLINE$The angered ocean foams, with which I meant$NEWLINE$To scourge th’ ingratitude that despiteful Rome$NEWLINE$Cast on my noble father.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I address the three of you, the sole rulers of this world and the main arbiters of the gods’ will. I don’t know why my father’s death shouldn’t be avenged, since he has a son and friends to do it. You avenged Julius Caesar’s death at Philippi, where his ghost haunted his killer, Brutus. Why did Cassius conspire against Caesar? And why did the honorable, well-intentioned Brutus and the others, men devoted to the ideal of freedom, assassinate Caesar? They didn’t want one man to be king in Rome.$NEWLINE$And that’s why I’ve built my navy, which is so huge that the weight of the ships makes the sea foam with anger. I will punish Rome for her ingratitude toward my noble father.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                Take your time.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Take your time.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails.$NEWLINE$We’ll speak with thee at sea. At land, thou know’st$NEWLINE$How much we do o’ercount thee.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Pompey, you cannot frighten us with your navy. We’ll meet you at sea. You know that on land our army is far greater than yours.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                                 At land indeed$NEWLINE$Thou dost o’ercount me of my father’s house,$NEWLINE$But since the cuckoo builds not for himself,$NEWLINE$Remain in ’t as thou mayst.
paragraphs.translated:
POMPEY$NEWLINE$Yes, on land you do outnumber me. Even more since you annexed my father’s house and lands. But since,
like the cuckoo, you don’t build anything for yourself, live in those lands as long as you can.$NEWLINE$like the cuckoo$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                                     Be pleased to tell us—$NEWLINE$For this is from the present—how you take$NEWLINE$The offers we have sent you.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$To get back to the matter at hand, what do you think of our proposal?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                        There’s the point.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$That’s the point.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Which do not be entreated to, but weigh$NEWLINE$What it is worth embraced.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Don’t let us talk you into anything, but consider carefully the value of our offers.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                      And what may follow,$NEWLINE$To try a larger fortune.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$And consider the possible consequences of fighting against us, in the hopes of gaining a greater fortune.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                              You have made me offer$NEWLINE$Of Sicily, Sardinia. And I must$NEWLINE$Rid all the sea of pirates, then, to send$NEWLINE$Measures of wheat to Rome. This ’greed upon$NEWLINE$To part with unhacked edges and bear back$NEWLINE$Our targes undinted.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$You have offered me the lands of Sicily and Sardinia. In return, I must clear the sea of pirates and send tributes of wheat to Rome. If I agree to this, we may leave unharmed, with our shields undented.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                          That’s our offer.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR, ANTONY, AND LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$That’s our offer.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                                           Know then$NEWLINE$I came before you here a man prepared$NEWLINE$To take this offer, but Mark Antony$NEWLINE$Put me to some impatience. (to ANTONY )—Though I lose$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The praise of it by telling, you must know,$NEWLINE$When Caesar and your brother were at blows,$NEWLINE$Your mother came to Sicily and did find$NEWLINE$Her welcome friendly.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$You should know that when I came here I was prepared to accept your offer. But Mark Antony made me somewhat angry. (to ANTONY ) Though it would be nobler to for me not to speak of this good act myself, you should know that when Caesar and your brother were fighting, your mother came to Sicily for refuge. I welcomed her gladly.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$          (to POMPEY )        I have heard it, Pompey,$NEWLINE$          (to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)        $NEWLINE$And am well studied for a liberal thanks$NEWLINE$Which I do owe you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to POMPEY ) I heard what you did for her, Pompey, and want to give you the many thanks I owe you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                          Let me have your hand.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Let me shake your hand.

paragraphs.original: They clasp hands
paragraphs.translated: They shake hands.

paragraphs.original: I did not think, sir, to have met you here.
paragraphs.translated: I didn’t think I would see you here.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The beds i’ th’ East are soft, and thanks to you,$NEWLINE$That called me timelier than my purpose hither,$NEWLINE$For I have gained by ’t.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The East is very seductive. I have you to thank for my trip here; I wouldn’t have left Egypt otherwise, and I have benefited from it.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$          (to POMPEY )          Since I saw you last$NEWLINE$          (to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)          $NEWLINE$There’s a change upon you.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(to POMPEY ) You’ve changed since the last time I saw you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                       Well, I know not$NEWLINE$What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face,$NEWLINE$But in my bosom shall she never come$NEWLINE$To make my heart her vassal.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Well, I cannot tell how my difficult life has weathered my face, but I will never let those difficulties subdue my courage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                                         Well met here.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$It’s good we had this meeting.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed.$NEWLINE$I crave our composition may be written$NEWLINE$And sealed between us.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I hope it works out for the best, Lepidus. So we are in agreement. Please have the contract written up so we can all sign it.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                              That’s the next to do.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$That’s the next thing on the agenda.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$We’ll feast each other ere we part, and let’s$NEWLINE$Draw lots who shall begin.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$We’ll have celebration feasts for each other before we go our separate ways. Let’s draw lots to see who will host the first one.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                     That will I, Pompey.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ll give the first one, Pompey.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$No, Antony, take the lot. But, first or last,$NEWLINE$Your fine Egyptian cookery shall have$NEWLINE$The fame. I have heard that Julius Caesar$NEWLINE$Grew fat with feasting there.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$No, Antony. Pick one of these lots. Whether your banquet is first or last, your Egyptian cooking will make it the best. I heard that Julius Caesar got fat from all the feasting there.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You have heard much.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You’ve heard a lot.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I have fair meanings, sir.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I mean well, sir.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$And fair words to them.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’m sure you do.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Then so much have I heard.$NEWLINE$And I have heard Apollodorus carried—
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I’ve heard a lot more. I heard that Apollodorus carried—

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(interrupting POMPEY ) No more of that. He did so.$NEWLINE$(interrupting$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(interrupting POMPEY ) That’s enough of that. Yes, it’s true.$NEWLINE$(interrupting$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                                            What, I pray you?
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$What did he carry, please?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$A certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.
paragraphs.translated:
ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$A certain queen to Caesar,
rolled up in a mattress.$NEWLINE$rolled up in a mattress$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I know thee now. How far’st thou, soldier?
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Now I know who you are. How are you, soldier?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                                                  Well,$NEWLINE$And well am like to do, for I perceive,$NEWLINE$Four feasts are toward.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I’m well, and probably will be for a while, as I hear that four feasts are being prepared.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                            Let me shake thy hand.$NEWLINE$I never hated thee. I have seen thee fight$NEWLINE$When I have envied thy behavior.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Let me shake your hand. I’ve never been your enemy. I’ve seen you fight and envied your skill.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                                  Sir,$NEWLINE$I never loved you much, but I ha’ praised ye$NEWLINE$When you have well deserved ten times as much$NEWLINE$As I have said you did.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Sir, I wouldn’t say I was your friend, but I’ve praised you when you deserved ten times more praise than I gave.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                            Enjoy thy plainness.$NEWLINE$It nothing ill becomes thee.—$NEWLINE$Aboard my galley I invite you all.$NEWLINE$Will you lead, lords?
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Enjoy your frankness; it suits you. I invite you all aboard my ship. After you, my lords?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$                                         Show ’s the way, sir.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR, ANTONY, AND LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Show us the way, sir.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                                                Come.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Come with me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS and MENAS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$MENAS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except for ENOBARBUS and MENAS.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$MENAS

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside) Thy father, Pompey, would ne’er have made this$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$treaty. (to ENOBARBUS ) You and I have known, sir.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)
