paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$(to himself) Your father would never have agreed to this treaty, Pompey. (to ENOBARBUS ) You and I have met, sir.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$At sea, I think.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I think it was at sea.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$We have, sir.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$That it was, sir.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$You have done well by water.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$You’ve done well at sea.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$And you by land.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$And you’ve done well on land.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I will praise any man that will praise me, though it cannot be denied what I have done by land.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I’ll flatter anyone who flatters me—though what I’ve accomplished on land cannot be denied.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Nor what I have done by water.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Neither can my accomplishments at sea.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you have been a great thief by sea.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Yes, for your own safety, you should deny one thing: you have been a great thief at sea.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$And you by land.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$As you were on land.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$There I deny my land service. But give me your hand, Menas.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$That’s the one part of my service on land I do deny. But let’s shake hands, Menas.

paragraphs.original: They clasp hands
paragraphs.translated: They shake.

paragraphs.original: If our eyes had authority, here they might take two thieves kissing.
paragraphs.translated: If our eyes were policemen, they might capture two thieves at once while we’re embracing.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$All men’s faces are true, whatsome’er their hands are.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Men’s faces are truthful, whatever their hands do.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$But there is never a fair woman has a true face.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$But no beautiful woman has an honest face.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$No slander. They steal hearts.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$That’s no lie. They steal hearts.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$We came hither to fight with you.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$We came here to fight against you.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking. Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$For my part, I’m sorry this battle turned into a drinking match. Today Pompey laughs away his fortune.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$If he do, sure he cannot weep ’t back again.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$If that’s true, he won’t get it back by crying.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$You’ve said, sir. We looked not for Mark Antony here. Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$That’s the truth, sir. We didn’t expect Mark Antony to be here. Is he married to Cleopatra?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Caesar’s sister is called Octavia.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Caesar’s sister is named Octavia.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$True, sir. She was the wife of Caius Marcellus.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$That’s true, sir. She was previously Caius Marcellus’ wife.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$But she is now Mark Antony’s wife.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Pray ye, sir?
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Excuse me, sir?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$’Tis true.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$It’s true.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Then is Caesar and he forever knit together.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Then Caesar and he will always be united.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not prophesy so.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$If I were to make a prediction regarding this union, I wouldn’t say that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$I think the marriage was made more for political reasons than for love.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I think so too. But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity. Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I think so too. But you’ll see that the very thing that joins them will be the thing that separates them. Octavia has a pious, chaste, meek disposition.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Who would not have his wife so?
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Doesn’t everyone want a wife like that?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Not he that himself is not so, which is Mark Antony. He will to his Egyptian dish again. Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance. Antony will use his affection where it is. He married but his occasion here.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Not someone who doesn’t share that disposition, meaning Mark Antony. He’ll go back to his Egyptian dish. Then Octavia’s complaints will rouse Caesar, and as I said before, the thing that brought them together will part them. Antony will go where his passion is. He only married out of political necessity.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard? I have a health for you.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Then that’s the way it may turn out. Come on, sir, will you come aboard? I want to drink your health.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I shall take it, sir. We have used our throats in Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I’ll join you, sir. We did a lot of drinking in Egypt.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Come, let’s away.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Let’s go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Music plays. Enter two or three SERVANTS with a banquet$NEWLINE$SERVANTS
paragraphs.translated: Music plays. Two or three SERVANTS enter with a feast.$NEWLINE$SERVANTS

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Here they’ll be, man. Some o’ their plants are ill-rooted already. The least wind i’ th’ world will blow them down.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Here’s where they’ll end up, on the floor. Some of them are leaning already. It won’t take much for them to fall over.

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$Lepidus is high-colored.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$Lepidus is red in the face.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$They have made him drink alms-drink.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$They made him drink the leftover wine usually given to the poor.

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$As they pinch one another by the disposition, he cries out, “No more,” reconciles them to his entreaty and himself to th’ drink.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$Their various personalities grate on one another. Lepidus cries, “No more arguing!” and then when they agree he resigns himself to drink.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$But it raises the greater war between him and his discretion.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$Which goes on to impede his judgment.

paragraphs.original: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$Why, this it is to have a name in great men’s fellowship. I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SERVANT$NEWLINE$That’s what happens when you partner with great men but lack their power. I’d rather carry a reed that obviously can’t protect me than a sword I cannot lift.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$To be called into a huge sphere, and not to be seen to move in ’t, are the holes where eyes should be, which pitifully disaster the cheeks.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SERVANT$NEWLINE$To be so unimportant in the company of important men is like having a face without any eyes.

paragraphs.original: A sennet sounded. Enter CAESAR, ANTONY, POMPEY, LEPIDUS, AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, ENOBARBUS, and MENAS, with other captains and a BOY$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet call sounds. CAESAR, ANTONY, POMPEY, LEPIDUS, AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, ENOBARBUS, and MENAS enter, along with other captains and a BOY.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o’ th’ Nile$NEWLINE$By certain scales i’ th’ Pyramid. They know$NEWLINE$By th’ height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth$NEWLINE$Or foison follow. The higher Nilus swells$NEWLINE$The more it promises. As it ebbs, the seedsman$NEWLINE$Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain,$NEWLINE$And shortly comes to harvest.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$This is how they do it, sir: they measure the depth of the Nile, according to certain marks made on the walls of the Pyramid. They know by those measurements if there will be famine or plenty. The higher the Nile flows, the better the harvest. As the river ebbs, the farmer scatters his seeds on the remaining silt. The harvest comes shortly after that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$You’ve strange serpents there?
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Do you have unusual snakes there?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Ay, Lepidus.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Yes, Lepidus.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun. So is your crocodile.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$The Egyptian snake is born when the sun shines on the Nile mud, just like the crocodile.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$They are so.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Yes, Lepidus.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(to LEPIDUS ) Sit, and some wine. A health to Lepidus!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Let’s have a seat and some wine. A toast to Lepidus!

paragraphs.original: They sit and drink
paragraphs.translated: They sit and drink.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$I am not so well as I should be, but I’ll ne’er out.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$I don’t feel so well, but I won’t stop.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Not till you have slept. I fear me you’ll be in till then.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Not until you pass out. I’m afraid you’ll keep going until then.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies’ pyramises are very goodly things. Without contradiction I have heard that.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$No, I certainly won’t stop. I’ve heard that the pyramids build by the Ptolemies are splendid. Without doubt I’ve heard that.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside to POMPEY ) Pompey, a word.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside to POMPEY ) Pompey, could I have a word with you?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(aside to MENAS ) Say in mine ear. What is ’t?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(aside to MENAS ) Whisper it in my ear. What is it?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside to POMPEY ) Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee, captain,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And hear me speak a word.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$(whispers in POMPEY ’s ear) Please, captain, leave the feast and let me speak with you privately.$NEWLINE$(whispers in$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$’s ear)

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(aside to MENAS ) Forbear me till anon.—This wine for Lepidus!$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(aside to MENAS ) Leave me alone awhile. Where’s the wine for Lepidus?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$What manner o’ thing is your crocodile?
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$What does a crocodile look like?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$It is shaped, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it hath breadth. It is just so high as it is, and moves with its own organs. It lives by that which nourisheth it, and, the elements once out of it, it transmigrates.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY$NEWLINE$Sir, it’s shaped like itself and is as wide as it has width. It is only as high as it is and moves with its own legs. It lives on what nourishes it, and when
the four elements leave it, its soul moves into another body.$NEWLINE$the four elements$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$What color is it of?
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$What color is it?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Of it own color too.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Its own color.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$’Tis a strange serpent.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$It’s a strange snake.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$’Tis so. And the tears of it are wet.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$It is that. And its tears are wet.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(aside to ANTONY ) Will this description satisfy him?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(aside to ANTONY ) Will that description satisfy him?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(aside to CAESAR ) With the health that Pompey gives him, else he is a very epicure.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(aside to CAESAR ) That last toast Pompey gave him will take care of him, unless he’s a raging glutton.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MENAS whispers again$NEWLINE$MENAS
paragraphs.translated: MENAS whispers to POMPEY again.$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$POMPEY

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(aside to MENAS ) Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that? Away!$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Do as I bid you.—Where’s this cup I called for?
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(aside to MENAS ) Go to hell, sir. Are you still here? Go away! Do what I tell you. Where’s the wine I ordered?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside to POMPEY ) If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear me,$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Rise from thy stool.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside to POMPEY ) If any service I’ve done you deserves a favor, get up from your stool and speak with me.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$   (aside to MENAS )     I think th’ art mad.$NEWLINE$   (aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$(aside to MENAS ) I think you’re crazy!$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: He rises, and they walk aside
paragraphs.translated: He gets up and walks aside with MENAS.$NEWLINE$MENAS

paragraphs.original: The matter?
paragraphs.translated: What is it?

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$I’ve always had great respect for your destiny.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Thou hast served me with much faith. What’s else to say?—$NEWLINE$(to the others) Be jolly, lords.$NEWLINE$(to the others)
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$You’ve served me faithfully. What else can I say? (to the others) Be happy, lords!$NEWLINE$(to the others)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                       These quicksands, Lepidus,$NEWLINE$Keep off them, for you sink.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Stay away from the quicksand of drink, Lepidus: you’re sinking.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside to POMPEY ) Wilt thou be lord of all the world?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$(to POMPEY ) Would you like to be king of the entire world?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$POMPEY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                                             What sayst thou?
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$What are you saying?

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That’s twice.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Would you like to be king of the entire world? Now I’ve said it twice.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$How should that be?
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$How could that happen?

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$But entertain it,$NEWLINE$And, though thou think me poor, I am the man$NEWLINE$Will give thee all the world.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Just consider it. Though I seem poor, I am the man who will give you the world.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                      Hast thou drunk well?
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Are you drunk?

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.$NEWLINE$Thou art, if thou dar’st be, the earthly Jove.$NEWLINE$Whate’er the ocean pales or sky inclips$NEWLINE$Is thine, if thou wilt ha ’t.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$No, Pompey, I haven’t had anything to drink. You can be the most powerful man on earth if you dare use your power. Both land and sea are yours if you will take them.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                                  Show me which way.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Tell me how.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$These three world-sharers, these competitors,$NEWLINE$Are in thy vessel. Let me cut the cable,$NEWLINE$And, when we are put off, fall to their throats.$NEWLINE$All there is thine.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$The three who share the known world are aboard your boat. Let me cut the anchor cable. When we are away from land, cut their throats. Everything that belongs to them is yours.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                   Ah, this thou shouldst have done$NEWLINE$And not have spoke on ’t! In me ’tis villainy,$NEWLINE$In thee ’t had been good service. Thou must know,$NEWLINE$’Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor;$NEWLINE$Mine honor, it. Repent that e’er thy tongue$NEWLINE$Hath so betrayed thine act. Being done unknown,$NEWLINE$I should have found it afterwards well done,$NEWLINE$But must condemn it now. Desist, and drink.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Oh, you should have done it without telling me! For me to do such a thing would be dishonorable. For you to do it would be good service. You should know that to me, profit isn’t more important than honor, but the other way around. Regret that your mouth betrayed your actions. If you had acted without my knowledge, I would have approved your action later. But now I must condemn it. Give it up and go drink.

paragraphs.original: He returns to the feast
paragraphs.translated: He returns to the feast.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$(aside) For this,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$I’ll never follow thy palled fortunes more.$NEWLINE$Who seeks and will not take when once ’tis offered$NEWLINE$Shall never find it more.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$(to himself) For this, I’ll never be faithful to your declining fortunes again. A person who wants something but won’t take it when it materializes won’t get the opportunity again.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$                                               This health to Lepidus!
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$This toast is for Lepidus!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to a servant) Bear him ashore.—I’ll pledge it for him, Pompey.$NEWLINE$(to a servant)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to a servant) Help Lepidus ashore . . . I’ll accept it for him, Pompey.$NEWLINE$(to a servant)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Here’s to thee, Menas!
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Here’s to you, Menas.

paragraphs.original: They drink
paragraphs.translated: They drink.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$                                               Enobarbus, welcome.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$I accept with thanks, Enobarbus.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Fill till the cup be hid.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Fill the cups until they run over.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$There’s a strong fellow, Menas.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$There goes a strong fellow, Menas.

paragraphs.original: Pointing to the servant who carries off LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS
paragraphs.translated: He points to the servant carrying LEPIDUS away.$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$                                                              Why?
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Why do you say that?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                                           He bears$NEWLINE$The third part of the world, man. Seest not?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$He carries a third of the world. Can’t you see that?

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$The third part, then, is drunk. Would it were all,$NEWLINE$That it might go on wheels!
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Then a third of the world is drunk. I wish it were all drunk. Then everything would go more smoothly.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Drink thou. Increase the reels.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Drink up. Liven up the party.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Come.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$All right, then.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$This hasn’t reached the level of an Egyptian feast yet.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho!$NEWLINE$Here’s to Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$It’s getting there. Clink your cups together in a toast! Here’s to Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                  I could well forbear ’t.$NEWLINE$It’s monstrous labor when I wash my brain$NEWLINE$And it grows fouler.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I could do without another toast. It’s unnatural. I keep washing my brain with alcohol, and it keeps getting fouler and more muddled.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                        Be a child o’ th’ time.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Live in the moment.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Possess it, I’ll make answer.$NEWLINE$But I had rather fast from all four days$NEWLINE$Than drink so much in one.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I’d prefer to seize the day. But I would rather abstain from everything for four days than drink so much in one.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$              (to ANTONY )            Ha! My brave emperor,$NEWLINE$              (to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)            $NEWLINE$Shall we dance now the Egyptian bacchanals$NEWLINE$And celebrate our drink?
paragraphs.translated:
ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(to ANTONY ) Ha! Shall we dance Egyptian
bacchanals, my noble emperor, and celebrate our wine?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$bacchanals$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Let’s ha ’t, good soldier.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Let’s have one, good soldier.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Come, let’s all take hands$NEWLINE$Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense$NEWLINE$In soft and delicate Lethe.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Come, let’s join our hands until the overpowering wine makes us soft and forgetful.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                   All take hands.$NEWLINE$Make battery to our ears with the loud music,$NEWLINE$The while I’ll place you; then the boy shall sing.$NEWLINE$The holding every man shall beat as loud$NEWLINE$As his strong sides can volley.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Everyone join hands. Attack our ears with loud music, and I’ll position you for the dance. Then the boy will sing, and every man will sing the chorus at the top of his voice.

paragraphs.original: Music plays. ENOBARBUS places them hand in hand$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Music plays. ENOBARBUS places each man in position, hand in hand.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: The Song.
paragraphs.translated: The Song.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$(Sings)     Come, thou monarch of the vine,$NEWLINE$(Sings)    $NEWLINE$Come, thou monarch of the vine,$NEWLINE$               Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!$NEWLINE$               Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne!$NEWLINE$               In thy vats our cares be drowned,$NEWLINE$               In thy vats our cares be drowned,$NEWLINE$               With thy grapes our hairs be crowned.$NEWLINE$               With thy grapes our hairs be crowned.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$(singing) Come, you king of the vine, plump Bacchus, with your pink eyes. Our troubles are drowned in your vats. We’ll crown ourselves with wreathes of grapes.$NEWLINE$(singing)

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$(Singing) Cup us till the world go round,$NEWLINE$(Singing) Cup us till the world go round,$NEWLINE$                Cup us till the world go round!$NEWLINE$                Cup us till the world go round!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$(singing) Give us cups until the world spins! Give us cups until the world spins!$NEWLINE$(singing)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What would you more?—Pompey, good night. (to ANTONY ) Good brother,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Let me request you off. Our graver business$NEWLINE$Frowns at this levity.—Gentle lords, let’s part.$NEWLINE$You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarb$NEWLINE$Is weaker than the wine; and mine own tongue$NEWLINE$Splits what it speaks. The wild disguise hath almost$NEWLINE$Anticked us all. What needs more words? Good night.$NEWLINE$Good Antony, your hand.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$How can you top that? Good night, Pompey. (to ANTONY ) Dear brother-in-law, let’s leave together. This frivolity isn’t appropriate to the serious purpose that brought us here. Noble lords, let’s say good night. We’ve all gotten red in the face. Even the strong Enobarbus isn’t immune to the effects of wine, and I’m tongue-tied myself. This wild party has almost turned us all into clowns. What more need I say? Good night. Good Antony, shake my hand.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$I’ll try you on the shore.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$We’ll have a rematch at your feast on shore.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$And shall, sir. Give ’s your hand.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Yes, we will. Let’s shake on it.

paragraphs.original: POMPEY$NEWLINE$O Antony, You have my father’s house.$NEWLINE$But what? We are friends. Come, down into the boat.
paragraphs.translated: POMPEY$NEWLINE$Oh, Antony, even if you’ve taken my father’s house, what is that to me? We’re friends! Come, this way to the rowboat.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Take heed you fall not.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Be careful not to fall in.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but MENAS and ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except MENAS and ENOBARBUS.$NEWLINE$MENAS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: Menas, I’ll not on shore.
paragraphs.translated: Menas, I’m not going back on shore.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$No, to my cabin. These drums, these trumpets, flutes! What!$NEWLINE$Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell$NEWLINE$To these great fellows. Sound and be hanged, sound out!
paragraphs.translated:
MENAS$NEWLINE$No, come to my cabin. We’ll have the musicians play drums, trumpets, flutes. What do you say? We’ll make
Neptune hear us bid a loud good night to these great men. Play and be damned. Play loud!$NEWLINE$Neptune$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Sound a flourish, with drums
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets and drums play a fanfare.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Hoo! says ’a. There’s my cap.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Hooray, I say. There’s my hat!

paragraphs.original: He flings it in the air
paragraphs.translated: He throws his hat in the air.

paragraphs.original: MENAS$NEWLINE$Hoo! Noble captain, come.
paragraphs.translated: MENAS$NEWLINE$Hooray! Come on, noble captain.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter VENTIDIUS as it were in triumph, the dead body of Pacorus borne before him, with SILIUS, and other Romans, officers, and soldiers$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$SILIUS
paragraphs.translated: The dead body of Pacorus is carried in, followed by the triumphant entrance of VENTIDIUS, with SILIUS and soldiers.$NEWLINE$VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$SILIUS

paragraphs.original: VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now$NEWLINE$Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus’ death$NEWLINE$Make me revenger. Bear the King’s son’s body$NEWLINE$Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes,$NEWLINE$Pays this for Marcus Crassus.
paragraphs.translated:
VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$Now I’ve paid you back, Parthia, and gotten revenge for Marcus Crassus’ death. Carry
King Orodes’ son at the front of our army, so all the Parthians will know—Orodes, Pacorus pays for Marcus Crassus!$NEWLINE$King Orodes$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SILIUS$NEWLINE$                                                           Noble Ventidius,$NEWLINE$Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm,$NEWLINE$The fugitive Parthians follow. Spur through Media,$NEWLINE$Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither$NEWLINE$The routed fly. So thy grand captain, Antony,$NEWLINE$Shall set thee on triumphant chariots and$NEWLINE$Put garlands on thy head.
paragraphs.translated:
SILIUS$NEWLINE$Noble Ventidius, while your sword is still warm with the blood of slain Parthians, why not finish the job? The Parthians retreat. Go after them. Chase them down if you have to track them through
Media, Mesopotamia, or any other places they may go to hide. Then our great general, Antony, will commend you.$NEWLINE$Media, Mesopotamia$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$                                                  O Silius, Silius,$NEWLINE$I have done enough. A lower place, note well,$NEWLINE$May make too great an act. For learn this, Silius:$NEWLINE$Better to leave undone than by our deed$NEWLINE$Acquire too high a fame when him we serve’s away.$NEWLINE$Caesar and Antony have ever won$NEWLINE$More in their officer than person. Sossius,$NEWLINE$One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant,$NEWLINE$For quick accumulation of renown,$NEWLINE$Which he achieved by th’ minute, lost his favor.$NEWLINE$Who does i’ th’ wars more than his captain can$NEWLINE$Becomes his captain’s captain; and ambition,$NEWLINE$The soldier’s virtue, rather makes choice of loss$NEWLINE$Than gain which darkens him.$NEWLINE$I could do more to do Antonius good,$NEWLINE$But ’twould offend him, and in his offense$NEWLINE$Should my performance perish.
paragraphs.translated: VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Silius, Silius, I’ve done enough. A subordinate may exceed his authority. You must understand, Silius, that it’s better to leave something undone than achieve too much fame in your superior’s absence. Caesar and Antony have always achieved more by delegating authority to their officers than by leading their troops in person. Sossius, an officer that held the same position in Syria as I do here, achieved great distinction very quickly but lost Antony’s support as a result. A man who achieves more in war than his captain does becomes his captain’s rival. Ambition is a good quality in a soldier, but it proves detrimental rather than beneficial when used to surpass his superiors. I could do more to help Antony, but to do so would insult him. And by insulting him, I would lose credit for the good I have done him already.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SILIUS$NEWLINE$Thou hast, Ventidius, that$NEWLINE$Without the which a soldier and his sword$NEWLINE$Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony?
paragraphs.translated: SILIUS$NEWLINE$A soldier is just a tool, like his sword, unless he has your qualities, Ventidius. Are you going to write Antony about this?

paragraphs.original: VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll humbly signify what in his name,$NEWLINE$That magical word of war, we have effected:$NEWLINE$How with his banners and his well-paid ranks$NEWLINE$The ne’er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia$NEWLINE$We have jaded out o’ th’ field.
paragraphs.translated: VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll modestly tell him what I have done in his name—that’s the magical wording these days. I’ll write how, under his flag and with his well-paid troops, we have beaten the formerly unvanquished Parthia.

paragraphs.original: SILIUS$NEWLINE$                                                            Where is he now?
paragraphs.translated: SILIUS$NEWLINE$Where’s Antony now?

paragraphs.original: VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$He purposeth to Athens, whither, with what haste$NEWLINE$The weight we must convey with’s will permit,$NEWLINE$We shall appear before him. (to the soliders) On, there. Pass along!$NEWLINE$(to the soliders)
paragraphs.translated: VENTIDIUS$NEWLINE$He plans to go to Athens. We must arrive there before him, as quickly as our baggage train will allow us. (to the soldiers) Get a move on!$NEWLINE$(to the soldiers)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter AGRIPPA at one door, ENOBARBUS at another$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA enters through one door and ENOBARBUS enters through another.$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$What, are the brothers parted?
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Did the brothers-in-law leave?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone.$NEWLINE$The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps$NEWLINE$To part from Rome. Caesar is sad, and Lepidus,$NEWLINE$Since Pompey’s feast, as Menas says, is troubled$NEWLINE$With the greensickness.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$They finished their business with Pompey, and Pompey has left. Now the three triumvirs are putting their official seals on the treaty. Octavia weeps at the thought of leaving Rome. Caesar is in a sober mood. And Menas reports that Lepidus has been hungover since Pompey’s party.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                               ’Tis a noble Lepidus.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$That Lepidus is an elegant man.$NEWLINE$That Lepidus is an elegant man.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$A very fine one. Oh, how he loves Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$He’s a stylish man. And how he loves Caesar!

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Yes, but how he adores Mark Antony!

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Caesar? Why, he’s the Jupiter of men.
paragraphs.translated:
ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Caesar?
He’s a god of a man.$NEWLINE$He’s a god of a man.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$What’s Antony? The god of Jupiter.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Then what’s Antony? A god of a god?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Spake you of Caesar? How, the nonpareil!
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Are you talking about Caesar? He’s without equal!

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$O Antony, O thou Arabian bird!
paragraphs.translated:
AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Oh, Antony! Oh, you
phoenix!$NEWLINE$phoenix$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Would you praise Caesar, say “Caesar.” Go no further.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$If you want to praise Caesar, just say his name—that’s all the praise that’s necessary.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$He certainly flattered them both with extravagant compliments.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony.$NEWLINE$Hoo! Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot$NEWLINE$Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number—hoo!—$NEWLINE$His love to Antony. But as for Caesar,$NEWLINE$Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$He loves Caesar best, but he also loves Antony. Oh! No one can describe or fathom Lepidus’ love for Antony! Hearts cannot think it, tongues cannot speak it, meas-urements cannot calculate it, scribes cannot write it, bards cannot sing it, and poets cannot make verses about it. But when it comes to Caesar, Lepidus’ love approaches the awestruck wonder of a worshipper.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                                                          Both he loves.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$He loves them both.

paragraphs.original:
ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$They are his shards, and he
their beetle.$NEWLINE$their beetle$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$They are his dung, and he their beetle.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Trumpets within
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original: So,$NEWLINE$This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.
paragraphs.translated: So, there’s the signal to ride. Good-bye, noble Agrippa.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Good luck, worthy soldier, and good-bye.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA enter.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No further, sir.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You can’t go any further with us, sir.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You take from me a great part of myself;$NEWLINE$Use me well in ’t.—Sister, prove such a wife$NEWLINE$As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest bond$NEWLINE$Shall pass on thy approof.—Most noble Antony,$NEWLINE$Let not the piece of virtue, which is set$NEWLINE$Betwixt us as the cement of our love,$NEWLINE$To keep it builded, be the ram to batter$NEWLINE$The fortress of it. For better might we$NEWLINE$Have loved without this mean, if on both parts$NEWLINE$This be not cherished.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You take an important part of myself with you. Treat it well . . . . Sister, be the kind of wife I hope you will be, and that this great contract rests upon your being . . . Gracious Antony, don’t let my sister, this epitome of virtue that connects us, become the reason we separate.$NEWLINE$If you and I don’t value her equally, it would be better for us to work out our differences without her.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                            Make me not offended$NEWLINE$In your distrust.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Don’t insult me with your distrust.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                 I have said.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I mean what I say.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                         You shall not find,$NEWLINE$Though you be therein curious, the least cause$NEWLINE$For what you seem to fear. So the gods keep you$NEWLINE$And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.$NEWLINE$We will here part.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You won’t find any cause for anxiety, even if you look for one. So, may the gods protect you and change the hearts of the Romans so that they turn and give you their support. We’ll leave you here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well.$NEWLINE$The elements be kind to thee and make$NEWLINE$Thy spirits all of comfort! Fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Good-bye, my dearest sister, good-bye. I hope you have good weather to set your mind at ease. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$My noble brother!
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$My noble brother!

paragraphs.original: She weeps$NEWLINE$She weeps
paragraphs.translated: She begins to cry.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The April’s in her eyes; it is love’s spring,$NEWLINE$And these the showers to bring it on. (to OCTAVIA ) Be cheerful.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Her eyes are like April: full of showers. But they’ll flower into love. (to OCTAVIA ) Be cheerful.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$(to CAESAR ) Sir, look well to my husband’s house, and—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$(to CAESAR ) Take care of my former husband’s property, and—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What, Octavia?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What is it, Octavia?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$                               I’ll tell you in your ear.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you privately.

paragraphs.original: She and CAESAR walk aside$NEWLINE$She and$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$walk aside
paragraphs.translated: She and CAESAR move apart from the group, and she whispers to him.$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can$NEWLINE$Her heart inform her tongue—the swan’s-down feather$NEWLINE$That stands upon the swell at the full of tide$NEWLINE$And neither way inclines.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$She won’t say what she’s feeling, and she can’t understand her feelings. She’s balanced uneasily, like a feather on the swell of a great wave—she won’t move, even though her situation is about to change.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to AGRIPPA ) Will Caesar weep?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to AGRIPPA ) Do you think Caesar will cry?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$(aside to ENOBARBUS ) He has a cloud in ’s face.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$(aside to ENOBARBUS ) He does look like it.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to AGRIPPA ) He were the worse for that, were he a horse;$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$So is he, being a man.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to AGRIPPA ) If he were a horse, watery eyes would lower his value. Men aren’t supposed to cry, either.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$  (aside to ENOBARBUS )  Why, Enobarbus,$NEWLINE$  (aside to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$When Antony found Julius Caesar dead,$NEWLINE$He cried almost to roaring, and he wept$NEWLINE$When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$(aside to ENOBARBUS ) Why, Enobarbus, when Antony saw that Julius Caesar was dead, he cried terribly. And he wept when he found that Brutus had been killed at Philippi.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to AGRIPPA ) That year indeed he was troubled with a rheum.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$What willingly he did confound he wailed,$NEWLINE$Believe ’t, till I wept too.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to AGRIPPA ) He certainly did have rheumy eyes that year. Whenever he had to kill, he cried—it’s true!—until I cried too.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$            (coming forward with OCTAVIA ) No, sweet Octavia,$NEWLINE$            (coming forward with$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You shall hear from me still. The time shall not$NEWLINE$Outgo my thinking on you.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$(returning with OCTAVIA ) Don’t worry, sweet Octavia, I’ll always write to you, and I’ll think about you all the time.$NEWLINE$(returning with$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                      Come, sir, come,$NEWLINE$I’ll wrestle with you in my strength of love.$NEWLINE$Look, here I have you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Come here, sir. I’ll wrestle with you out of love. See, now I have you.

paragraphs.original: Embraces him
paragraphs.translated: They embrace.

paragraphs.original: Thus I let you go$NEWLINE$And give you to the gods.
paragraphs.translated: And thus I let you go and give you to the gods.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                  Adieu. Be happy.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Good-bye. Be happy.

paragraphs.original: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$(to ANTONY ) Let all the number of the stars give light$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$To thy fair way.
paragraphs.translated: LEPIDUS$NEWLINE$(to ANTONY ) May every star light your path.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                Farewell, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Farewell, farewell.

paragraphs.original: Kisses OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: He kisses OCTAVIA.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                     Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Trumpets sound. Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound a fanfare as they exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$ALEXAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS enter.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$ALEXAS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Where is the fellow?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Where is that messenger?

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$                                        Half afeard to come.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$He’s afraid to come in.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Go to, go to.—Come hither, sir.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, come on.—Come here, sir.

paragraphs.original: Enter the MESSENGER as before$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$                                                                Good majesty,$NEWLINE$Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you$NEWLINE$But when you are well pleased.
paragraphs.translated: ALEXAS$NEWLINE$Gracious Queen, even Herod of Judea wouldn’t dare look at you unless you were in a good mood.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                             That Herod’s head$NEWLINE$I’ll have! But how? When Antony is gone,$NEWLINE$Through whom I might command it? (to MESSENGER ) Come thou near.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MESSENGER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I’ll have Herod’s head chopped off! But now that Antony’s gone, who will do it for me? (to MESSENGER ) Come closer.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MESSENGER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Most gracious majesty!
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Most formidable Queen!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                              Didst thou behold Octavia?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Did you see Octavia?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Ay, dread Queen.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Yes, revered Queen.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                   Where?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Where?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                   Madam, in Rome.$NEWLINE$I looked her in the face, and saw her led$NEWLINE$Between her brother and Mark Antony.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$In Rome, Madam. I saw her face as she walked with her brother and Mark Antony.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is she as tall as me?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is she as tall as I am?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                       She is not, madam.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$She is not, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Didst hear her speak? Is she shrill-tongued or low?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Did you hear her speak? Is her voice pitched high or low?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, I heard her speak. She is low-voiced.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, I heard her speak. She has a low-pitched voice.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s not so good. He cannot like her long.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s not in her favor. He can’t like her very long.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Like her? O Isis, ’tis impossible.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Like her? Oh, Isis, that’s impossible.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I think so, Charmian. Dull of tongue, and dwarfish.—$NEWLINE$What majesty is in her gait? Remember,$NEWLINE$If e’er thou looked’st on majesty.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$You’re right, Charmian. She’s both dull-spoken and dwarfishly little.—Did she carry herself with majesty? Compare her to any memory you might have of royalty.

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                              She creeps.$NEWLINE$Her motion and her station are as one.$NEWLINE$She shows a body rather than a life,$NEWLINE$A statue than a breather.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$She creeps along. Moving or standing still, her bearing is about the same. She has a body, not a life. She’s more like a statue than a living, breathing human being.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                Is this certain?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is this true?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Or I have no observance.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$If not, then I have no powers of observation.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                 Three in Egypt$NEWLINE$Cannot make better note.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$There aren’t three people in all of Egypt who could do better.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                  He’s very knowing,$NEWLINE$I do perceive ’t. There’s nothing in her yet.$NEWLINE$The fellow has good judgment.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$He’s very observant. I can tell. She doesn’t have anything going for her so far. This messenger is wise.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                             Excellent.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Very wise.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to MESSENGER ) Guess at her years, I prithee.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MESSENGER$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to MESSENGER ) How old do you think she is?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MESSENGER$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, she was a widow—
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$She was a widow previously, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Widow? Charmian, hark.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$A widow? Do you hear that, Charmian?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$And I do think she’s thirty.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$And I think she’s at least thirty.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Bear’st thou her face in mind? Is ’t long or round?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Do you remember her face? Was it long or round?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Round, even to faultiness.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Round enough to be unattractive.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.$NEWLINE$Her hair, what color?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Usually that means a person is foolish. What color is her hair?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Brown, madam, and her forehead$NEWLINE$As low as she would wish it.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Brown, madam, and she wouldn’t want her forehead to be any lower.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$            (giving money)             There’s gold for thee.$NEWLINE$            (giving money)$NEWLINE$Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.$NEWLINE$I will employ thee back again; I find thee$NEWLINE$Most fit for business. Go make thee ready;$NEWLINE$Our letters are prepared.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Here’s gold for you. You mustn’t hold my earlier outburst against me. I’ll hire you again to go back to Rome. I find that you’re very good at this kind of work. Go, prepare to travel. My letters are ready to go.

paragraphs.original: Exit MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: The MESSENGER exits.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                 A proper man.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$He’s an admirable man.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Indeed, he is so. I repent me much$NEWLINE$That so I harried him. Why, methinks, by him,$NEWLINE$This creature’s no such thing.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$He certainly is. I’m very sorry I was so hard on him. Why, from what he says, Octavia isn’t worth getting upset over.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                          Nothing, madam.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Not a bit, madam.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$The man hath seen some majesty and should know.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$This man’s been around royalty. He should recognize it when he sees it.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend,$NEWLINE$And serving you so long!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Been around royalty! Isis forbid it were otherwise, since he’s been in your service so long.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I have one thing more to ask him yet, good Charmian—$NEWLINE$But ’tis no matter; thou shalt bring him to me$NEWLINE$Where I will write. All may be well enough.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I want to ask him one more thing, Charmian. But it’s not important. Bring him to my writing room. Everything may still be all right.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$I warrant you, madam.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$I assure you it is, madam.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and OCTAVIA enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Nay, nay, Octavia, not only that—$NEWLINE$That were excusable, that and thousands more$NEWLINE$Of semblable import—but he hath waged$NEWLINE$New wars ’gainst Pompey; made his will, and read it$NEWLINE$To public ear;$NEWLINE$Spoke scantly of me; when perforce he could not$NEWLINE$But pay me terms of honor, cold and sickly$NEWLINE$He vented them, most narrow measure lent me.$NEWLINE$When the best hint was given him, he not took ’t,$NEWLINE$Or did it from his teeth.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, no, Octavia, it’s not only that. That would be excusable—that and a thousand other offenses like it. But Caesar has gone and waged a new war against Pompey.
He made his will and read it in a public assembly. He hardly refers to me at all, though official decisions are supposed to be made jointly. When he can’t avoid mentioning my services to the state, he minimizes them as much as possible. When situations arise when it would be natural to emphasize my due credit, he either ignores them or only pays me lip service. $NEWLINE$He made his will and read it in a public assembly.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$                                               O my good lord,$NEWLINE$Believe not all, or, if you must believe,$NEWLINE$Stomach not all. A more unhappy lady,$NEWLINE$If this division chance, ne’er stood between,$NEWLINE$Praying for both parts.$NEWLINE$The good gods will mock me presently,$NEWLINE$When I shall pray “O bless my lord and husband!”$NEWLINE$Undo that prayer by crying out as loud$NEWLINE$“O bless my brother!” Husband win, win brother$NEWLINE$Prays and destroys the prayer; no midway$NEWLINE$’Twixt these extremes at all.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, dear husband, don’t believe everything you hear—or if you must believe it, don’t let it all make you angry. No lady could be more miserable than I if you two disagree. I’ll be left in the middle, praying for both sides. The good gods will laugh at me when on the one hand I pray for my husband and on the other for my brother. “Let my husband win!” “Let my brother win!” One prayer cancels out the other. There’s no middle ground between these two extremes.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                       Gentle Octavia,$NEWLINE$Let your best love draw to that point which seeks$NEWLINE$Best to preserve it. If I lose mine honor,$NEWLINE$I lose myself; better I were not yours$NEWLINE$Than yours so branchless. But, as you requested,$NEWLINE$Yourself shall go between ’s. The meantime, lady,$NEWLINE$I’ll raise the preparation of a war$NEWLINE$Shall stain your brother. Make your soonest haste;$NEWLINE$So your desires are yours.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Gentle Octavia, support the one that supports you. If I’m defeated, I lose my reputation. If I lose my reputation, I lose myself. It would be better for you to have no husband than a husband who lacks honor. However, as you requested, you may go and try to negotiate with your brother. In the meantime, I’ll raise an army that will surpass his. Go as soon as possible, so your prayers may be answered the sooner.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$                                                  Thanks to my lord.$NEWLINE$The Jove of power make me most weak, most weak,$NEWLINE$Your reconciler! Wars ’twixt you twain would be$NEWLINE$As if the world should cleave, and that slain men$NEWLINE$Should solder up the rift.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Thank you, my lord. May the god of power make me, the weakest of the weak, your mediator. A war between you two would split the very world, and the bodies of your slaughtered soldiers would have to fill the chasm between.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$When it appears to you where this begins,$NEWLINE$Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults$NEWLINE$Can never be so equal that your love$NEWLINE$Can equally move with them. Provide your going;$NEWLINE$Choose your own company and command what cost$NEWLINE$Your heart has mind to.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$When you find out who started this disagreement, turn your anger upon them. Our faults can’t be so alike that you would judge us similarly. Order supplies for your trip and choose your traveling companions. Spend as much as you like.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ENOBARBUS and EROS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS and EROS enter.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$EROS

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$How now, friend Eros!
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$How goes it, friend Eros?

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$There’s strange news come, sir.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Some startling news has just arrived, sir.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$What, man?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$What news, man?

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Caesar and Lepidus declared war against Pompey.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$This is old. What is the success?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$That’s old news. Who’s winning?

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Caesar, having made use of him in the wars ’gainst Pompey, presently denied him rivality, would not let him partake in the glory of the action, and, not resting here, accuses him of letters he had formerly wrote to Pompey; upon his own appeal seizes him. So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Caesar used Lepidus in the war, but as soon as it was over, Lepidus was expelled from the triumvirate. He wasn’t allowed any of the glory of the victory, and he was accused of treasonous correspondence with Pompey. On the basis of Caesar’s accusation alone, Lepidus was imprisoned. So the weak third of the triumvirate is imprisoned until death frees him.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more,$NEWLINE$And throw between them all the food thou hast,$NEWLINE$They’ll grind the one the other. Where’s Antony?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$So now the world will only be devoured by two sets of jaws—Caesar’s and Antony’s. And even if you throw everything you possess to the two of them, they’ll battle each other to the death to have it all. Where’s Antony?

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$He’s walking in the garden—(imitating anger) thus, and spurns$NEWLINE$(imitating anger)$NEWLINE$The rush that lies before him; cries, “Fool Lepidus!”$NEWLINE$And threats the throat of that his officer$NEWLINE$That murdered Pompey.
paragraphs.translated:
EROS$NEWLINE$He’s walking in the garden, like this (imitating anger). And he kicks the leaves on the path, exclaiming, “Lepidus, you fool!”
Then he threatens to kill the officer who murdered Pompey.$NEWLINE$(imitating anger).$NEWLINE$Then he threatens to kill the officer who murdered Pompey.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                Our great navy’s rigged.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Antony’s grand navy is prepared.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$For Italy and Caesar. More, Domitius:$NEWLINE$My lord desires you presently. My news$NEWLINE$I might have told hereafter.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$To sail to Italy and Caesar. Another thing, Domitius: Antony wants to see you now. I should have waited to tell you my news.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                      ’Twill be naught,$NEWLINE$But let it be. Bring me to Antony.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$It won’t be that important. But never mind. Take me to Antony.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Come, sir.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Come with me, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter AGRIPPA, MECAENAS, and CAESAR$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MECAENAS$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, and CAESAR enter.$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Contemning Rome, he has done all this and more$NEWLINE$In Alexandria. Here’s the manner of ’t:$NEWLINE$I’ th’ marketplace, on a tribunal silvered,$NEWLINE$Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold$NEWLINE$Were publicly enthroned. At the feet sat$NEWLINE$Caesarion, whom they call my father’s son,$NEWLINE$And all the unlawful issue that their lust$NEWLINE$Since then hath made between them. Unto her$NEWLINE$He gave the stablishment of Egypt, made her$NEWLINE$Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia,$NEWLINE$Absolute Queen.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR$NEWLINE$In Alexandria he condemned Rome, and that’s not all. This is what happened: he and Cleopatra sat on chairs of gold on a silver-covered stage in the marketplace.
Caesarion—whom they call my father’s son—and all their illegitimate children sat at their feet. Antony confirmed her possession of Egypt and made her absolute Queen of lower Syria, Cyprus, and Lydia.$NEWLINE$Caesarion—whom they call my father’s son—$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$                                  This in the public eye?
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$He did this in public?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I’ th’ common showplace, where they exercise.$NEWLINE$His sons he there proclaimed the kings of kings:$NEWLINE$Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia$NEWLINE$He gave to Alexander; to Ptolemy he assigned$NEWLINE$Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia. She$NEWLINE$In th’ habiliments of the goddess Isis$NEWLINE$That day appeared, and oft before gave audience,$NEWLINE$As ’tis reported, so.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$In the public arena, where they perform sporting events. He proclaimed his sons to be kings of kings. He gave Media, Parthia, and Armenia to Alexander. He gave Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia to Ptolemy. Cleopatra was dressed like the goddess Isis. They say she often attended her public functions like that.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Let Rome be thus informed.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Let’s send this news to Rome.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Who, queasy with his insolence already,$NEWLINE$Will their good thoughts call from him.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$The Roman people are fed up with his arrogance already. They’ll abandon him completely when they hear this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$The people knows it, and have now received$NEWLINE$His accusations.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$The people have heard it already, and they’ve been told of his accusations.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                Who does he accuse?
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Who does he accuse?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Caesar, and that, having in Sicily$NEWLINE$Sextus Pompeius spoiled, we had not rated him$NEWLINE$His part o’ th’ isle. Then does he say he lent me$NEWLINE$Some shipping, unrestored. Lastly, he frets$NEWLINE$That Lepidus of the triumvirate$NEWLINE$Should be deposed, and, being, that we detain$NEWLINE$All his revenue.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$He accuses me of withholding his share of Sextus Pompeius’ possessions, which we seized in Sicily. Then he says I didn’t return some ships he loaned me. Finally, he criticizes the deposing of Lepidus, and then goes on to accuse me of keeping all of Lepidus’ property for myself.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                Sir, this should be answered.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Sir, these accusations should be answered.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$’Tis done already, and the messenger gone.$NEWLINE$I have told him, Lepidus was grown too cruel,$NEWLINE$That he his high authority abused$NEWLINE$And did deserve his change. For what I have conquered,$NEWLINE$I grant him part; but then, in his Armenia,$NEWLINE$And other of his conquered kingdoms, I$NEWLINE$Demand the like.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$It has been done already, and the messenger is on his way. I answered that Lepidus had become too brutal and abused his position. For this he deserved to be deposed. As for what I seized in the wars, I granted that Antony should have a share. But I also demanded my share of his acquisitions in Armenia and the other conquered kingdoms.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$                                   He’ll never yield to that.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$He’ll never agree to that.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Nor must not then be yielded to in this.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Then we won’t agree to his demands.

paragraphs.original: Enter OCTAVIA with her train$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA enters with her attendants.$NEWLINE$OCTAVIA

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Hail, Caesar, and my lord! Hail, most dear Caesar!
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Greetings, Caesar, my lord! Greetings, dearest Caesar!

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$That ever I should call thee castaway!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Oh, to think you’ve been rejected!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$You have not called me so, nor have you cause.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$You’ve never thought of me like that, and you have no reason to.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Why have you stol’n upon us thus? You come not$NEWLINE$Like Caesar’s sister. The wife of Antony$NEWLINE$Should have an army for an usher and$NEWLINE$The neighs of horse to tell of her approach$NEWLINE$Long ere she did appear. The trees by th’ way$NEWLINE$Should have borne men, and expectation fainted,$NEWLINE$Longing for what it had not. Nay, the dust$NEWLINE$Should have ascended to the roof of heaven,$NEWLINE$Raised by your populous troops. But you are come$NEWLINE$A market-maid to Rome and have prevented$NEWLINE$The ostentation of our love, which, left unshown,$NEWLINE$Is often left unloved. We should have met you$NEWLINE$By sea and land, supplying every stage$NEWLINE$With an augmented greeting.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Then why did you travel so quietly? You didn’t arrive like Caesar’s sister. Antony’s wife should have an army to escort her, with neighing horses to announce her arrival long before she appears. The trees along the road should have been filled with eager spectators. Crowds should have been faint with excitement waiting to see you. The dust from your attending troops should have risen to heaven. But you’ve arrived like a common maid bringing goods to a Roman market. You’ve kept me from displaying my love—and when love is not shown, it’s often not felt. I would have met you by sea and again by land. At each stage of your trip there would have been a more spectacular greeting.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$                                                          Good my lord,$NEWLINE$To come thus was I not constrained, but did it$NEWLINE$On my free will. My lord, Mark Antony,$NEWLINE$Hearing that you prepared for war, acquainted$NEWLINE$My grievèd ear withal, whereon I begged$NEWLINE$His pardon for return.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$My good lord, I wasn’t forced to travel like this. It was my choice. Mark Antony heard that you were preparing to wage war on him. When he gave me this news, I begged him to let me visit you.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                            Which soon he granted,$NEWLINE$Being an obstruct ’tween his lust and him.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Which he quickly allowed, given that you’re an obstacle to his lust.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Do not say so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Don’t say that, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                              I have eyes upon him,$NEWLINE$And his affairs come to me on the wind.$NEWLINE$Where is he now?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$I’ve kept track of him, and reports of his affairs arrive on every ship. Where do you think he is now?

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$My lord, in Athens.
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$He’s in Athens, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$No, my most wrongèd sister. Cleopatra$NEWLINE$Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his empire$NEWLINE$Up to a whore; who now are levying$NEWLINE$The kings o’ th’ earth for war. He hath assembled$NEWLINE$Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus,$NEWLINE$Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King$NEWLINE$Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas;$NEWLINE$King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont;$NEWLINE$Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King$NEWLINE$Of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas,$NEWLINE$The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia,$NEWLINE$With a more larger list of scepters.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$No, he’s not. You’ve been deceived. Cleopatra summoned him. He’s given his empire to a whore, and now they’re gathering kings to wage a war. He’s recruited Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; the King of Pont; Herod, of Judea; Mithridates, King of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas, the kings of Mede and Lycaonia, and many more.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Ay me, most wretched,$NEWLINE$That have my heart parted betwixt two friends$NEWLINE$That does afflict each other!
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$Oh, I’m heartbroken. I’m divided between two friends who are determined to kill each other.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                       Welcome hither.$NEWLINE$Your letters did withhold our breaking forth$NEWLINE$Till we perceived both how you were wrong led$NEWLINE$And we in negligent danger. Cheer your heart.$NEWLINE$Be you not troubled with the time, which drives$NEWLINE$O’er your content these strong necessities,$NEWLINE$But let determined things to destiny$NEWLINE$Hold unbewailed their way. Welcome to Rome,$NEWLINE$Nothing more dear to me. You are abused$NEWLINE$Beyond the mark of thought, and the high gods,$NEWLINE$To do you justice, makes his ministers$NEWLINE$Of us and those that love you. Best of comfort,$NEWLINE$And ever welcome to us.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$You’re welcome here. I didn’t write about breaking the alliance with Antony until I saw you were being misled and realized how dangerous it would be to keep postponing preparations. Cheer yourself. Don’t be troubled by the present situation, the obligations of which must ruin your happiness. Don’t worry about things that have already been decided by fate. Welcome home to Rome. Nothing is more precious to me than you. You have been unbelievably abused, and now the gods make us the dispensers of justice. Be comforted. You will always be welcome to me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$                                                 Welcome, lady.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Welcome, lady.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Welcome, dear madam.$NEWLINE$Each heart in Rome does love and pity you.$NEWLINE$Only th’ adulterous Antony, most large$NEWLINE$In his abominations, turns you off$NEWLINE$And gives his potent regiment to a trull$NEWLINE$That noises it against us.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Welcome, dear madam. Every heart in Rome loves and pities you.$NEWLINE$Only the adulterous and abominable Antony abandons you, giving his power to a whore who turns that power against us.

paragraphs.original: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$          (to CAESAR )            Is it so, sir?$NEWLINE$          (to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: OCTAVIA$NEWLINE$(to CAESAR ) Is that true, sir?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Most certain. Sister, welcome. Pray you$NEWLINE$Be ever known to patience. My dear’st sister!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$It’s undeniable. You are welcome here, sister. I beg you to continue to be patient. My dearest sister!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA and ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA and ENOBARBUS enter.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I will be even with thee, doubt it not.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I’ll be straight with you. Do not doubt it.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$But why, why, why?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$But why, why, why?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars$NEWLINE$And sayst it is not fit.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$You opposed my taking part in the war. You said it wasn’t proper.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                            Well, is it, is it?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Well, is it? Is it?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is ’t not denounced against us? Why should not we$NEWLINE$Be there in person?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Isn’t this war against me? Why shouldn’t I be there in person?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                      Well, I could reply,$NEWLINE$If we should serve with horse and mares together,$NEWLINE$The horse were merely lost. The mares would bear$NEWLINE$A soldier and his horse.
