paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Well, I could answer that if we went to war on male and female horses alike—the male horses would be totally distracted and useless. The mares would be ridden by their riders and the male horses.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                               What is ’t you say?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What do you mean?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Your presence needs must puzzle Antony,$NEWLINE$Take from his heart, take from his brain, from ’s time$NEWLINE$What should not then be spared. He is already$NEWLINE$Traduced for levity, and ’tis said in Rome$NEWLINE$That Photinus, an eunuch, and your maids$NEWLINE$Manage this war.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Antony will necessarily be distracted by your presence. You will affect his heart and his head. You’ll take up time he can’t afford to lose. He’s already criticized for frivolous behavior. In Rome they say that your eunuch Photinus and your maids run the war.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                   Sink Rome! And their tongues rot$NEWLINE$That speak against us! A charge we bear i’ th’ war,$NEWLINE$And as the president of my kingdom will$NEWLINE$Appear there for a man. Speak not against it.$NEWLINE$I will not stay behind.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Let Rome fall! May the tongues of our critics rot! I have responsibilities in this war, and as the absolute ruler of my kingdom I will carry out my duties as if I were a man. Don’t argue against it. I won’t stay behind.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Enter$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$CANIDIUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and CANIDIUS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CANIDIUS

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                           Nay, I have done.$NEWLINE$Here comes the Emperor.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$No, I’ve had my say. Here comes the Emperor.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                 Is it not strange, Canidius,$NEWLINE$That from Tarentum and Brundusium$NEWLINE$He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea$NEWLINE$And take in Toryne?—You have heard on ’t, sweet?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Isn’t it strange, Canidius, that he could cross the Ionian Sea so quickly from Tarentum and Brundusium and take Toryne?—Have you heard about this, sweet?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Celerity is never more admired$NEWLINE$Than by the negligent.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No one admires speed more than the lazy.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                             A good rebuke,$NEWLINE$Which might have well becomed the best of men,$NEWLINE$To taunt at slackness.—Canidius, we will fight$NEWLINE$With him by sea.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$That’s a good reprimand, suitable for reminding even the best of men to guard against negligence. Canidius, we’ll fight him at sea.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                   By sea, what else?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Of course we’ll fight him by sea. What else?

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$                                                                     Why will$NEWLINE$My lord do so?
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Why do you want to do that, my lord?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                              For that he dares us to ’t.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Because he’s daring us to do it.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$So hath my lord dared him to single fight.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$So you’ve dared him to single combat.

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia,$NEWLINE$Where Caesar fought with Pompey. But these offers,$NEWLINE$Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off,$NEWLINE$And so should you.
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Yes, and you dared Caesar to fight the battle at Pharsalia, where he fought against Pompey. But Caesar ignores offers that don’t give him an advantage, and so should you.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                       Your ships are not well manned,$NEWLINE$Your mariners are muleteers, reapers, people$NEWLINE$Engrossed by swift impress. In Caesar’s fleet$NEWLINE$Are those that often have ’gainst Pompey fought.$NEWLINE$Their ships are yare, yours, heavy. No disgrace$NEWLINE$Shall fall you for refusing him at sea,$NEWLINE$Being prepared for land.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Your ships are not well crewed. Your sailors are mule drivers, harvesters—men who were drafted quickly and have little training. Caesar’s fleet is manned by mariners who already have experience battling Pompey. His ships are maneuverable. Yours are slow and awkward. Refusing to fight him at sea won’t disgrace you. You’ve prepared for a land war.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                By sea, by sea.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I will fight by sea. By sea.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Most worthy sir, you therein throw away$NEWLINE$The absolute soldiership you have by land,$NEWLINE$Distract your army, which doth most consist$NEWLINE$Of war-marked footmen, leave unexecuted$NEWLINE$Your own renownèd knowledge, quite forego$NEWLINE$The way which promises assurance, and$NEWLINE$Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard$NEWLINE$From firm security.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Most worthy sir, if you do that you throw away all the advantages you have on land. You will have to divide your army, which mostly consists of battle-hardened foot soldiers. You will be unable to use your legendary battle knowledge. You’ll be abandoning proven methods that promise victory, and instead you’ll put yourself at the mercy of haphazard chance.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                       I’ll fight at sea.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ll fight at sea.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I have sixty sails, Caesar none better.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I have sixty ships. Caesar doesn’t have any that are better.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Our overplus of shipping will we burn,$NEWLINE$And with the rest full-manned, from th’ head of Actium$NEWLINE$Beat th’ approaching Caesar. But if we fail,$NEWLINE$We then can do ’t at land.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$We’ll burn our surplus ships and fully man the rest. We’ll sail from Actium and beat Caesar as he approaches. Even if we fail at that, we can still fight him on land.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: Thy business?
paragraphs.translated: What’s your business?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The news is true, my lord. He is descried.$NEWLINE$Caesar has taken Toryne.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The news is true, my lord. Caesar has been seen. He has captured Toryne.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Can he be there in person? ’Tis impossible,$NEWLINE$Strange that his power should be. Canidius,$NEWLINE$Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land,$NEWLINE$And our twelve thousand horse. We’ll to our ship.$NEWLINE$Away, my Thetis!
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY$NEWLINE$Can Caesar be there in person? No, that’s impossible. It’s strange enough that his army should be there. Canidius, take our nineteen
legions and twelve thousand horse soldiers. You must hold them on land. We’ll go to our ship. Come away, Cleopatra.$NEWLINE$legions$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a SOLDIER$NEWLINE$SOLDIER
paragraphs.translated: A SOLDIER enters.$NEWLINE$SOLDIER

paragraphs.original: How now, worthy soldier?
paragraphs.translated: What’s the news, brave soldier?

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea!$NEWLINE$Trust not to rotten planks. Do you misdoubt$NEWLINE$This sword and these my wounds? Let th’ Egyptians$NEWLINE$And the Phoenicians go a-ducking. We$NEWLINE$Have used to conquer standing on the earth$NEWLINE$And fighting foot to foot.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Oh, don’t fight by sea, noble Emperor! Don’t trust rotten planks. Don’t you trust my sword and these wounds? Let the Egyptians and Phoenicians go swimming. We are used to winning by standing on the earth and fighting toe to toe.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                  Well, well, away.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Well, well, let’s go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, and ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, and ENOBARBUS exit.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$By Hercules, I think I am i’ th’ right.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$By Hercules, I think I’m right.

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Soldier, thou art; but his whole action grows$NEWLINE$Not in the power on ’t. So our leader’s led,$NEWLINE$And we are women’s men.
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Soldier, you are. But Antony’s decisions aren’t coming from his extensive experience. Our leader is being led. We are following a woman.

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$                                                    You keep by land$NEWLINE$The legions and the horse whole, do you not?
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$On land you keep the legions and cavalry together, don’t you?

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius,$NEWLINE$Publicola, and Caelius, are for sea;$NEWLINE$But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar’s$NEWLINE$Carries beyond belief.
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius will go by sea, but we’ll keep the bulk on land. Caesar’s speed defies belief.

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$While he was yet in Rome$NEWLINE$His power went out in such distractions as$NEWLINE$Beguiled all spies.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$While he was still in Rome, he deployed his forces in so many different disguises that all our spies were fooled.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$                                    Who’s his lieutenant, hear you?
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Who’s his lieutenant, do you know?

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$They say, one Taurus.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$A man named Taurus, they say.

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$                                           Well I know the man.
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$I know the man well.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The Emperor calls Canidius.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The Emperor is calling for Canidius.

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$With news the time’s with labor, and throws forth$NEWLINE$Each minute some.
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$The present time is like a woman in labor, each minute giving birth to some piece of news.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR with his army, and TAURUS, marching$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$TAURUS
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR enters with TAURUS and his army.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$TAURUS

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Taurus!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Taurus!

paragraphs.original: TAURUS$NEWLINE$My lord?
paragraphs.translated: TAURUS$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Strike not by land; keep whole. Provoke not battle$NEWLINE$Till we have done at sea. Do not exceed$NEWLINE$The prescript of this scroll.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Don’t attack by land. Keep the army together. Don’t provoke them to battle until we have finished at sea. Don’t exceed your orders as written here.

paragraphs.original: He gives a scroll
paragraphs.translated: He hands TAURUS a scroll.$NEWLINE$TAURUS

paragraphs.original: Our fortune lies$NEWLINE$Upon this jump.
paragraphs.translated: Our fate depends on this chance.

paragraphs.original: Exit with army
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and ENOBARBUS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Set we our squadrons on yond side o’ th’ hill,$NEWLINE$In eye of Caesar’s battle, from which place$NEWLINE$We may the number of the ships behold$NEWLINE$And so proceed accordingly.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Assemble our squadrons on the other side of the hill, in sight of Caesar’s navy. From there we’ll be able to see how many ships he has and plan accordingly.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS marcheth with his land army one way over the stage, and TAURUS, the lieutenant of CAESAR, the other way. After their going in is heard the noise of a sea fight$NEWLINE$CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$TAURUS$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS and his army marches one way across the stage while CAESAR’s lieutenant, TAURUS, marches across the other way. After the two armies march off stage, the noise of a battle at sea is heard.$NEWLINE$CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$TAURUS

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound a retreat. ENOBARBUS enters.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Naught, naught, all naught! I can behold no longer.$NEWLINE$Th’ Antoniad, the Egyptian admiral,$NEWLINE$Antoniad$NEWLINE$With all their sixty, fly and turn the rudder.$NEWLINE$To see ’t mine eyes are blasted.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$We’re ruined, ruined, ruined! I can’t watch any more. The Egyptian flagship, the Antoniad, followed by all sixty Egyptian ships, has turned and fled. It destroyed my eyes to look upon it.$NEWLINE$Antoniad,

paragraphs.original: Enter SCARUS$NEWLINE$SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS enters.$NEWLINE$SCARUS

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$                                                              Gods and goddesses,$NEWLINE$All the whole synod of them!
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$Gods and goddesses—the whole congregation of them!

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                         What’s thy passion?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$What’s wrong with you?

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$The greater cantle of the world is lost$NEWLINE$With very ignorance. We have kissed away$NEWLINE$Kingdoms and provinces.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$We have lost a major portion of the world through utter foolishness. We have kissed away entire kingdoms and provinces.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                   How appears the fight?
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$How goes the battle?

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$On our side like the tokened pestilence,$NEWLINE$Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt—$NEWLINE$Whom leprosy o’ertake!—i’ th’ midst o’ th’ fight,$NEWLINE$When vantage like a pair of twins appeared$NEWLINE$Both as the same, or rather ours the elder,$NEWLINE$The breeze upon her, like a cow in June,$NEWLINE$Hoists sails and flies.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$Our side shows all the signs of certain defeat, which appear like the symptomatic sores of the plague. Right in the middle of the fight, just when the battle could have gone either way—actually we had a slight advantage—that immoral Egyptian nag—May she die of leprosy!—suddenly became frightened, and turned her ships around and fled.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$That I beheld.$NEWLINE$Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not$NEWLINE$Endure a further view.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I saw that. The sight made me so sick I couldn’t watch any more.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$                                             She once being loofed,$NEWLINE$The noble ruin of her magic, Antony,$NEWLINE$Claps on his sea-wing and, like a doting mallard$NEWLINE$Leaving the fight in height, flies after her.$NEWLINE$I never saw an action of such shame.$NEWLINE$Experience, manhood, honor, ne’er before$NEWLINE$Did violate so itself.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$Once she had turned around, the noble Antony, ruined by love, hoisted his own sails and followed her like a lovesick duck. He left the battle at the most crucial point. I never saw such a shameful act. He betrayed his own experience, manhood, and honor.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                         Alack, alack!
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Terrible. Terrible.

paragraphs.original: Enter CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$CANIDIUS
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS enters.$NEWLINE$CANIDIUS

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Our fortune on the sea is out of breath$NEWLINE$And sinks most lamentably. Had our general$NEWLINE$Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.$NEWLINE$Oh, he has given example for our flight$NEWLINE$Most grossly by his own!
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$The battle on the sea is almost lost. If our general had been his old self, we would have won. Oh, with his sordid desertion, he sets the example for our own.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Ay, are you thereabouts? Why then, good night indeed.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Are you considering desertion, as well? Then everything must really be finished.

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$They fled toward Peloponnesus.

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$’Tis easy to ’t, and there I will attend$NEWLINE$What further comes.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$It’s easy to get there. I’ll go there and ascertain their next move.

paragraphs.original: He exits
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$                                          To Caesar will I render$NEWLINE$My legions and my horse. Six kings already$NEWLINE$Show me the way of yielding.
paragraphs.translated: CANIDIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll yield my legions and cavalry to Caesar. In this, I follow the examples of the six kings who have already surrendered.

paragraphs.original: He exits
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                         I’ll yet follow$NEWLINE$The wounded chance of Antony, though my reason$NEWLINE$Sits in the wind against me.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I’ll still follow Antony, even though the odds are against him and good sense tells me I should go the other way.

paragraphs.original: He exits
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY with attendants$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters with attendants.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Hark. The land bids me tread no more upon ’t.$NEWLINE$It is ashamed to bear me. Friends, come hither.$NEWLINE$I am so lated in the world that I$NEWLINE$Have lost my way forever. I have a ship$NEWLINE$Laden with gold. Take that, divide it. Fly$NEWLINE$And make your peace with Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Listen. The earth tells me to stop walking upon it, as it’s ashamed to carry me. Friends, come here. I’m completely lost. I have a ship full of treasure. Take that. Divide it. Escape and make peace with Caesar.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$                                                                    Fly? Not we.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Flee? Not us.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards$NEWLINE$To run and show their shoulders. Friends, begone.$NEWLINE$I have myself resolved upon a course$NEWLINE$Which has no need of you. Begone.$NEWLINE$My treasure’s in the harbor. Take it. Oh,$NEWLINE$I followed that I blush to look upon!$NEWLINE$My very hairs do mutiny, for the white$NEWLINE$Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them$NEWLINE$For fear and doting. Friends, begone. You shall$NEWLINE$Have letters from me to some friends that will$NEWLINE$Sweep your way for you. Pray you, look not sad,$NEWLINE$Nor make replies of loathness. Take the hint$NEWLINE$Which my despair proclaims. Let that be left$NEWLINE$Which leaves itself. To the seaside straightway!$NEWLINE$I will possess you of that ship and treasure.$NEWLINE$Leave me, I pray, a little. Pray you now,$NEWLINE$Nay, do so, for indeed I have lost command.$NEWLINE$Therefore I pray you. I’ll see you by and by.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I have already fled from my true self. I’ve told cowards to turn their backs on me and run. Friends, go. I’ve decided on a plan that doesn’t require your assistance. Leave. My treasure’s in the harbor; take it. Oh, I followed something I’m ashamed to look at now! Even my hair revolts. The white hairs blame the brown hairs for being irresponsible, and the brown ones blame the white ones for being spineless and foolish. Friends, go. I’ll give you letters of introduction to some friends of mine who will help you. Please, don’t be sad, and don’t tell me how reluctant you are. Take your cues from my own despair. Abandon the person that has abandoned himself. Go to the harbor immediately! I’ll give you the title to that ship and its treasure. Just give me a moment, please—only a moment. I’ve relinquished my authority, so please—I’ll see you all before long.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt attendants. ANTONY sits down$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: The attendants exit. ANTONY sits.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, led by CHARMIAN, IRAS, and EROS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN, IRAS, and EROS enter, supporting CLEOPATRA.$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Nay, gentle madam, to him, comfort him.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$No, gentle madam, go. Comfort him.

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Do, most dear Queen.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Yes, do, dearest Queen.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Do. Why, what else?
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Of course you must comfort him! What else?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Let me sit down. O Juno!
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Let me sit down. Oh,
Juno!$NEWLINE$Juno$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: She sits
paragraphs.translated: She sits.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(seeing CLEOPATRA ) No, no, no, no, no.$NEWLINE$(seeing$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(seeing CLEOPATRA ) No, no, no, no, no.$NEWLINE$(seeing$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$See you here, sir?
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Do you see her, sir?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Oh, fie, fie, fie!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Oh, damn, damn, damn!

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Madam!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Madam!

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Madam, O good Empress!
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Madam, oh, good Empress!

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Sir, sir—
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Sir . . . sir . . .

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(aside) Yes, my lord, yes. He at Philippi kept$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$His sword e’en like a dancer, while I struck$NEWLINE$The lean and wrinkled Cassius, and ’twas I$NEWLINE$That the mad Brutus ended. He alone$NEWLINE$Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practice had$NEWLINE$In the brave squares of war, yet now—no matter.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to himself) Yes, my lord, that’s true. At Philippi, Caesar kept his sword in its sheath, like a dancer, while I commanded the armies that conquered Cassius and Brutus. Caesar fought only through lieutenants. He had no experience with the brave contests of war. But now . . . never mind.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Ah, stand by.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Ah, give us some privacy.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                             The Queen, my lord, the Queen.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$The Queen is here, my lord.

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Go to him, madam, speak to him.$NEWLINE$He is unqualitied with very shame.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Go to him, madam, speak to him. He’s not himself because he feels so ashamed.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Well then, sustain me. Oh!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Well, then, help me.

paragraphs.original: She rises
paragraphs.translated: Her attendants help her to stand.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Most noble sir, arise. The Queen approaches.$NEWLINE$Her head’s declined, and death will seize her but$NEWLINE$Your comfort makes the rescue.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Most noble sir, stand up. The Queen is coming. She’s weak and will die unless you comfort her.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I have offended reputation,$NEWLINE$A most unnoble swerving.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ve destroyed my reputation, a most shameful error.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                                     Sir, the Queen.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Sir, here’s the Queen.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Oh, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See$NEWLINE$How I convey my shame out of thine eyes$NEWLINE$By looking back what I have left behind$NEWLINE$’Stroyed in dishonor.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Oh, where have you led me, Egypt? See how I hide my shame from you by turning around? I look behind me to see my past, destroyed by dishonor.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                          O my lord, my lord,$NEWLINE$Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought$NEWLINE$You would have followed.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, my lord, my lord, forgive my panic! I didn’t think you would follow me.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                   Egypt, thou knew’st too well$NEWLINE$My heart was to thy rudder tied by th’ strings,$NEWLINE$And thou shouldst tow me after. O’er my spirit$NEWLINE$Thy full supremacy thou knew’st, and that$NEWLINE$Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods$NEWLINE$Command me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Queen, you knew very well that my heart was tied to your ship and that you would pull me along with you. You knew that my spirit was completely under your control and that I would ignore the gods’ orders in favor of yours.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                              Oh, my pardon!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, forgive me!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                               Now I must$NEWLINE$To the young man send humble treaties, dodge$NEWLINE$And palter in the shifts of lowness, who$NEWLINE$With half the bulk o’ th’ world played as I pleased,$NEWLINE$Making and marring fortunes. You did know$NEWLINE$How much you were my conqueror, and that$NEWLINE$My sword, made weak by my affection, would$NEWLINE$Obey it on all cause.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now I will have to send my humble proposal of peace to that young man. I’ve done as I pleased with half the world, making and losing fortunes, but now I negotiate from a position of weakness. You knew how far you had conquered my spirit. You knew that my sword, weakened by my love for you, would obey that love no matter what.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                         Pardon, pardon!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Forgive me! Forgive me!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Fall not a tear, I say. One of them rates$NEWLINE$All that is won and lost. Give me a kiss.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Don’t shed even one tear. One of your tears is worth everything that was won and lost. Give me a kiss.

paragraphs.original: They kiss
paragraphs.translated: They kiss.

paragraphs.original: Even this repays me.—$NEWLINE$We sent our schoolmaster. Is he come back?—$NEWLINE$Love, I am full of lead.—(calling) Some wine,$NEWLINE$(calling)$NEWLINE$Within there, and our viands! Fortune knows$NEWLINE$We scorn her most when most she offers blows.
paragraphs.translated: This repays me. I sent our children’s schoolmaster to Caesar with our offer. Has he returned? Love, I am full of heaviness. (calling) Servants, bring some wine and food! We have the most contempt for fortune when it goes against us.$NEWLINE$(calling)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, THIDIAS, and DOLABELLA, with others$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$DOLABELLA
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR, AGRIPPA, THIDIAS, and DOLABELLA enter, with others of the court.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$DOLABELLA

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Let him appear that’s come from Antony.$NEWLINE$Know you him?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Let the envoy from Antony come in. Do you know him?

paragraphs.original: DOLABELLA$NEWLINE$                                Caesar, ’tis his schoolmaster—$NEWLINE$An argument that he is plucked, when hither$NEWLINE$He sends so poor a pinion of his wing,$NEWLINE$Which had superfluous kings for messengers$NEWLINE$Not many moons gone by.
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA$NEWLINE$It’s Antony’s schoolmaster. By sending such an insignificant emissary, Antony shows us how low he has sunk. Not so long ago, he had so many royal supporters that he sent along extra kings as messengers.

paragraphs.original: Enter AMBASSADOR from Antony$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR
paragraphs.translated: Antony’s AMBASSADOR enters.$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                     Approach and speak.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Come forward and speak.

paragraphs.original: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Such as I am, I come from Antony.$NEWLINE$I was of late as petty to his ends$NEWLINE$As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf$NEWLINE$To his grand sea.
paragraphs.translated: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Humble as I am, I represent Antony. Until recently, I was as unimportant to his affairs as the morning dew is to the wide ocean.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                  Be ’t so. Declare thine office.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$So be it. Say what you’re here for.

paragraphs.original: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and$NEWLINE$Requires to live in Egypt; which not granted,$NEWLINE$He lessens his requests, and to thee sues$NEWLINE$To let him breathe between the heavens and earth$NEWLINE$A private man in Athens. This for him.$NEWLINE$Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness,$NEWLINE$Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves$NEWLINE$The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs,$NEWLINE$Now hazarded to thy grace.
paragraphs.translated: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$He acknowledges that you are the master of his fate, and he requests to be allowed to live in Egypt. If that is not granted, he reduces his requests and asks only that he be allowed to live as a private man in Athens. That’s all he asks for himself. Cleopatra recognizes your greatness and accepts your authority. She only asks that the crown of Egypt pass to her heirs, who are now at your mercy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                        For Antony,$NEWLINE$I have no ears to his request. The Queen$NEWLINE$Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she$NEWLINE$From Egypt drive her all-disgracèd friend$NEWLINE$Or take his life there. This if she perform,$NEWLINE$She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$As for Antony, I’m not interested in his requests. I’ll give the Queen a hearing and grant her requests if she either throws her dishonored friend out of Egypt or kills him. Then I’ll listen to her. Give my answer to them both.

paragraphs.original: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Fortune pursue thee!
paragraphs.translated: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$May good luck follow you!

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                         Bring him through the bands.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Take him safely through the lines.

paragraphs.original: Exit AMBASSADOR, attended$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR
paragraphs.translated: The AMBASSADOR exits.$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR

paragraphs.original: (to THIDIAS ) To try thy eloquence now ’tis time. Dispatch.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$From Antony win Cleopatra. Promise,$NEWLINE$And in our name, what she requires. Add more,$NEWLINE$From thine invention, offers. Women are not$NEWLINE$In their best fortunes strong, but want will perjure$NEWLINE$The ne’er-touched vestal. Try thy cunning, Thidias.$NEWLINE$Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we$NEWLINE$Will answer as a law.
paragraphs.translated:
(to THIDIAS ) Now it’s time to test your eloquence. On your way. Separate Cleopatra from Antony. In my name, promise to fulfill her petitions. You can make up additional offers, if necessary. Women aren’t strong, even at their best. Hardship will make even a
vestal abandon her vows. Use your ingenuity, Thidias. You can make your own conditions, which I will authorize as law.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$vestal$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$                                         Caesar, I go.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$I go, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Observe how Antony becomes his flaw,$NEWLINE$And what thou think’st his very action speaks$NEWLINE$In every power that moves.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Observe how Antony takes his defeat and how his attitude influences his actions.

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$                                                      Caesar, I shall.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$I will, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS enter.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What shall we do, Enobarbus?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What are we going to do, Enobarbus?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                            Think and die.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Think about our situation, then die.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is Antony or we in fault for this?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Who is to blame for this: Antony or I?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Antony only, that would make his will$NEWLINE$Lord of his reason. What though you fled$NEWLINE$From that great face of war, whose several ranges$NEWLINE$Frighted each other? Why should he follow?$NEWLINE$The itch of his affection should not then$NEWLINE$Have nicked his captainship at such a point$NEWLINE$When half to half the world opposed, he being$NEWLINE$The merèd question. ’Twas a shame no less$NEWLINE$Than was his loss, to course your flying flags$NEWLINE$And leave his navy gazing.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Only Antony was at fault. He put his desire in charge of his reason. So what if you ran from the battle, terrified, as ranks of ships threatened one another? Why should he have followed you? With half the world opposing the other half, it wasn’t the time for Antony, the pivotal player, to let love distract him. To race after your departing ships, leaving his navy to watch, was a shame as great as the resulting loss.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                    Prithee, peace.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Please, let’s not talk about it.

paragraphs.original: Enter AMBASSADOR with ANTONY$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: The AMBASSADOR and ANTONY enter.$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Is that his answer?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Is that his answer?

paragraphs.original: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she$NEWLINE$Will yield us up?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The Queen will be treated fairly if she gives me up?

paragraphs.original: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$                                  He says so.
paragraphs.translated: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$That’s what he says.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                           Let her know ’t.—$NEWLINE$(to CLEOPATRA ) To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And he will fill thy wishes to the brim$NEWLINE$With principalities.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Tell her. (to CLEOPATRA ) If you send my aged head to that boy, Caesar, he’ll give you all the kingdoms you want.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                       That head, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Your head, my lord?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to the AMBASSADOR ) To him again. Tell him he wears the rose$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Of youth upon him, from which the world should note$NEWLINE$Something particular. His coin, ships, legions,$NEWLINE$May be a coward’s, whose ministers would prevail$NEWLINE$Under the service of a child as soon$NEWLINE$As i’ th’ command of Caesar. I dare him therefore$NEWLINE$To lay his gay caparisons apart$NEWLINE$And answer me declined, sword against sword,$NEWLINE$Ourselves alone. I’ll write it. Follow me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to the AMBASSADOR ) Go back to him. Tell him that his cheeks still bear the pink flush of youth, and that the world expects to see something remarkable from him. His treasure, his navy, and his armies might belong to a coward, and his ministers might be able to succeed just as well on behalf of a child as under the command of Caesar. Therefore, I dare him to lay aside his fancy trappings and meet this old man in single combat, sword against sword, just the two of us. I’ll write the challenge. Follow me.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTONY and AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and the AMBASSADOR exit.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$AMBASSADOR

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside) Yes, like enough, high-battled Caesar will$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Unstate his happiness and be staged to th’ show$NEWLINE$Against a sworder! I see men’s judgments are$NEWLINE$A parcel of their fortunes, and things outward$NEWLINE$Do draw the inward quality after them$NEWLINE$To suffer all alike. That he should dream,$NEWLINE$Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will$NEWLINE$Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdued$NEWLINE$His judgment too.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside) Oh, that’s likely! Caesar, the great commander of troops, will surely risk all he has gained in order to fight this gladiator in the public square! I see that men’s judgments are tied to their fortunes, and that external factors influence a man’s internal qualities, making everything suffer. How could Antony, knowing how luck stood on either side, still imagine that Caesar would respond to his nonsense! Caesar, you’ve conquered his judgment too.$NEWLINE$(aside)

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$                                      A messenger from Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$A messenger has arrived from Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What, no more ceremony? See, my women,$NEWLINE$Against the blown rose may they stop their nose,$NEWLINE$That kneeled unto the buds.—Admit him, sir.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$With no more ceremony than that? See, ladies, how they scorn me now. They pinch their noses to avoid smelling the dying rose whose scent, as a bud, they happily inhaled. Show him in, sir.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside) Mine honesty and I begin to square.$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$The loyalty well held to fools does make$NEWLINE$Our faith mere folly. Yet he that can endure$NEWLINE$To follow with allegiance a fall’n lord$NEWLINE$Does conquer him that did his master conquer$NEWLINE$And earns a place i’ th’ story.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside) My integrity and I begin to contradict each other. Being loyal to a fool makes loyalty foolish. But a person who can bear to keep his allegiance to a defeated lord defeats his lord’s conqueror and earns a place in history.$NEWLINE$(aside)

paragraphs.original: Enter THIDIAS$NEWLINE$THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS enters.$NEWLINE$THIDIAS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                          Caesar’s will?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What does Caesar want?

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$Hear it apart.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$It is for your ears only.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                          None but friends. Say boldly.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$There are only friends here. Speak confidently.

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$So haply are they friends to Antony.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$So they are possibly Antony’s friends.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has,$NEWLINE$Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master$NEWLINE$Will leap to be his friend. For us, you know$NEWLINE$Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar’s.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Sir, he should have as many as Caesar has. If he had that many friends, then he wouldn’t need us. If Caesar chose, Antony would jump at the chance to be his friend. As for us, you know we are Antony’s, and he is Caesar’s.

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$So.—$NEWLINE$Thus then, thou most renowned: Caesar entreats$NEWLINE$Not to consider in what case thou stand’st,$NEWLINE$Further than he is Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$So be it. This, then, this is the message Caesar sends to you, famous Queen: he implores you not to be concerned about your situation. Just remember that he is Caesar.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                    Go on. Right royal.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Respectfully put. Go on.

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$He knows that you embrace not Antony$NEWLINE$As you did love, but as you feared him.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$He knows that you didn’t embrace Antony because you loved him, but because you feared him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                                               Oh!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh!

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$The scars upon your honor therefore he$NEWLINE$Does pity as constrainèd blemishes,$NEWLINE$Not as deserved.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$So he regrets that any dishonorable acts were forced on you, not being performed of your own free will.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                 He is a god and knows$NEWLINE$What is most right. Mine honor was not yielded,$NEWLINE$But conquered merely.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$He is like a god and knows the truth. My honor wasn’t given; it was only dominated.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                (aside) To be sure of that,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky$NEWLINE$That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for$NEWLINE$Thy dearest quit thee.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside) I’ll go get the truth of this from Antony. Sir, sir, are you so badly off that we must abandon you to your fate? Even your dearest friend has abandoned you.$NEWLINE$(aside)

paragraphs.original: Exit ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS exits.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$                                            Shall I say to Caesar$NEWLINE$What you require of him? For he partly begs$NEWLINE$To be desired to give. It much would please him$NEWLINE$That of his fortunes you should make a staff$NEWLINE$To lean upon. But it would warm his spirits$NEWLINE$To hear from me you had left Antony$NEWLINE$And put yourself under his shroud,$NEWLINE$The universal landlord.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$Shall I tell Caesar what you request from him? He almost begs for the opportunity to help you. It would please him very much if you would rely on his wealth and success to support you. But he would feel even better if I could tell him that you had left Antony and put yourself under his protection.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                               What’s your name?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$What’s your name?

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$My name is Thidias.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$My name is Thidias.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                         Most kind messenger,$NEWLINE$Say to great Caesar this in deputation:$NEWLINE$I kiss his conqu’ring hand. Tell him I am prompt$NEWLINE$To lay my crown at ’s feet, and there to kneel.$NEWLINE$Tell him, from his all-obeying breath I hear$NEWLINE$The doom of Egypt.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Most kind messenger, tell great Caesar that through his deputy I kiss his conquering hand. Tell him I am ready to lay my crown at his feet and kneel before him. Tell him—whose decrees are obeyed by the whole world—that I will accept the fate he chooses for Egypt.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$                                        ’Tis your noblest course.$NEWLINE$Wisdom and fortune combating together,$NEWLINE$If that the former dare but what it can,$NEWLINE$No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay$NEWLINE$My duty on your hand.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$That’s your most dignified course of action. When confronted with the choice between a prudent action and a risky one, a wise man should dare to do only what he can practically accomplish—if he follows this course, he will never be subjected to unpredictable chance. Allow me to pay my respects by kissing your hand.

paragraphs.original: He kisses her hand
paragraphs.translated: He kisses her hand.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Your Caesar’s father oft,$NEWLINE$When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in,$NEWLINE$Bestowed his lips on that unworthy place$NEWLINE$As it rained kisses.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$When Octavius Caesar’s father thought about conquering kingdoms, he rained kisses on my unworthy hand.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and ENOBARBUS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                      Favors? By Jove that thunders!$NEWLINE$What art thou, fellow?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Promising favors? By Jove that thunders! Who are you, slave?

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$                                             One that but performs$NEWLINE$The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest$NEWLINE$To have command obeyed.
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$A person who merely follows the orders of the best man, the man most worthy of service.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                      You will be whipped.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$You will be whipped.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(calling for servants) Approach, there! (to THIDIAS ) Ah, you kite!—Now, gods and devils!$NEWLINE$(calling for servants)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Authority melts from me. Of late, when I cried “Ho!”$NEWLINE$Like boys unto a muss kings would start forth$NEWLINE$And cry, “Your will?” (calling to servants) Have you no ears? I am$NEWLINE$(calling to servants)$NEWLINE$Antony yet.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(calling for servants) Come here! (to THIDIAS ) Ah, you bird of prey! Now by all the gods and devils, my authority weakens. Not long ago, when I cried, “Ho!” kings would jump up and cry, “What’s your pleasure?” (calling to servants) Are you deaf? I’m still Antony.$NEWLINE$(calling for servants)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(calling to servants)

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT, followed by others$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters, followed by others.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Take hence this jack and whip him.
paragraphs.translated: Take away this lout and whip him.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside) ’Tis better playing with a lion’s whelp$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Than with an old one dying.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside) It’s safer to toy with a lion cub than an old, dying lion.$NEWLINE$(aside)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                        Moon and stars!$NEWLINE$Whip him. Were ’t twenty of the greatest tributaries$NEWLINE$That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them$NEWLINE$So saucy with the hand of she here—what’s her name$NEWLINE$Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows,$NEWLINE$Till like a boy, you see him cringe his face$NEWLINE$And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$By the moon and stars! Whip him! If I saw twenty of the greatest powers that pay tribute to Caesar taking such liberties with her hand—what’s her name now? This woman who once was Cleopatra, but now has become something different? Whip him, fellows, until he screws up his face like a baby and cries aloud for mercy! Take him away.

paragraphs.original: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony—
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS$NEWLINE$Mark Antony—

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                 Tug him away! Being whipped,$NEWLINE$Bring him again. This jack of Caesar’s shall$NEWLINE$Bear us an errand to him.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Pull him away, and once he has been whipped, bring him back. Caesar’s knave will bring him a message for us.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SERVANTS with THIDIAS$NEWLINE$SERVANTS$NEWLINE$THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANTS exit with THIDIAS.$NEWLINE$SERVANTS$NEWLINE$THIDIAS

paragraphs.original: (to CLEOPATRA ) You were half blasted ere I knew you. Ha!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Have I my pillow left unpressed in Rome,$NEWLINE$Forborne the getting of a lawful race,$NEWLINE$And by a gem of women, to be abused$NEWLINE$By one that looks on feeders?
paragraphs.translated: (to CLEOPATRA ) You were damaged goods before I met you. Ha! Did I desert my bed in Rome, passing up the chance to have a legitimate family with a jewel of a woman, in order to be deceived by one who wastes her favors on servants?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                         Good my lord—
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$My good lord—

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You have been a boggler ever.$NEWLINE$But when we in our viciousness grow hard—$NEWLINE$Oh, misery on ’t!—the wise gods seel our eyes,$NEWLINE$In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us$NEWLINE$Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut$NEWLINE$To our confusion.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You’ve always been a liar. But when our vices become habits—Oh, the sadness of it!—the wise gods blind us, shade our better judgment, make us love our mistakes, and laugh as we strut to our ruin.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                    Oh, is ’t come to this?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, has it come to this?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I found you as a morsel cold upon$NEWLINE$Dead Caesar’s trencher. Nay, you were a fragment$NEWLINE$Of Gneius Pompey’s, besides what hotter hours,$NEWLINE$Unregistered in vulgar fame, you have$NEWLINE$Luxuriously picked out. For I am sure,$NEWLINE$Though you can guess what temperance should be,$NEWLINE$You know not what it is.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You were a cold crumb on dead Julius Caesar’s plate when I met you. No, you were one of Gneius Pompey’s leftovers—not to mention your other, more depraved affairs, which have somehow managed to avoid becoming the subject of vulgar gossip. For I’m sure that although you may know what temperance is, you’ve never experienced it firsthand.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                Wherefore is this?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Why are you doing this?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$To let a fellow that will take rewards$NEWLINE$And say “God quit you!” be familiar with$NEWLINE$My playfellow, your hand, this kingly seal$NEWLINE$And plighter of high hearts! Oh, that I were$NEWLINE$Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar$NEWLINE$The hornèd herd! For I have savage cause,$NEWLINE$And to proclaim it civilly were like$NEWLINE$A haltered neck which does the hangman thank$NEWLINE$For being yare about him.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY$NEWLINE$To let a servant be familiar with my little toy, your hand—a hand that has signed royal treaties and pledged your love to me—oh, if only I were standing on the hill of
Basan, so that I could roar louder than that horned herd! For I have been savagely abused, and to state my grievances politely would be as absurd as a condemned criminal thanking the hangman for doing his job quickly.$NEWLINE$Basan$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVANT with THIDIAS$NEWLINE$SERVANT$NEWLINE$THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters with THIDIAS.$NEWLINE$SERVANT$NEWLINE$THIDIAS

paragraphs.original: Is he whipped?
paragraphs.translated: Has he been whipped?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Soundly, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Soundly, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Cried he? And begged he pardon?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Did he cry? Did he beg my pardon?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$He did ask favor.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$He did ask for mercy.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to THIDIAS ) If that thy father live, let him repent$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thou wast not made his daughter, and be thou sorry$NEWLINE$To follow Caesar in his triumph, since$NEWLINE$Thou hast been whipped for following him. Henceforth$NEWLINE$The white hand of a lady fever thee;$NEWLINE$Shake thou to look on ’t. Get thee back to Caesar.$NEWLINE$Tell him thy entertainment. Look thou say$NEWLINE$He makes me angry with him, for he seems$NEWLINE$Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,$NEWLINE$Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry,$NEWLINE$And at this time most easy ’tis to do ’t,$NEWLINE$When my good stars, that were my former guides,$NEWLINE$Have empty left their orbs and shot their fires$NEWLINE$Into th’ abysm of hell. If he mislike$NEWLINE$My speech and what is done, tell him he has$NEWLINE$Hipparchus, my enfranchèd bondman, whom$NEWLINE$He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture,$NEWLINE$As he shall like, to quit me. Urge it thou.$NEWLINE$Hence with thy stripes, begone!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to THIDIAS ) If your father is alive, let him be sorry you weren’t born a daughter. And you should be sorry to follow Caesar in his triumphal parade, since you have been whipped for following him. From now on, you should tremble and grow feverish whenever you see the white hand of a lady. Get yourself back to Caesar. Tell him how you’ve been treated. Be sure you tell him he makes me angry with him, because he seems proud and disdainful, harping on what I am now rather than what he knows. He makes me angry—and that’s easy to do right now, now that my lucky stars have abandoned me. If he doesn’t like what I’ve said or done, remind him that he holds Hipparchus, a slave I freed. He may whip, or hang, or torture him as he pleases. Then we will be even. Recommend that to him. Take your whipping scars and go.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$THIDIAS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit THIDIAS$NEWLINE$THIDIAS
paragraphs.translated: THIDIAS exits.$NEWLINE$THIDIAS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                               Have you done yet?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Are you done yet?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Alack, our terrene moon is now eclipsed,$NEWLINE$And it portends alone the fall of Antony.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You, my earthly moon, are now eclipsed, and that alone foretells my ruin.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(aside) I must stay his time.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(aside) I must wait for him to finish his tirade.$NEWLINE$(aside)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes$NEWLINE$With one that ties his points?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$In order to flatter Caesar, would you flirt with the servant who laces up his pants?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                         Not know me yet?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Don’t you know me still?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Coldhearted toward me?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Has your heart cooled toward me?

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                 Ah, dear, if I be so,$NEWLINE$From my cold heart let heaven engender hail,$NEWLINE$And poison it in the source, and the first stone$NEWLINE$Drop in my neck. As it determines, so$NEWLINE$Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite,$NEWLINE$Till by degrees the memory of my womb,$NEWLINE$Together with my brave Egyptians all,$NEWLINE$By the discandying of this pelleted storm$NEWLINE$Lie graveless till the flies and gnats of Nile$NEWLINE$Have buried them for prey!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Ah, dear, if that is true, let heaven make poisonous hail grow from my heart, and let the first hailstone drop down my throat. As it dissolves, so shall my life. The next hailstone should hit Caesarion, until one by one all my children, and every one of my brave Egyptians, are killed by the dissolving of this pellet storm and lie unburied, covered by gnats and flies.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                      I am satisfied.$NEWLINE$Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where$NEWLINE$I will oppose his fate. Our force by land$NEWLINE$Hath nobly held. Our severed navy too$NEWLINE$Have knit again, and fleet, threat’ning most sealike.$NEWLINE$Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady?$NEWLINE$If from the field I shall return once more$NEWLINE$To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.$NEWLINE$I and my sword will earn our chronicle.$NEWLINE$There’s hope in ’t yet.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I am satisfied. Caesar has made camp in Alexandria. I will fight him there. Our land forces have bravely stood firm. Our tattered navy has reassembled and set sail, as formidable as the sea itself. Where have you been, my bravery? Do you hear what I say, lady? If I come back from the battlefield again to kiss those lips, I’ll be covered in blood. My sword and I will earn our place in history. We still have hope.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s my brave lord!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s my brave lord!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I will be treble-sinewed, -hearted, -breathed,$NEWLINE$And fight maliciously. For when mine hours$NEWLINE$Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives$NEWLINE$Of me for jests; but now I’ll set my teeth$NEWLINE$And send to darkness all that stop me. Come,$NEWLINE$Let’s have one other gaudy night. Call to me$NEWLINE$All my sad captains. Fill our bowls once more.$NEWLINE$Let’s mock the midnight bell.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ll be triple the soldier I was in strength, bravery, and stamina. I’ll fight brutally. In the days when I had better luck, prisoners of war could buy their freedoms from me with simple trinkets. But now I’ll grit my teeth and kill anyone who tries to stop me. Come, let’s have one more extravagant night. Invite all my sad captains. Fill our wine bowls again. Let’s drink through midnight.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                           It is my birthday.$NEWLINE$I had thought t’ have held it poor; but since my lord$NEWLINE$Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$It’s my birthday. I had planned to celebrate it quietly, but since my lord is once more himself, I will be Cleopatra again.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$We will yet do well.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$We’ll win yet.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to ENOBARBUS ) Call all his noble captains to my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to ENOBARBUS ) Call all my lord’s noble captains to him.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Do so. We’ll speak to them, and tonight I’ll force$NEWLINE$The wine peep through their scars.—Come on, my Queen,$NEWLINE$There’s sap in ’t yet. The next time I do fight$NEWLINE$I’ll make Death love me, for I will contend$NEWLINE$Even with his pestilent scythe.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Do so. I’ll speak to them, and then tonight I’ll get them all so drunk that the wine seeps out of their old war wounds. Come on, my Queen. There’s still life in our cause. The next time I fight, I’ll make Death love me. I’ll compete even with his fatal scythe.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except ENOBARBUS exits.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Now he’ll outstare the lightning. To be furious$NEWLINE$Is to be frighted out of fear, and in that mood$NEWLINE$The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still$NEWLINE$A diminution in our captain’s brain$NEWLINE$Restores his heart. When valor preys on reason,$NEWLINE$It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek$NEWLINE$Some way to leave him.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Now he’ll work himself up to a fury. Rage scares away a man’s fear. In that state, a dove will attack an ostrich. I have always noticed that when my captain’s reason is diminished, his bravery increases. When courage consumes reason, it destroys its only weapon. I’ll look for some way to leave his service.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS, with his army, CAESAR reading a letter$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR enters, reading a letter, with AGRIPPA, MAECENAS, and his army.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$He calls me “boy” and chides as he had power$NEWLINE$To beat me out of Egypt. My messenger$NEWLINE$He hath whipped with rods, dares me to personal combat,$NEWLINE$Caesar to Antony. Let the old ruffian know$NEWLINE$I have many other ways to die, meantime$NEWLINE$Laugh at his challenge.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$He calls me “boy” and scolds me as if he had the power to whip me out of Egypt. He whipped my messenger with rods. He dares me to personal combat, Caesar against Antony. Let the old ruffian discover that I have many other ways to die, and in the meantime, we’ll laugh at his challenge.

paragraphs.original: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Caesar must think$NEWLINE$When one so great begins to rage, he’s hunted$NEWLINE$Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now$NEWLINE$Make boot of his distraction. Never anger$NEWLINE$Made good guard for itself.
paragraphs.translated: MAECENAS$NEWLINE$Caesar must realize that when a man as powerful as Antony begins to rage, he has been pursued to the point of collapse. Don’t give him time to catch his breath. Take advantage of his unreasonable rage. Anger does not protect the angry well.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                                      Let our best heads$NEWLINE$Know that tomorrow the last of many battles$NEWLINE$We mean to fight. Within our files there are,$NEWLINE$Of those that served Mark Antony but late,$NEWLINE$Enough to fetch him in. See it done$NEWLINE$And feast the army. We have store to do ’t,$NEWLINE$And they have earned the waste. Poor Antony!
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Tell our top commanders that I want tomorrow’s battle to be the last we fight. Our army has recently acquired many of Mark Antony’s former soldiers—enough to capture him. See that it is done, and prepare a feast for the soldiers. We have enough supplies for it, and they’ve earned it. Poor Antony!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS, with others$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS enter, with attendants.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$He will not fight with me, Domitius?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$He won’t fight with me, Domitius?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                                        No.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Why should he not?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Why won’t he?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,$NEWLINE$He is twenty men to one.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$He thinks that since his fortune is twenty times better than yours, it would be like pitting twenty men against one.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                 Tomorrow, soldier,$NEWLINE$By sea and land I’ll fight. Or I will live$NEWLINE$Or bathe my dying honor in the blood$NEWLINE$Shall make it live again. Woo’t thou fight well?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, soldier, I’ll fight by sea and land. By the end I will either live, or else I’ll restore my honor by shedding my blood. Will you fight well?

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I’ll strike and cry, “Take all.”
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$When I strike, I’ll cry, “All or nothing!”

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                          Well said. Come on!$NEWLINE$Call forth my household servants.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Well put. Come on. Call out my household servants.

paragraphs.original: Enter three or four SERVITORS$NEWLINE$SERVITORS
paragraphs.translated: Three or four SERVANTS enter.$NEWLINE$SERVANTS

paragraphs.original: Let’s tonight$NEWLINE$Be bounteous at our meal.
paragraphs.translated: Tonight let’s have plenty to eat.

paragraphs.original: Greeting them one by one
paragraphs.translated: He greets the SERVANTS one by one.$NEWLINE$SERVANTS

paragraphs.original: Give me thy hand.$NEWLINE$Thou hast been rightly honest.—So hast thou,—$NEWLINE$Thou,—and thou,—and thou. You have served me well,$NEWLINE$And kings have been your fellows.
paragraphs.translated: Give me your hand; you’ve been truly honest—so have you and you—and you—you too.$NEWLINE$You have all served me well, and kings are your peers.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(aside to ENOBARBUS ) What means this?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(aside to ENOBARBUS ) What is this?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to CLEOPATRA ) ’Tis one of those odd tricks which sorrow shoots$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Out of the mind.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to CLEOPATRA ) It’s one of those nostalgic moods caused by sorrow.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$           (to another SERVITOR ) And thou art honest too.$NEWLINE$(to another$NEWLINE$SERVITOR$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I wish I could be made so many men,$NEWLINE$And all of you clapped up together in$NEWLINE$An Antony, that I might do you service$NEWLINE$So good as you have done.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to another SERVANT ) And you’re honest too. I wish I could split into as many men as there are servants here before me, and that all of you could merge into a single Antony, so I could give you the same good service you’ve given me.$NEWLINE$(to another$NEWLINE$SERVANT$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALL THE SERVITORS$NEWLINE$                                                    The gods forbid!
paragraphs.translated: ALL THE SERVANTS$NEWLINE$The gods forbid!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.$NEWLINE$Scant not my cups, and make as much of me$NEWLINE$As when mine empire was your fellow too,$NEWLINE$And suffered my command.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight. Keep my cups full and treat me as you did when my empire was one of your fellow servants, obeying my commands.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(aside to ENOBARBUS ) What does he mean?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to ENOBARBUS ) Why is he doing this?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(aside to CLEOPATRA ) To make his followers weep.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$(to CLEOPATRA ) He wants to make his followers weep.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to the SERVITORS ) Tend me tonight.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$SERVITORS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$May be it is the period of your duty.$NEWLINE$Haply you shall not see me more, or if,$NEWLINE$A mangled shadow. Perchance tomorrow$NEWLINE$You’ll serve another master. I look on you$NEWLINE$As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends,$NEWLINE$I turn you not away, but, like a master$NEWLINE$Married to your good service, stay till death.$NEWLINE$Tend me tonight two hours, I ask no more,$NEWLINE$And the gods yield you for ’t!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(to the SERVANTS ) Wait on me tonight. It’s possible that this will be the end of your service. It’s possible you won’t see me again, or if you do, it will only be my mangled body. Perhaps tomorrow you’ll be serving another master. I look upon you as a person saying good-bye. My honest friends, I won’t turn you away, but like a master dependent on your good service, I will stay with you until death separates us. Serve me tonight for two hours—I don’t ask any more—and may the gods bless you for it.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$SERVANTS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$                                                          What mean you, sir,$NEWLINE$To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep,$NEWLINE$And I, an ass, am onion-eyed. For shame,$NEWLINE$Transform us not to women.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$What are you doing, sir? You’re making them uncomfortable. Look—they’re crying. And I’m just foolish enough to tear up myself. It’s embarrassing. Don’t turn us into women.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                         Ho, ho, ho!$NEWLINE$Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!$NEWLINE$Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends,$NEWLINE$You take me in too dolorous a sense,$NEWLINE$For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you$NEWLINE$To burn this night with torches. Know, my hearts,$NEWLINE$I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you$NEWLINE$Where rather I’ll expect victorious life$NEWLINE$Than death and honor. Let’s to supper, come,$NEWLINE$And drown consideration.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Ha, ha, ha! May the evil one take me if I meant it like that! Those tears will bring blessings to you. You interpret my words in a melancholy sense, my hearty friends. I spoke to encourage you, asking that you help me make this night a brilliant one. You should know, my friends, that I have good hopes for tomorrow, and that I will lead you as if I expect victory rather than an honorable death. Let’s go to supper. Come, and let’s drown our worries.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a company of SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: A company of SOLDIERS enters.$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Brother, good night. Tomorrow is the day.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Good night, brother. Tomorrow is the day.

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$It will determine one way. Fare you well.$NEWLINE$Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$This battle will determine who wins the war. Take care of yourself. Have you heard about anything unusual happening in the city?

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Nothing. What news?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$No. What was it?

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Belike ’tis but a rumor. Good night to you.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$It was probably just a rumor. Good night.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Well, sir, good night.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Well sir, good night.

paragraphs.original: They meet other SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: Two other SOLDIERS enter.$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Soldiers, have careful watch.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Soldiers, watch carefully.

paragraphs.original: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$And you. Good night, good night.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$You too. Good night. Good night.

paragraphs.original: The four SOLDIERS place themselves in every corner of the stage$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: Each SOLDIER takes a post at a corner of the stage.$NEWLINE$SOLDIER

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Here we. And if tomorrow$NEWLINE$Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope$NEWLINE$Our landmen will stand up.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$This is our station. And if our navy wins tomorrow, no doubt our army will do their part.

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$’Tis a brave army, and full of purpose.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$It’s an outstanding army and highly motivated.

paragraphs.original: Music of the hautboys is under the stage
paragraphs.translated: Oboe music comes from underneath the stage.

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Peace! What noise?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Quiet! What’s that sound?

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$List, list!
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Listen! Listen!

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Hark!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Listen!

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Music i’ th’ air.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$There’s music coming out of thin air.

paragraphs.original: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Under the earth.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$From under the earth.

paragraphs.original: FOURTH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$It signs well, does it not?
paragraphs.translated: FOURTH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$It’s a lucky sign, isn’t it?

paragraphs.original: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Peace, I say! What should this mean?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Quiet, I say. What does this mean?

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$’Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony loved,$NEWLINE$Now leaves him.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$It means that
