Antony’s patron god, Hercules, is leaving him.$NEWLINE$Antony’s patron god, Hercules$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Walk. Let’s see if other watchmen$NEWLINE$Do hear what we do.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Let’s walk over and see if the other soldiers heard the same thing.

paragraphs.original: They advance toward the other SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: They go to speak with the other SOLDIERS.$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$How now, masters?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Hello there, good sirs.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$(speak together) How now? How now? Do you hear this?$NEWLINE$(speak together)
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$(speaking at the same time) What now? What now? Do you hear that?$NEWLINE$(speaking at the same time)

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Ay. Is ’t not strange?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Yes. Isn’t it strange?

paragraphs.original: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Do you hear, masters? Do you hear?
paragraphs.translated: THIRD SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Do you hear that, men? Do you?

paragraphs.original: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Follow the noise so far as we have quarter;$NEWLINE$Let’s see how it will give off.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Let’s follow the music as far as we can without leaving our station and see if it stops.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$                                                       Content. ’Tis strange.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Good idea. It’s very strange.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, with CHARMIAN and others attending$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and CLEOPATRA enter with CHARMIAN and others of the court.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(calling) Eros! Mine armor, Eros!$NEWLINE$(calling)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$(calling) Eros! Bring my armor, Eros.$NEWLINE$(calling)

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                                 Sleep a little.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Get a little sleep.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, my chuck.—Eros, come, mine armor, Eros!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, my dear . . . Eros, come on, bring my armor, Eros.

paragraphs.original: Enter EROS with armor$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: EROS enters, carrying ANTONY’s armor.$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.$NEWLINE$If fortune be not ours today, it is$NEWLINE$Because we brave her. Come.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, good fellow, help me into that armor you’re carrying. If luck deserts us today, it’s because we defy it. Come on.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                          Nay, I’ll help too.$NEWLINE$What’s this for?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No, I’ll help too. What’s this part for?

paragraphs.original: She helps to arm him
paragraphs.translated: She picks up a piece of the armor.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                   Ah, let be, let be! Thou art$NEWLINE$The armorer of my heart. False, false. This, this.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Ah, leave it alone. Leave it alone! You armor my heart. No! No! That part goes there.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Sooth, la, I’ll help. Thus it must be.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Really, I’ll help. It must go like this.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                      Well, well,$NEWLINE$We shall thrive now.—Seest thou, my good fellow?$NEWLINE$Go put on thy defenses.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Yes, well done. We’ve got it now.—Do you see this, my good fellow? Go and put on your own armor.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                               Briefly, sir.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$In a minute, sir.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Is not this buckled well?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Didn’t I buckle this well?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                              Rarely, rarely.$NEWLINE$He that unbuckles this, till we do please$NEWLINE$To doff ’t for our repose, shall hear a storm.—$NEWLINE$Thou fumblest, Eros, and my Queen’s a squire$NEWLINE$More tight at this than thou. Dispatch.—O love,$NEWLINE$That thou couldst see my wars today, and knew’st$NEWLINE$The royal occupation! Thou shouldst see$NEWLINE$A workman in ’t.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Excellently, excellently. Anyone who unbuckles this before I want to take it off to rest will be sorry.—You’re fumbling, Eros. My Queen’s a better squire than you are. Hurry.—Oh, love, if you could only watch the battle today and see how expert I am at my craft.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter an armed SOLDIER$NEWLINE$SOLDIER
paragraphs.translated: An armed SOLDIER enters.$NEWLINE$SOLDIER

paragraphs.original: Good morrow to thee. Welcome.$NEWLINE$Thou look’st like him that knows a warlike charge.$NEWLINE$To business that we love we rise betimes$NEWLINE$And go to ’t with delight.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning to you. Welcome. You look like a person who knows the business of war. When we love our job we get up early and go to it joyfully.

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$                                                  A thousand, sir,$NEWLINE$Early though ’t be, have on their riveted trim$NEWLINE$And at the port expect you.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Even though it’s early, there are already a thousand armored soldiers waiting for you at the harbor.

paragraphs.original: Shout. Trumpets flourish
paragraphs.translated: A shout is heard, then a trumpet fanfare.

paragraphs.original: Enter CAPTAINS and SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$CAPTAINS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAINS and SOLDIERS enter.$NEWLINE$CAPTAINS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$The morn is fair. Good morrow, General.
paragraphs.translated: CAPTAIN$NEWLINE$The weather is fair. Good morning, General.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Good morrow, General.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Good morning, General.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                ’Tis well blown, lads.$NEWLINE$This morning, like the spirit of a youth$NEWLINE$That means to be of note, begins betimes.$NEWLINE$So, so. (to CLEOPATRA ) Come, give me that. This way. Well said.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Fare thee well, dame.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$That was a fine fanfare, boys. Like a young man who wants to amount to something, this morning begins early. (to CLEOPATRA ) So, so. Here, give me that. This is how it goes on. Well done.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Farewell, lady.

paragraphs.original: He kisses her
paragraphs.translated: He kisses her.

paragraphs.original: Whate’er becomes of me,$NEWLINE$This is a soldier’s kiss. Rebukable$NEWLINE$And worthy shameful check it were to stand$NEWLINE$On more mechanic compliment. I’ll leave thee$NEWLINE$Now like a man of steel. (to others) You that will fight,$NEWLINE$(to others)$NEWLINE$Follow me close. I’ll bring you to ’t. (to CLEOPATRA ) Adieu.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: Whatever happens to me, this is a soldier’s kiss. It would be shameful to draw out our good-byes. I’ll leave you without revealing any emotion, like a man of steel. (to the others) Anyone who wants to fight, follow me now, and I’ll see you get your wish. (to CLEOPATRA ) Good-bye.$NEWLINE$(to the others)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ANTONY, EROS, CAPTAINS, and SOLDIERS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$CAPTAINS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and EROS exit with the CAPTAINS and SOLDIERS.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$CAPTAINS$NEWLINE$SOLDIERS

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Please you retire to your chamber?
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$If it pleases you, let’s go to your room.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                                     Lead me.$NEWLINE$He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might$NEWLINE$Determine this great war in single fight!$NEWLINE$Then Antony—but now—. Well, on.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Lead the way. He goes forth to war bravely. If only he and Caesar could determine the outcome of this war by single combat! Then Antony would—but, with circumstances as they are—well, let’s go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Trumpets sound. Enter ANTONY and EROS, and a SOLDIER meeting them$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$SOLDIER
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound. ANTONY and EROS enter and are met by a SOLDIER entering from another direction.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$SOLDIER

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$The gods make this a happy day to Antony!
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$May the gods bless Antony today!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed$NEWLINE$To make me fight at land!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I wish you and your scarred self had convinced me to wage our last battle on land.

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$                                                   Hadst thou done so,$NEWLINE$The kings that have revolted, and the soldier$NEWLINE$That has this morning left thee, would have still$NEWLINE$Followed thy heels.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$If you had, the kings that have revolted and the soldier that deserted this morning would still be behind you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                      Who’s gone this morning?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Who deserted this morning?

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$                                                                                          Who?$NEWLINE$One ever near thee. Call for Enobarbus$NEWLINE$He shall not hear thee, or from Caesar’s camp$NEWLINE$Say “I am none of thine.”
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$You don’t know? Someone who was always near you. If you call for Enobarbus, he won’t hear you. Or if he can hear you from Caesar’s camp, he’ll reply, “I’m no longer on your side.”

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                   What sayest thou?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What are you saying?

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$                                                                                        Sir,$NEWLINE$He is with Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Sir, he’s with Caesar.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                     Sir, his chests and treasure$NEWLINE$He has not with him.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Sir, he left his belongings and treasure.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                          Is he gone?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$He’s gone?

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$                                                                 Most certain.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$It’s certain.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Go, Eros, send his treasure after. Do it.$NEWLINE$Detain no jot, I charge thee. Write to him—$NEWLINE$I will subscribe—gentle adieus and greetings.$NEWLINE$Say that I wish he never find more cause$NEWLINE$To change a master. Oh, my fortunes have$NEWLINE$Corrupted honest men! Dispatch.—Enobarbus!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Eros, send his treasure to him. Do it now. Don’t keep anything back, I insist. Write to him from me—I’ll sign it—sending greetings and gentle good-byes. Say that I hope he never has cause to look for a new master. Oh, my bad luck has forced honest men to become traitors. Hurry. Enobarbus!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter AGRIPPA, and CAESAR, with ENOBARBUS and DOLABELLA$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$DOLABELLA
paragraphs.translated: Trumpet fanfare. AGRIPPA and CAESAR enter with ENOBARBUS and DOLABELLA.$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$DOLABELLA

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.$NEWLINE$Our will is Antony be took alive.$NEWLINE$Make it so known.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Agrippa, go start the battle. We want Antony taken alive. Make sure everyone knows that.

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Caesar, I shall.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$I will, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$The time of universal peace is near.$NEWLINE$Prove this a prosp’rous day, the three-nooked world$NEWLINE$Shall bear the olive freely.
paragraphs.translated:
CAESAR$NEWLINE$An era of universal peace is about to start. If this battle goes well for us, there will be peace in all
three corners of the world.$NEWLINE$three corners of the world$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$                                                    Antony$NEWLINE$Is come into the field.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Antony has come onto the battlefield.

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$                                           Go charge Agrippa$NEWLINE$Plant those that have revolted in the vant,$NEWLINE$That Antony may seem to spend his fury$NEWLINE$Upon himself.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Go order Agrippa to put the men who deserted Antony’s army at the front. That way Antony will feel like he’s fighting his own men.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except ENOBARBUS.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Alexas did revolt and went to Jewry on$NEWLINE$Affairs of Antony, there did dissuade$NEWLINE$Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar$NEWLINE$And leave his master Antony. For this pains$NEWLINE$Caesar hath hanged him. Canidius and the rest$NEWLINE$That fell away have entertainment but$NEWLINE$No honorable trust. I have done ill,$NEWLINE$Of which I do accuse myself so sorely$NEWLINE$That I will joy no more.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Alexas deserted. He went to Judea as if on Antony’s business, but he persuaded Herod to support Caesar instead. Caesar hanged him for this service. Canidius and the others that left Antony are given hospitality here but no positions of trust. I’ve done a bad thing, for which I will blame myself so much that I’ll never be happy again.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a SOLDIER of Caesar’s$NEWLINE$SOLDIER
paragraphs.translated: A SOLDIER of Caesar’s enters.$NEWLINE$SOLDIER

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$                                                Enobarbus, Antony$NEWLINE$Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with$NEWLINE$His bounty overplus. The messenger$NEWLINE$Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now$NEWLINE$Unloading of his mules.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Enobarbus, Antony has sent you all your treasure, with generous gifts besides. The messenger arrived on my watch and is unloading his mules at your tent.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I give it you.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$It’s yours.

paragraphs.original: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Mock not, Enobarbus.$NEWLINE$I tell you true. Best you safed the bringer$NEWLINE$Out of the host. I must attend mine office,$NEWLINE$Or would have done ’t myself. Your Emperor$NEWLINE$Continues still a Jove.
paragraphs.translated: SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Don’t joke about this, Enobarbus. I’m telling you the truth. You’d better bring the messenger safely through the lines so he can return. I’d do it myself, but I can’t leave my post. Your Emperor is still a king among gods.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I am alone the villain of the earth,$NEWLINE$And feel I am so most. O Antony,$NEWLINE$Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid$NEWLINE$My better service, when my turpitude$NEWLINE$Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart.$NEWLINE$If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean$NEWLINE$Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do ’t, I feel.$NEWLINE$I fight against thee? No, I will go seek$NEWLINE$Some ditch wherein to die. The foul’st best fits$NEWLINE$My latter part of life.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$I am the worst person alive, and I know it the best. Oh, Antony, you extravagantly generous man, how would you have rewarded me for serving you faithfully when you reward my badness with all of this gold! My heart feels like it’s about to explode. If grief doesn’t kill me, I’ll find a quicker way to kill myself—even though I think grief will do the job just as well. I, fight against you, Antony? No, I’ll go find some ditch to die in. The foulest fate would be most appropriate for me now in this latest phase of my life.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Drums and trumpets. Enter AGRIPPA and others$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA
paragraphs.translated: A call to battle is sounded. Drums and trumpets sound. AGRIPPA and other soldiers of Caesar’s enter.$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA

paragraphs.original: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Retire! We have engaged ourselves too far.$NEWLINE$Caesar himself has work, and our oppression$NEWLINE$Exceeds what we expected.
paragraphs.translated: AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$Retreat! We’ve advanced too far. Caesar himself is in trouble and there are more adversaries than we expected.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Alarums. Enter ANTONY, and SCARUS, wounded$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: A battle call. ANTONY enters with SCARUS, who is wounded.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!$NEWLINE$Had we done so at first, we had droven them home$NEWLINE$With clouts about their heads.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$Oh, my brave Emperor, this is what I call a fight! If we’d fought like this before, we’d have driven them home with bandaged heads.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                             Thou bleed’st apace.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You’re bleeding a lot.

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$I had a wound here that was like a “T,”$NEWLINE$But now ’tis made an “H.”
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$I had a scar here that looked like a “T”; now it’s an “H.”

paragraphs.original: Sound retreat far off
paragraphs.translated: Distant trumpets sound the retreat.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                       They do retire.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$They’re retreating.

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$We’ll beat ’em into bench-holes. I have yet$NEWLINE$Room for six scotches more.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$We’ll chase ’em into their latrines. I still have room for six more wounds.

paragraphs.original: Enter EROS$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: EROS enters.$NEWLINE$EROS

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves$NEWLINE$For a fair victory.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$They’re retreating, sir, and our superiority indicates a clear victory.

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$                                   Let us score their backs$NEWLINE$And snatch ’em up, as we take hares, behind!$NEWLINE$’Tis sport to maul a runner.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$Let’s slash their backs and grab ’em like we do rabbits, from behind. It’s fair game to mark a coward.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                       I will reward thee$NEWLINE$Once for thy sprightly comfort and tenfold$NEWLINE$For thy good valor. Come thee on.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ll reward you once for your cheerfulness and ten times for your courage. Come on.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$                                                                   I’ll halt after.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$I’ll limp after you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter ANTONY again in a march; SCARUS, with others$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: A battle call. ANTONY marches in, followed by SCARUS and others.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$We have beat him to his camp. Run one before$NEWLINE$And let the Queen know of our gests.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$We’ve driven him all the way back to his camp. One of you run to the Queen with the news.

paragraphs.original: Exit a soldier
paragraphs.translated: A soldier exits.

paragraphs.original: Tomorrow,$NEWLINE$Before the sun shall see ’s, we’ll spill the blood$NEWLINE$That has today escaped. I thank you all,$NEWLINE$For doughty-handed are you, and have fought$NEWLINE$Not as you served the cause, but as ’t had been$NEWLINE$Each man’s like mine. You have shown all Hectors.$NEWLINE$Enter the city. Clip your wives, your friends.$NEWLINE$Tell them your feats, whilst they with joyful tears$NEWLINE$Wash the congealment from your wounds and kiss$NEWLINE$The honored gashes whole.
paragraphs.translated:
Before sunrise tomorrow, we’ll kill anyone who escaped today. I want to thank all of you. You’re formidable. You fought not as if you served the cause but as though it were as much your personal fight as mine. You are all
Hectors. Go on into the city. Embrace your wives and your friends. Describe your feats for them while they cry for joy. Their tears will wash the congealed blood from your wounds, and they will kiss those honorable cuts until they heal.$NEWLINE$Hectors$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA enters.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: (to SCARUS )                Give me thy hand.$NEWLINE$            (to$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$)                $NEWLINE$To this great fairy I’ll commend thy acts,$NEWLINE$Make her thanks bless thee. O thou day o’ the world,$NEWLINE$(to CLEOPATRA ) Chain mine armed neck. Leap thou, attire and all,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Through proof of harness to my heart, and there$NEWLINE$Ride on the pants triumphing!
paragraphs.translated: (to SCARUS ) Give me your hand. I’ll praise your actions to this powerful enchantress so that she will thank you with blessings. Oh, light of the world, (to CLEOPATRA ) wrap your arms around my armored neck. Leap, with all your finery through my armor and go straight to my heart. There you can ride upon my heartbeats, sharing in my triumph.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                            Lord of lords!$NEWLINE$O infinite virtue, com’st thou smiling from$NEWLINE$The world’s great snare uncaught?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Lord of lords! Your courage is infinite. Have you returned smiling from the great battle for the world?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                   Mine nightingale,$NEWLINE$We have beat them to their beds. What, girl, though gray$NEWLINE$Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha’ we$NEWLINE$A brain that nourishes our nerves and can$NEWLINE$Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man.$NEWLINE$Commend unto his lips thy favoring hand.$NEWLINE$(to SCARUS ) Kiss it, my warrior.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$My songbird, we have beaten them to their beds. What do you think, girl!$NEWLINE$Even though there are some gray hairs among the brown, I still have a brain and muscles that will let me compete with younger men. Look at this man. Show him favor by letting him kiss your hand. (to SCARUS ) Kiss it, my warrior.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SCARUS kisses CLEOPATRA’s hand$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS kisses CLEOPATRA’s hand$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: He hath fought today$NEWLINE$As if a god, in hate of mankind, had$NEWLINE$Destroyed in such a shape.
paragraphs.translated: Today he fought as though he were a god who hated mankind.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$            (to SCARUS )              I’ll give thee, friend,$NEWLINE$            (to$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$)              $NEWLINE$An armor all of gold. It was a king’s.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$(to SCARUS ) Friend, I’ll give you armor made of gold. It belonged to a king.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$SCARUS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$He has deserved it, were it carbuncled$NEWLINE$Like holy Phoebus’ car. Give me thy hand.$NEWLINE$Through Alexandria make a jolly march.$NEWLINE$Bear our hacked targets like the men that owe them.$NEWLINE$Had our great palace the capacity$NEWLINE$To camp this host, we all would sup together$NEWLINE$And drink carouses to the next day’s fate,$NEWLINE$Which promises royal peril.—Trumpeters,$NEWLINE$With brazen din blast you the city’s ear;$NEWLINE$Make mingle with our rattling taborins,$NEWLINE$That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together,$NEWLINE$Applauding our approach.
paragraphs.translated:
ANTONY$NEWLINE$He deserves it, even if it were covered with jewels like holy
Phoebus’ car. Give me your hand. Let’s have a cheerful march through Alexandria, proudly carrying our dented shields. If we had enough room in the palace to house this army, we’d all eat together and toast tomorrow, which promises to be full of danger. Trumpeters, blast the city’s ears. Mix your fanfares with our drums, so that sounds from both heaven and earth will herald our approach.$NEWLINE$Phoebus’ car$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a SENTRY and his company. ENOBARBUS follows$NEWLINE$SENTRY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS
paragraphs.translated: A SENTRY and his company enter, followed by ENOBARBUS.$NEWLINE$SENTRY$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: SENTRY$NEWLINE$If we be not relieved within this hour,$NEWLINE$We must return to th’ court of guard. The night$NEWLINE$Is shiny, and they say we shall embattle$NEWLINE$By th’ second hour i’ th’ morn.
paragraphs.translated: SENTRY$NEWLINE$If we aren’t relieved in an hour, we have to return to our barracks. The night is bright, and they say we’ll be forming for battle by two a.m.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$This last day was a shrewd one to ’s.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$That last day was a hard one for us.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$O bear me witness, night—
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Oh, listen to me, night—

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$What man is this?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Who is this?

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Stand close and list him.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Stay hidden and listen.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Be witness to me, O thou blessèd moon,$NEWLINE$When men revolted shall upon record$NEWLINE$Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did$NEWLINE$Before thy face repent.
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Be my witness, oh you blessed moon. The men who revolted against Antony will be remembered scornfully in the history books. But poor Enobarbus repented.

paragraphs.original: SENTRY$NEWLINE$Enobarbus?
paragraphs.translated: SENTRY$NEWLINE$That’s Enobarbus?

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Peace! Hark further.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Quiet! Keep listening.

paragraphs.original: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$O sovereign mistress of true melancholy,$NEWLINE$The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me,$NEWLINE$That life, a very rebel to my will,$NEWLINE$May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart$NEWLINE$Against the flint and hardness of my fault,$NEWLINE$Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder$NEWLINE$And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony,$NEWLINE$Nobler than my revolt is infamous,$NEWLINE$Forgive me in thine own particular,$NEWLINE$But let the world rank me in register$NEWLINE$A master-leaver and a fugitive.$NEWLINE$O Antony! O Antony!
paragraphs.translated: ENOBARBUS$NEWLINE$Oh, moon, you queen of sadness, drop poisonous dew on me so that my life, which continues against my wishes, will end. Take my heart and throw it against my hard, stony sin. My heart, which dried out with grief, will surely break apart into a powder, and that will be the end of my disgusting mind. Oh, Antony! You are more noble than my revolt is dishonorable. Forgive my crimes against you, but let history record me as a fugitive traitor. Oh, Antony! Oh, Antony!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: He dies
paragraphs.translated: He dies.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Let’s speak to him.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Let’s speak to him.

paragraphs.original: SENTRY$NEWLINE$Let’s hear him, for the things he speaks may concern Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: SENTRY$NEWLINE$Let’s listen to him. He may say something concerning Caesar.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Let’s do so. But he sleeps.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Good idea. But he’s sleeping.

paragraphs.original: SENTRY$NEWLINE$Swoons rather, for so bad a prayer as his$NEWLINE$Was never yet for sleep.
paragraphs.translated: SENTRY$NEWLINE$It looks more like he fainted. No one ever gave a prayer like that before going to sleep.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Go we to him.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Let’s go to him.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Awake, sir, awake. Speak to us.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Wake up, sir, wake up. Speak to us.

paragraphs.original: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Hear you, sir?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST WATCH$NEWLINE$Do you hear us, sir?

paragraphs.original: SENTRY$NEWLINE$The hand of death hath raught him.
paragraphs.translated: SENTRY$NEWLINE$The hand of death has taken him.

paragraphs.original: Drums afar off
paragraphs.translated: Drums are heard in the distance.

paragraphs.original: Hark, the drums$NEWLINE$Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him$NEWLINE$To th’ court of guard. He is of note. Our hour$NEWLINE$Is fully out.
paragraphs.translated: Listen. The drums softly wake the sleepers. Let’s carry him to the barracks. He’s an important person. Our hour is up.

paragraphs.original: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Come on, then. He may recover yet.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND WATCH$NEWLINE$Come on, then. He may recover yet.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt with the body
paragraphs.translated: They exit, carrying ENOBARBUS’s body.$NEWLINE$ENOBARBUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and SCARUS, with their army$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and SCARUS enter, with the army.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Their preparation is today by sea.$NEWLINE$We please them not by land.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$They’ve switched their operation to the sea today. We didn’t please them on land.

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$                                                         For both, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$We’re ready for both, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I would they’d fight i’ th’ fire or i’ th’ air,$NEWLINE$We’d fight there too. But this it is: our foot$NEWLINE$Upon the hills adjoining to the city$NEWLINE$Shall stay with us. Order for sea is given;$NEWLINE$They have put forth the haven,$NEWLINE$Where their appointment we may best discover$NEWLINE$And look on their endeavor.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I wish they’d fight in fire or in the air. We’d meet them there too. But here’s the plan: our army will stay with us on the hills by the city. Orders have been given to the navy and they’ve left port. We’ll be able to analyze and direct the battle better from the hills.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR and his army$NEWLINE$CAESAR
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR and his army enter.$NEWLINE$CAESAR

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$But being charged, we will be still by land—$NEWLINE$Which, as I take ’t, we shall, for his best force$NEWLINE$Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales,$NEWLINE$And hold our best advantage.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$We won’t move our land forces unless we’re attacked. And I doubt that will happen, since most of Antony’s men are with his navy. Let’s take up the best positions we can in the valleys.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and SCARUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and SCARUS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$SCARUS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Yet they are not joined. Where yond pine does stand$NEWLINE$I shall discover all. I’ll bring thee word$NEWLINE$Straight how ’tis like to go.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$They still haven’t joined the battle. I’ll be able to see better from that pine tree over there. I’ll let you know right away how it’s going.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Alarum afar off, as at a sea fight
paragraphs.translated: Noises like a sea battle are heard in the distance.

paragraphs.original: SCARUS$NEWLINE$                                                       Swallows have built$NEWLINE$In Cleopatra’s sails their nests. The auguries$NEWLINE$Say they know not, they cannot tell, look grimly,$NEWLINE$And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony$NEWLINE$Is valiant and dejected, and by starts$NEWLINE$His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear$NEWLINE$Of what he has and has not.
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS$NEWLINE$Swallows have built nests in Cleopatra’s sails. The fortunetellers won’t say whether that’s a good sign or a bad one, but they don’t look happy. Antony is valiant and dejected. His mood changes by fits and starts; his checkered luck vacillates between hope and fear, winning and losing.

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                        All is lost!$NEWLINE$This foul Egyptian hath betrayèd me.$NEWLINE$My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder$NEWLINE$They cast their caps up and carouse together$NEWLINE$Like friends long lost. Triple-turned whore! ’Tis thou$NEWLINE$Hast sold me to this novice, and my heart$NEWLINE$Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly,$NEWLINE$For when I am revenged upon my charm,$NEWLINE$I have done all. Bid them all fly. Begone!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$All is lost! This treacherous Egyptian has betrayed me. My fleet has surrendered to the enemy. You can see them over there throwing their hats up in the air and drinking together like long lost friends. Three-time traitor and whore! It’s you who have sold me to this youth, Caesar. Now my war is only with you. Tell the army to flee. Revenge on Cleopatra will be my last act. Order them to escape. Go!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit SCARUS$NEWLINE$SCARUS
paragraphs.translated: SCARUS exits.$NEWLINE$SCARUS

paragraphs.original: O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more.$NEWLINE$Fortune and Antony part here. Even here$NEWLINE$Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts$NEWLINE$That spanieled me at heels, to whom I gave$NEWLINE$Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets$NEWLINE$On blossoming Caesar, and this pine is barked$NEWLINE$That overtopped them all. Betrayed I am.$NEWLINE$Oh, this false soul of Egypt! This grave charm,$NEWLINE$Whose eye becked forth my wars and called them home,$NEWLINE$Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end,$NEWLINE$Like a right gypsy hath at fast and loose$NEWLINE$Beguiled me to the very heart of loss.$NEWLINE$(calling out) What, Eros, Eros!$NEWLINE$(calling out)
paragraphs.translated: Oh, sun, I will never see another one of your sunrises. Luck and Antony separate here and now. Here we’ll shake hands good-bye. Is it all come to this? The brave men who followed me like little dogs, whom I rewarded, have left me to follow Caesar. I’ve been stripped of everything, betrayed. Oh, that devious Egyptian spirit! Her charms launched my wars and called them back again. Pleasing her was my main goal, and she lured me to total defeat. (calling out) Where are you, Eros! Eros!$NEWLINE$(calling out)

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA enters.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!
paragraphs.translated: Ah, you sorceress! Be gone!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Why is my lord enraged against his love?
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Why is my lord enraged against his love?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving,$NEWLINE$And blemish Caesar’s triumph. Let him take thee$NEWLINE$And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!$NEWLINE$Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot$NEWLINE$Of all thy sex. Most monsterlike be shown$NEWLINE$For poor’st diminutives, for dolts, and let$NEWLINE$Patient Octavia plow thy visage up$NEWLINE$With her preparèd nails!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Get out of my sight, or I’ll give you what you deserve and spoil Caesar’s victory. Let him hoist you up in front of the shouting crowds! Follow his chariot, like the greatest disgrace to your whole gender. Let them exhibit you to the public for meager coins, like a monstrosity. Then let Octavia dig up your face with her nails.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA exits.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: ’Tis well th’art gone,$NEWLINE$If it be well to live, but better ’twere$NEWLINE$Thou fell’st into my fury, for one death$NEWLINE$Might have prevented many.—Eros, ho!—$NEWLINE$The shirt of Nessus is upon me. Teach me,$NEWLINE$Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage.$NEWLINE$Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o’ th’ moon,$NEWLINE$And with those hands that grasped the heaviest club$NEWLINE$Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die.$NEWLINE$To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall$NEWLINE$Under this plot. She dies for ’t.—Eros, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
If you wish to live, you had better get out of here. But I think it would have been better if you’d let me kill you. One death would have prevented the deaths of many others.—Eros, ho!—
I’m wearing the shirt of Nessus. Hercules, my ancestor, teach me how to feel your rage. I’ll toss Lichas to the moon and use my mighty hands to kill my better self. The witch shall die.$NEWLINE$I’m wearing the shirt of Nessus.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$She sold me to that young Roman boy and now I’m ruined. She’ll die for it.—Eros, ho!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN enter.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS$NEWLINE$MARDIAN

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Help me, my women! Oh, he’s more mad$NEWLINE$Than Telamon for his shield. The boar of Thessaly$NEWLINE$Was never so embossed.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Help me, ladies! Oh, Antony is more furious than Telamon, who killed himself in a jealous rage. The wild boar of Thessaly, which the goddess Diana sent to punish King Caledon for neglecting her sacrifices, didn’t foam at the mouth as much as Antony does now.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                To th’ monument!$NEWLINE$There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.$NEWLINE$The soul and body rive not more in parting$NEWLINE$Than greatness going off.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Go to your tomb! Lock yourself in and send him word that you’re dead. When a great person departs, it causes more pain than when the soul leaves the body.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                 To th’ monument!—$NEWLINE$Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself.$NEWLINE$Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,”$NEWLINE$And word it, prithee, piteously. Hence, Mardian,$NEWLINE$And bring me how he takes my death. (to the others) To th’ monument!$NEWLINE$(to the others)
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$To my tomb! Mardian, go tell him I’ve killed myself. Say the last word I spoke was “Antony,” and please word it pathetically. Go, Mardian, and let me know how he reacts to my death. (to the others) To the tomb!$NEWLINE$(to the others)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONY and EROS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY and EROS enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Eros, thou yet behold’st me?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Eros, can you still see me?

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                                        Ay, noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Yes, noble lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Sometimes we see a cloud that’s dragonish,$NEWLINE$A vapor sometime like a bear or lion,$NEWLINE$A towered citadel, a pendant rock,$NEWLINE$A forkèd mountain, or blue promontory$NEWLINE$With trees upon ’t that nod unto the world$NEWLINE$And mock our eyes with air. Thou hast seen these signs.$NEWLINE$They are black vesper’s pageants.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Sometimes we see a cloud that looks like a dragon. Sometimes there’s a cloud like a bear or a lion, a castle, a floating rock, a craggy mountain. Or it might look like a blue cliff with trees on it that bow to the ground. These things fool our eyes by seeming solid, when they are actually only air. You’ve seen these illusions. They’re spectacles that appear at sunset.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                                                  Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$That which is now a horse, even with a thought$NEWLINE$The rack dislimns and makes it indistinct$NEWLINE$As water is in water.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$What looks like a horse is quick as thought disfigured by the wind, made as difficult to distinguish as water poured into water.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                         It does, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$That’s true, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$My good knave Eros, now thy captain is$NEWLINE$Even such a body. Here I am Antony,$NEWLINE$Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.$NEWLINE$I made these wars for Egypt, and the Queen,$NEWLINE$Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine—$NEWLINE$Which whilst it was mine had annexed unto ’t$NEWLINE$A million more, now lost—she, Eros, has$NEWLINE$Packed cards with Caesar and false-played my glory$NEWLINE$Unto an enemy’s triumph.$NEWLINE$Nay, weep not, gentle Eros. There is left us$NEWLINE$Ourselves to end ourselves.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Eros, my young friend, your captain is now just like that cloud. Here and now I seem like Antony, but I can’t keep myself in this form, my boy. I went to war to save Cleopatra, whose love I thought I had, since she had mine—and mine carried with it a million others, those of my soldiers, now lost. The Queen conspired with Caesar to undermine my success and assure his victory. No, don’t cry, kind Eros. We still have the option of killing ourselves.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter MARDIAN$NEWLINE$MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN enters.$NEWLINE$MARDIAN

paragraphs.original: Oh, thy vile lady!$NEWLINE$She has robbed me of my sword.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, your contemptible lady! She has disarmed me.

paragraphs.original: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$                                                               No, Antony,$NEWLINE$My mistress loved thee, and her fortunes mingled$NEWLINE$With thine entirely.
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$No, Antony. My mistress loved you, and her destiny was completely joined with yours.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                       Hence, saucy eunuch! Peace!$NEWLINE$She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Get out, insolent eunuch! Silence! She has betrayed me and shall die.

paragraphs.original: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$Death of one person can be paid but once,$NEWLINE$And that she has discharged. What thou wouldst do$NEWLINE$Is done unto thy hand. The last she spake$NEWLINE$Was “Antony, most noble Antony!”$NEWLINE$Then in the midst a tearing groan did break$NEWLINE$The name of Antony. It was divided$NEWLINE$Between her heart and lips. She rendered life,$NEWLINE$Thy name so buried in her.
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$A person can only pay with their life once, and she has paid in full. What you wanted is yours. Her last words were “Antony! Most noble Antony!” Then, as she was speaking your name, a strangled groan split her words. “Antony” was divided between her heart and lips. She gave up her life with your name still within her.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                      Dead, then?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Is she dead, then?

paragraphs.original: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$                                                                              Dead.
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN$NEWLINE$Dead.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Unarm, Eros. The long day’s task is done,$NEWLINE$And we must sleep. (to MARDIAN ) That thou depart’st hence safe$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MARDIAN$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Does pay thy labor richly. Go.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Remove your armor, Eros. The long day’s work is over, and it is time to sleep. (to MARDIAN ) Permission to leave unharmed is abundant payment for your news. Go!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$MARDIAN$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit MARDIAN$NEWLINE$MARDIAN
paragraphs.translated: MARDIAN exits.$NEWLINE$MARDIAN

paragraphs.original: Off, pluck off!$NEWLINE$The sevenfold shield of Ajax cannot keep$NEWLINE$The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!$NEWLINE$Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.$NEWLINE$Crack thy frail case!—Apace, Eros, apace.$NEWLINE$No more a soldier. Bruisèd pieces, go.$NEWLINE$You have been nobly borne. (to EROS ) From me awhile.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: Off! Take off my armor. Not even Ajax’s famous shield, made of seven layers of oxhide and covered in bronze, could protect my heart from this attack. Oh, chest, obey me! Heart, for once be stronger than all the rest of the body combined. Break out of my ribcage! Faster, Eros, faster. I won’t be a soldier anymore. Battered armor, be off. You were worn with honor. (to EROS ) Leave me awhile.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$EROS$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit EROS$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: EROS exits.$NEWLINE$EROS

paragraphs.original: I will o’ertake thee, Cleopatra, and$NEWLINE$Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now$NEWLINE$All length is torture. Since the torch is out,$NEWLINE$Lie down and stray no farther. Now all labor$NEWLINE$Mars what it does. Yea, very force entangles$NEWLINE$Itself with strength. Seal then, and all is done.—$NEWLINE$Eros!—I come, my Queen.—Eros!—Stay for me.$NEWLINE$Where souls do couch on flowers, we’ll hand in hand,$NEWLINE$And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.$NEWLINE$Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops,$NEWLINE$And all the haunt be ours.—Come, Eros, Eros!
paragraphs.translated: I will catch up with you, Cleopatra, and weep for your forgiveness. It’s the only way left, because now any extension of my life would be torture. Since the light of my life has gone out, I’ll stop here. Now any effort ruins what it attempts. Yes, even power gets in its own way. End it, then, and everything is over.—Eros!—I’m coming, my Queen!—Eros!—Wait for me. In the place where souls recline on beds of flowers we’ll walk hand in hand and amaze the other ghosts with our spirited demeanor. Those famous lovers, Dido and Aeneas, will lose their admirers, and the whole place will be devoted to us.—Come, Eros. Eros!

paragraphs.original: Enter EROS$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: EROS enters.$NEWLINE$EROS

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$What would my lord?
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$What can I do for my lord?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                           Since Cleopatra died$NEWLINE$I have lived in such dishonor that the gods$NEWLINE$Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword$NEWLINE$Quartered the world, and o’er green Neptune’s back$NEWLINE$With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack$NEWLINE$The courage of a woman—less noble mind$NEWLINE$Than she which by her death our Caesar tells$NEWLINE$“I am conqueror of myself.” Thou art sworn, Eros,$NEWLINE$That when the exigent should come which now$NEWLINE$Is come indeed, when I should see behind me$NEWLINE$Th’ inevitable prosecution of$NEWLINE$Disgrace and horror, that on my command,$NEWLINE$Thou then wouldst kill me. Do ’t. The time is come.$NEWLINE$Thou strik’st not me, ’tis Caesar thou defeat’st.$NEWLINE$Put color in thy cheek.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Since Cleopatra died, I have lived in such dishonor that the gods despise my disgrace. Though I have made conquests throughout the four corners of the world and sailed with fleets so large they looked like floating cities, I don’t have as much courage as a woman. I have less nobility than the lady who, by killing herself, says to Caesar, “Only Cleopatra can defeat Cleopatra.” You promised me, Eros, that should the ultimate moment arrive—which it has—when dishonor and disgust are inevitable, that upon my command, you would kill me. Do it. This is that time. You won’t be striking me down, but defeating Caesar. Call up your courage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                              The gods withhold me!$NEWLINE$Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,$NEWLINE$Though enemy, lost aim and could not?
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$The gods forbid! Can I do what all the Parthian arrows, though shot by enemies, could not?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                              Eros,$NEWLINE$Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see$NEWLINE$Thy master thus with pleached arms, bending down$NEWLINE$His corrigible neck, his face subdued$NEWLINE$To penetrative shame, whilst the wheeled seat$NEWLINE$Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded$NEWLINE$His baseness that ensued?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Eros, would you like to look through a window in Rome and watch your master marching in Caesar’s victory parade, his arms crossed and tied, his head bowed in submission, his face red from shame, while the chariot of triumphant Caesar precedes him, putting the final stamp to his humiliation?

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                                  I would not see ’t.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$I would not.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Come, then, for with a wound I must be cured.$NEWLINE$Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn$NEWLINE$Most useful for thy country.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Then come on. I must be restored to health by an injury. Draw your trustworthy sword, which you have used in such service to your country.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                                       O sir, pardon me!
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Oh, sir, pardon me!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$When I did make thee free, swor’st thou not then$NEWLINE$To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once,$NEWLINE$Or thy precedent services are all$NEWLINE$But accidents unpurposed. Draw and come.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$When I freed you from slavery, didn’t you swear to do this when I asked you? Do it immediately, or all your previous services to me were accidental, without purpose. Take out your sword and come on.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Turn from me then that noble countenance$NEWLINE$Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Then turn your noble face away from me, that face that the whole world adores.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Lo thee!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Look!

paragraphs.original: He turns away
paragraphs.translated: He turns away.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$My sword is drawn.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$I have drawn my sword.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                      Then let it do at once$NEWLINE$The thing why thou hast drawn it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now let it carry out its purpose immediately.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$                                                                  My dear master,$NEWLINE$My captain, and my emperor, let me say,$NEWLINE$Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$My dear master, my captain, my sovereign, let me say before I strike this fatal blow: farewell.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$’Tis said, man, and farewell.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$You’ve said it, friend, and farewell to you.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Good-bye, great commander. Should I do it now?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                             Now, Eros.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Now, Eros.

paragraphs.original: EROS$NEWLINE$Why, there then!
paragraphs.translated: EROS$NEWLINE$Well, then, there!

paragraphs.original: Stabs himself
paragraphs.translated: He stabs himself.

paragraphs.original: Thus I do escape the sorrow$NEWLINE$Of Antony’s death.
paragraphs.translated: With this I avoid the grief of Antony’s death.

paragraphs.original: He dies
paragraphs.translated: He dies.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                         Thrice nobler than myself,$NEWLINE$Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what$NEWLINE$I should and thou couldst not. My Queen and Eros$NEWLINE$Have by their brave instruction got upon me$NEWLINE$A nobleness in record. But I will be$NEWLINE$A bridegroom in my death, and run into ’t$NEWLINE$As to a lover’s bed. Come then, and Eros,$NEWLINE$Thy master dies thy scholar. To do thus$NEWLINE$I learned of thee.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Brave Eros, three times more honorable than I am! You teach me what I should do but could not. My Queen and Eros have by their brave examples beaten me to the history books. But I will embrace death as a bridegroom does his bride, and rush to it as to a lover’s bed. Come then. Eros, your master dies your student. I learned to do this from you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: He falls on his sword
paragraphs.translated: He falls on his sword.

paragraphs.original: How! Not dead? Not dead?$NEWLINE$The guard, ho! Oh, dispatch me!
paragraphs.translated: What! I’m not dead? Not dead?—Guard, here! Oh, kill me!

paragraphs.original: Enter DERCETUS and others of a GUARD$NEWLINE$DERCETUS$NEWLINE$GUARD
paragraphs.translated: DERCETUS enters with three GUARDS.$NEWLINE$DERCETUS$NEWLINE$GUARDS

paragraphs.original: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$What’s the noise?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$What’s the trouble?

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I have done my work ill, friends. Oh, make an end$NEWLINE$Of what I have begun!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I’ve botched the job, friends. Oh, finish what I’ve begun.

paragraphs.original: SECOND GUARD$NEWLINE$                                             The star is fall’n.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND GUARD$NEWLINE$Our guiding light is out.

paragraphs.original: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$And time is at his period.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$And time itself is ended.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$                                                   Alas, and woe!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Sadness and despair!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Let him that loves me strike me dead.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Whoever’s a real friend should strike me dead.

paragraphs.original: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$Not I.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$Not me.

paragraphs.original: SECOND GUARD$NEWLINE$Nor I.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND GUARD$NEWLINE$Me neither.

paragraphs.original: THIRD GUARD$NEWLINE$Nor anyone.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD GUARD$NEWLINE$None of us.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt GUARD$NEWLINE$GUARD
paragraphs.translated: The GUARDS exit.$NEWLINE$GUARDS

paragraphs.original: DERCETUS$NEWLINE$Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
paragraphs.translated: DERCETAS$NEWLINE$Your death and destiny advise your followers to escape.

paragraphs.original: He takes up ANTONY’s sword$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: He takes up ANTONY’s sword$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings,$NEWLINE$Shall enter me with him.
paragraphs.translated: I only need to show your sword to Caesar and tell him about your death to get into his good favor.

paragraphs.original: Enter DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$DIOMEDES
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES enters.$NEWLINE$DIOMEDES

paragraphs.original: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Where’s Antony?
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Where’s Antony?

paragraphs.original: DERCETUS$NEWLINE$There, Diomed, there.
paragraphs.translated: DERCETAS$NEWLINE$There, Diomedes, there.

paragraphs.original: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Lives he? Wilt thou not answer, man?
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Is he still alive? Why don’t you answer me, man?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit DERCETUS$NEWLINE$DERCETUS
paragraphs.translated: DERCETAS exits.$NEWLINE$DERCETAS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword and give me$NEWLINE$Sufficing strokes for death.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Is that you, Diomedes? Draw your sword and give me enough blows to kill me.

paragraphs.original: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$                                                    Most absolute lord,$NEWLINE$My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Most powerful lord, my mistress Cleopatra sent me to you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$When did she send thee?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$When did she send you?

paragraphs.original: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$                                                  Now, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Just now, my lord.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                                Where is she?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Where is she?

paragraphs.original: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Locked in her monument. She had a prophesying fear$NEWLINE$Of what hath come to pass. For when she saw—$NEWLINE$Which never shall be found—you did suspect$NEWLINE$She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage$NEWLINE$Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead.$NEWLINE$But fearing since how it might work, hath sent$NEWLINE$Me to proclaim the truth, and I am come,$NEWLINE$I dread, too late.
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Locked in her tomb. She had a premonition of what has actually happened. She saw that you suspected her of negotiating a treaty with Caesar—which never will be true. Afraid that your anger would not subside, she sent you word she was dead. But later, fearing how that news might affect you, she sent me to tell you the truth. I’m afraid I’ve come too late.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, I prithee.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Too late, good Diomedes. Call my guard, please.

paragraphs.original: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$What ho, the Emperor’s guard! The guard, what ho!$NEWLINE$Come, your lord calls!
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$Hey out there! Emperor’s guards! Guards, hey! Come! Your lord calls for you!

paragraphs.original: Enter four or five of the GUARD of Antony$NEWLINE$GUARD
paragraphs.translated: Four or five of Antony’s GUARDS enter.$NEWLINE$GUARDS

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides.$NEWLINE$’Tis the last service that I shall command you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Carry me, good friends, to where Cleopatra is. It’s the last command I shall ever give you.

paragraphs.original: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear$NEWLINE$All your true followers out.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST GUARD$NEWLINE$We’re very sorry, sir, that you may not live to wear us out with your commands.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$                                                       Most heavy day!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$It’s a very sad day.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate$NEWLINE$To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome$NEWLINE$Which comes to punish us, and we punish it,$NEWLINE$Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up.$NEWLINE$I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends,$NEWLINE$And have my thanks for all.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$No, my friends, don’t please fate by giving it your sorrow as well. If we welcome our punishment, we punish it right back by seeming to take it lightly. Pick me up. I have often led you, now you must carry me, my good friends—and take my thanks for everything.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, bearing ANTONY and the body of EROS$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS
paragraphs.translated: They exit, carrying ANTONY and EROS’ body.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$EROS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLEOPATRA and her maids aloft, with CHARMIAN and IRAS$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, and IRAS enter with Cleopatra’s maids in the upper gallery.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$IRAS

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$O Charmian, I will never go from hence.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, Charmian, I will never leave this tomb!

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Be comforted, dear madam.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Be calm, dear lady.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                      No, I will not.$NEWLINE$All strange and terrible events are welcome,$NEWLINE$But comforts we despise. Our size of sorrow,$NEWLINE$Proportioned to our cause, must be as great$NEWLINE$As that which makes it.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No, I won’t. Strange and terrible events are all welcome, but I despise comforts. The size of my sorrow must be as great as its source.

paragraphs.original: Enter below DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$DIOMEDES
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES enters below.$NEWLINE$DIOMEDES

paragraphs.original: How now? Is he dead?
paragraphs.translated: What’s the news! Is he dead?

paragraphs.original: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$His death’s upon him, but not dead.$NEWLINE$Look out o’ th’ other side your monument.$NEWLINE$His guard have brought him thither.
paragraphs.translated: DIOMEDES$NEWLINE$He is close to death, but not dead yet. Look out the other window; his guard has brought him here.

paragraphs.original: Enter below ANTONY, and the guard bearing him$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: Guards enter, carrying ANTONY.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                                                        O sun,$NEWLINE$Burn the great sphere thou mov’st in. Darkling stand$NEWLINE$The varying shore o’ th’ world! O Antony,$NEWLINE$Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help!$NEWLINE$Help, friends below! Let’s draw him hither.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Oh, sun, burn up the orbit in which you move, so that the world may be dark forever! Oh, Antony, Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help! Help, friends below; lift him up here.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                                                     Peace!$NEWLINE$Not Caesar’s valor hath o’erthrown Antony,$NEWLINE$But Antony’s hath triumphed on itself.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Be calm! It was not Caesar’s bravery that conquered Antony but Antony’s that has triumphed over himself.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$So it should be, that none but Antony$NEWLINE$Should conquer Antony, but woe ’tis so!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$That’s the way it should be—only Antony should conquer Antony. But how terrible that it has happened!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I am dying, Egypt, dying. Only$NEWLINE$I here importune death awhile, until$NEWLINE$Of many thousand kisses the poor last$NEWLINE$I lay upon thy lips.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I am dying, Cleopatra, dying. I just beg death to wait awhile, until I place the last of our many thousands of kisses on your lips.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                                     I dare not, dear,$NEWLINE$Dear my lord, pardon, I dare not,$NEWLINE$Lest I be taken. Not th’ imperious show$NEWLINE$Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall$NEWLINE$Be brooched with me. If knife, drugs, serpents, have$NEWLINE$Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe.$NEWLINE$Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes$NEWLINE$And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor$NEWLINE$Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony—$NEWLINE$Help me, my women—We must draw thee up.$NEWLINE$Assist, good friends.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I don’t dare come down—forgive me, my lord—I don’t dare, for fear of capture. I will never be exhibited as lucky Caesar’s prize. If knives, poison, or snakes have edge, effect, or venom, I am safe from that fate. Your wife Octavia, with her self-effacing eyes and self-righteous assumptions, won’t get any praise from patronizing me. But come. Come up here, Antony—help me, ladies—we must carry you up. Help us, good friends.

paragraphs.original: They begin lifting him
paragraphs.translated: They lift him.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                         Oh, quick, or I am gone.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Oh, quick, before I’m gone.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Here’s sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord!$NEWLINE$Our strength is all gone into heaviness,$NEWLINE$That makes the weight. Had I great Juno’s power,$NEWLINE$The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up$NEWLINE$And set thee by Jove’s side. Yet come a little.$NEWLINE$Wishers were ever fools. Oh, come, come, come!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Such exercise! My lord is so heavy! Our strength has all turned into sadness. That’s what makes the weight. If I had the goddess Juno’s power, I would make the strong-winged messenger, Mercury, pick you up and seat you beside Jove. Up just a little more—wishes are always foolish—oh, come on, come on, come on!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: They heave ANTONY aloft to CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: They lift ANTONY up to CLEOPATRA.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA.

paragraphs.original: And welcome, welcome! Die when thou hast lived.$NEWLINE$Quicken with kissing. Had my lips that power,$NEWLINE$Thus would I wear them out.
paragraphs.translated: And welcome, welcome! Die where you have lived, in my arms. Let me revive you with my kisses. If my lips had the power to give life, I would wear them out like this.

paragraphs.original: She kisses him
paragraphs.translated: She kisses him.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$A heavy sight!
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$What a sad sight!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I am dying, Egypt, dying.$NEWLINE$Give me some wine and let me speak a little.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$I am dying, Cleopatra, dying. Give me some wine and let me say a few words.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No, let me speak, and let me rail so high$NEWLINE$That the false huswife Fortune break her wheel,$NEWLINE$Provoked by my offense.
paragraphs.translated:
CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No, let me talk, and let me scold to the heavens, so that
Fortune, that deceitful hussy, will become so upset that she breaks her wheel.$NEWLINE$Fortune, that deceitful hussy, will become so upset that she breaks her wheel.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                One word, sweet Queen:$NEWLINE$Of Caesar seek your honor, with your safety—Oh!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$One thing, dear Queen: request honor, as well as safety, from Caesar. Oh!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$They do not go together.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Honor and safety do not go together.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$                                                Gentle, hear me.$NEWLINE$None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Dear, listen to me: don’t trust any of Caesar’s men besides Proculeius.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$My resolution and my hands I’ll trust,$NEWLINE$None about Caesar.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$I’ll trust my determination and my hands, but none of Caesar’s men.

paragraphs.original: ANTONY$NEWLINE$The miserable change now at my end$NEWLINE$Lament nor sorrow at, but please your thoughts$NEWLINE$In feeding them with those my former fortunes,$NEWLINE$Wherein I lived the greatest prince o’ th’ world,$NEWLINE$The noblest, and do now not basely die,$NEWLINE$Not cowardly put off my helmet to$NEWLINE$My countryman—a Roman by a Roman$NEWLINE$Valiantly vanquished. Now my spirit is going.$NEWLINE$I can no more.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY$NEWLINE$Don’t mourn over this unhappy reversal of fortune at the end of my life. Remember my earlier lot, when I lived as the greatest, most noble prince in the world. I’m not dying shamefully, doffing my helmet to my countryman like a coward, but as a Roman, honorably conquered by another Roman. Now I feel my soul leaving. I can’t speak any more.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$                             Noblest of men, woo’t die?$NEWLINE$Hast thou no care of me? Shall I abide$NEWLINE$In this dull world, which in thy absence is$NEWLINE$No better than a sty? O see, my women,$NEWLINE$The crown o’ th’ earth doth melt. My lord!
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Most noble man, will you die? Don’t you care about me? Shall I stay in this dreary world, which is no better than a pigsty without you? Oh, look, ladies. The best of the world disappears. My lord!

paragraphs.original: ANTONY dies$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: ANTONY dies.$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: Oh, withered is the garland of the war.$NEWLINE$The soldier’s pole is fall’n! Young boys and girls$NEWLINE$Are level now with men. The odds is gone,$NEWLINE$And there is nothing left remarkable$NEWLINE$Beneath the visiting moon.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, the glory of war has faded. The flags have fallen. Young boys and girls are equal to men. There is nothing distinctive, nothing remarkable left in the world.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$                                                 Oh, quietness, lady!$NEWLINE$
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, stay calm, lady!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA swoons$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA faints.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$She’s dead too, our sovereign.
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Our Queen is dead too.

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Lady!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Lady!

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Madam!
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Madam!

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$O madam, madam, madam!
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Oh, madam, madam, madam!

paragraphs.original: IRAS$NEWLINE$Royal Egypt, Empress!
paragraphs.translated: IRAS$NEWLINE$Royal Egypt, Empress!

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA stirs$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$stirs
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA wakes up.$NEWLINE$CLEOPATRA

paragraphs.original: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Peace, peace, Iras.
paragraphs.translated: CHARMIAN$NEWLINE$Quiet, quiet, Iras.

paragraphs.original: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$No more but e’en a woman, and commanded$NEWLINE$By such poor passion as the maid that milks$NEWLINE$And does the meanest chares. It were for me$NEWLINE$To throw my scepter at the injurious gods,$NEWLINE$To tell them that this world did equal theirs$NEWLINE$Till they had stolen our jewel. All’s but naught.$NEWLINE$Patience is sottish, and impatience does$NEWLINE$Become a dog that’s mad. Then is it sin$NEWLINE$To rush into the secret house of death$NEWLINE$Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women?$NEWLINE$What, what, good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian?$NEWLINE$My noble girls! Ah, women, women! Look,$NEWLINE$Our lamp is spent, it’s out. Good sirs, take heart.$NEWLINE$We’ll bury him, and then, what’s brave, what’s noble,$NEWLINE$Let’s do ’t after the high Roman fashion$NEWLINE$And make death proud to take us. Come, away.$NEWLINE$This case of that huge spirit now is cold.$NEWLINE$Ah, women, women! Come. We have no friend$NEWLINE$But resolution, and the briefest end.
paragraphs.translated: CLEOPATRA$NEWLINE$Now I am no more than a woman, ruled by the same lowly passion as the maid who milks and does the humblest chores. I might now hurl my scepter at the destructive gods and tell them that this earthly world was as good as their heavenly one, until they stole away its jewel, Antony. Now all is for nothing. Patience is foolish. Impatience suits a mad dog. So why should it be a sin to rush toward death, to seek it out in its hiding place before it dares to come to find me? How are you, my ladies? Tell me! Cheer up! How are you, Charmian? My gallant girls! Ah, ladies, look: the light of our lives has gone out. Good noble ladies, be brave. We’ll bury him, and then we’ll commit acts as brave and fine as any Romans, and make death proud to take us. Come on, you can go. The container of that great soul is now cold. Ah, ladies, ladies! Let’s go. We have no friends but determination and the quickest death.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt, those above bearing off ANTONY’s body$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: They exit, carrying ANTONY’s body.$NEWLINE$ANTONY$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CAESAR, with AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, MAECENAS, GALLUS, and PROCULEIUS, and his council of war$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$DOLABELLA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$GALLUS$NEWLINE$PROCULEIUS
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR enters with his war council: AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, MAECENAS, GALLUS, and PROCULEIUS.$NEWLINE$CAESAR$NEWLINE$AGRIPPA$NEWLINE$DOLABELLA$NEWLINE$MAECENAS$NEWLINE$GALLUS$NEWLINE$PROCULEIUS

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield.$NEWLINE$Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks$NEWLINE$The pauses that he makes.
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Dolabella, go see Antony. Tell him to surrender. His position is hopeless. This delay makes him look ridiculous.

paragraphs.original: DOLABELLA$NEWLINE$                                                    Caesar, I shall.
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA$NEWLINE$Right away, Caesar.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: DOLABELLA exits.$NEWLINE$DOLABELLA

paragraphs.original: Enter DERCETUS, with the sword of ANTONY$NEWLINE$DERCETUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY
paragraphs.translated: DECRETUS enters carrying ANTONY’s sword.$NEWLINE$DECRETUS$NEWLINE$ANTONY

paragraphs.original: CAESAR$NEWLINE$Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar’st$NEWLINE$Appear thus to us?
paragraphs.translated: CAESAR$NEWLINE$What are you doing with a sword? Who do you think you are coming in here armed?

paragraphs.original: DERCETUS$NEWLINE$                                      I am called Dercetus.$NEWLINE$Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy$NEWLINE$Best to be served. Whilst he stood up and spoke,$NEWLINE$He was my master, and I wore my life$NEWLINE$To spend upon his haters. If thou please$NEWLINE$To take me to thee, as I was to him$NEWLINE$I’ll be to Caesar. If thou pleasest not,$NEWLINE$I yield thee up my life.
